PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise two matters of privilege concerning the work of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Articles in several newspapers this morning have made reference to a draft report of the committee and purport to reveal conclusions reached by the committee. The committee has considered these revelations at length at a meeting this morning and has concluded that publication of this material has caused substantial interference with the work of the committee.

PARA.TAB: The second matter concerns remarks made in this morning's edition of the ABC program AM by a committee member, the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan). The committee is of the opinion that the views expressed by the honourable member constitute a further substantial interference with the committee's work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Mr Speaker, I am having copies of the relevant articles—
—Because you are Labor.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong will resume his seat. The honourable member for Fraser is raising a very serious allegation. The honourable member for Fraser has the call.
—Yes, but he is not doing a very good job. This is totally partisan.
—Order! Those on my left will come to order. The honourable member for Fraser is raising a very serious matter.

—I should say in response to the honourable member for Kooyong that I am reporting the unanimous vote of the committee. I am having copies of the relevant articles and a transcript of the radio interview made. I ask that you consider these matters under standing orders 95 and 96 with a view to according precedence to a motion referring them to the Committee of Privileges.
—I will look at the issues that have been raised by the honourable member and report back to the House at a later time.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 22 December.
Senate's amendment—

PROCTEXT.PARA: Part 2, Division 2, line 8 (page 2) to line 10 (page 3), omit the Division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House insists on disagreeing to the amendment insisted on by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) contains three provisions which all aim at greater equity between various groups of disabled veterans, various categories of pensioners and the assessment of various forms of investments. This bill would enable veterans severely disabled by reason of their war service and who receive an extreme disablement adjustment to receive support for the education of their children through the veterans' children education scheme. The longer the delay, the longer the children of certain severely disabled veterans are denied the benefits available to children of other categories of disabled veterans.

PARA.TAB: The second provision is shares and listed securities. The bill aims to place the assessment of overseas investments on the same footing as investments in Australia. Existing provisions could encourage people in receipt of a service pension to evade the constraints of the income and assets test by investing in offshore ventures. This measure has already been implemented under the Social Security Act. Failure to pass the bill prolongs the discrepancy in the income and assets test applied by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security respectively. It also has the potential to discourage small-scale investment in Australian companies at a time when such investment is needed.

The third provision is allocated pensions and annuities. The bill standardises the treatment of allocated pensions and annuities with that of other forms of managed investments. The Senate amendment will reduce the equity of the service pension income and assets test. Pensioners with the same means and the same financial resources available to them should have the same amount of income and assets assessed for service pension purposes. People who invest in allocated pensions or allocated annuities should not be treated more beneficially than those who invest in other managed investments. The early passage of this measure would eliminate a number of inconsistencies and anomalies arising from the current treatment of allocated pensions and annuities.

As I have already mentioned on two other occasions, when this matter has come before the House and then been sent back to us from the Senate, the government has committed itself to a whole review of both veterans' pensions and social security pensions. The reality is that we cannot have these inconsistencies in place. The opposition talks about management and consistency in management, yet when we have a bill before us which would make the management of these pensions across the board consistent what happens? The opposition insists on inconsistencies and mismanagement, which will effectively be the case if these provisions are not passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to the script, Andrew.

—The honourable member for Moncrieff knows that there has been a review audit. The review is proceeding to look at all these issues for not only service pensioners but all pensioners. We have said, `Let's pass this legislation, let's pass these rules, so as to give continuity and additional benefits to certain veterans'. When we have passed this legislation and achieved consistency, we can look at the whole issue when the report of the review comes down. We will make determinations across the board for pensioners. That is what we should do if we want consistent administration, and that is all we have asked for. The Senate is quite mistaken in insisting in the majority on this inconsistency continuing, and the government will persist in its determination in this matter.

—This is a further step in the ongoing saga of the treatment of a whole range of pensioners' investments. I would like to take the opportunity to say once again—it is at least the 100th time I have said it in this place—that we do not share the government's enthusiasm for attacking pensioners in this way. I take the point of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) that a review is going on. We are aware of that. The shadow minister for social security, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), has expressed a number of concerns about the sorts of issues that that review should look at. Hopefully, in the end, it will come up with some recommendations that we can support which will change the assets test in particular and the incomes test in a way that takes account of the circumstances out in the real world which have changed so dramatically, particularly with interest rates coming down.

PARA.TAB: From our point of view, the treatment of allocated pensions, managed investments, shares and a whole range of issues has never been satisfactory. In every case we have argued that this has disadvantaged a significant number of pensioners, and we still hold that view. The argument that the parliamentary secretary put forward this morning in the veterans area that this will make this legislation consistent with other legislation, in my view, does not answer the objections we have to do it at all. It may be an excuse for changing the veterans affairs legislation, but it is only an excuse.

That argument does not address the fundamental issue. The attempt to treat these sorts of investments in a way that somehow takes account of the gains in their value that do not translate into part of a pensioner's income is obviously flawed. We have had this argument so many times, but it has continually fallen on deaf ears. The opposition spokesman is not in the chamber at the moment, so speaking on behalf of the opposition and veterans—and, Mr Speaker, you would be aware of my interest in these matters and my desire to take every opportunity to pursue these issues—I indicate that we do not accept this proposal.

Let me say what I have said before: even if there were an argument—I say it is an excuse—for changing the veterans' legislation to bring it in line with the social security legislation, I would be prepared to argue in this place that veterans should be treated differently to others. They are treated differently. Veterans in this country are concerned all the time about the way they are treated by this government and the way their benefits are constantly downgraded. As the veterans become less of a political force by sheer diminishing numbers, I am quite sure there will be an ongoing attack on them to diminish their importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only from your side.

—The attack so far has come consistently from the government side of the House. I am concerned that over time people tend to forget the service these people have given our country. I am thinking particularly of the older veterans, but also the veterans of my generation—the Vietnam veterans—and a new range of veterans from the more recent conflicts such as the Gulf War.

PARA.TAB: In my view, veterans have a very special place in this country and we should not forget that. I will argue in this place at every opportunity for the special treatment and recognition of veterans and the setting aside and quarantining of their benefits. The suggestion being made is that because we treat social security pensioners and their managed investments, allocated pensions and share portfolios in this way—something we have been consistently opposed to—we should now do the same for veterans. In my view that does not carry weight at all. It was wrong to treat social security pensioners in that way and it is equally wrong to treat veteran pensioners in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I take this opportunity to apologise for the Leader of National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the opposition spokesman for veterans' affairs, not being here. He is in Lockhart this morning. I thank the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) for very ably addressing this issue on behalf of the opposition. I take this opportunity to affirm what the honourable member for McPherson has said: we are very strongly of the view that the amendment made in the Senate should be retained. We believe that the House should accept that amendment.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the amendment was essentially to maintain the status quo for the assets and income testing of veterans until we have the results of the independent inquiry that the government has agreed is appropriate into income and assets testing generally. We see no necessity to make changes to bring the veterans' arrangements into line with what we regard as the lowest common denominator which is operating in the Department of Social Security.

The way in which assets and income testing is undertaken in the Department of Veterans' Affairs is considerably different to the way in which it is being undertaken in the Department of Social Security. The way in which the recipients of benefits who have modest investments either in managed investments or in shares are treated in respect of those investments is quite different not because of the legislative arrangements but, I suspect, because of the way in which one department treats its clients as against the way in which another department treats its clients.

I was very interested to learn that, in relation to managed investments and shares where changes are being undertaken in accordance with the new legislative regime that operates in the Department of Social Security, clients are not given any particulars about the way in which reductions to their benefits are occasioned. There is no listing of their portfolio and no advice is given as to the manner in which calculations are undertaken to effect a reduction. The department, which I understand buys information from advisers as to variations to the capital value of managed investments or shares, gives no advice as to what information has been provided to it. The clients are simply given advice by the department that a change has been effected. When the Department of Veterans' Affairs makes these arrangements it gives all that information and the calculations to its clients so that they are in a position to check the information they have against the information that is held by the department.

So it is clear that, in areas that are not directly related to this legislation but which relate to the way in which the legislation is intended to operate, the departments already use totally different means of calculating these arrangements where one would expect a common approach. So we have to ask ourselves why, at this point in time, the veterans' affairs legislation has to be brought into line with the Department of Social Security legislation if the departments separately administering these matters use different procedures and provide different information not because of any statutory differences but simply as a matter of practice. Why do we have to bring them both into line when clearly they have different administrative arrangements in place to satisfy their administrative needs for their client base?

I have had a briefing, for which I thank the government, from the consultant who has been asked to undertake this independent inquiry. It is interesting that, while I personally have doubts about the ambitious nature of the program for the review that the consultant has set having regard to the nature of the very considerable task that has to be undertaken, the consultant seems to believe that he will be able to expedite the process. He is talking about bringing forward the date for the preliminary report, which will be made public, from July to June. He is hopeful that he may be able to speed up the process.

I do not know whether that is right or whether it is wrong in terms of what will be the end result, but the whole issue of this inquiry has of course been in the government's hands. The inquiry was announced last November. If the government was of the view that it wanted to get these matters sorted out quickly, it could have got its consultants in place even earlier than was outlined in the announcements of the last week or so. It could have been up and running with the task.

All of the delays with the inquiry to this point and all of the doubts about the timetable that has been set are in the government's hands. The opposition's view of this legislation and of social security legislation—I have made this clear before—is that we will not accommodate any amendments to assets and income testing until such time as the independent inquiry has undertaken its review and the government is in a position to give effect to the substantive results that we believe will come from that inquiry.

In our view, the system of assets testing, particularly as it relates to unrealised capital gains and the treatment of managed investments, is harsh, unconscionable, unfair and has already produced quite different results between beneficiaries. We do not believe that the amendments proposed for veterans will achieve a fairer and more equitable system in terms of the major issues that need to be addressed. For that reason we believe there needs to be a cooling-off period, a proper and cooperative approach taken to the review, the substantial issues need to be addressed and then we can look at amendments to both veterans' affairs legislation and social security legislation in light of that review.

Rather than this ping-pong between the Senate and the House of Representatives, we would encourage the government to accept the amendment of the Senate to get the legislation up and running on the other matters that have been dealt with and essentially agreed. There is no need for any continuation of this matter. The government needs to know of our resolve to see this matter through. I suggest to the government that the easiest and simplest solution at this time would be to accept the amendments and allow the rest of the proposed changes to the veterans' affairs legislation to proceed.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made a number of comments about the government's position. It is very clear. On the question of the review, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) would be interested in a couple of matters. The government is trying to expedite the review, although within the parameter of making sure that we achieve a result. It is interesting that the honourable member expressed some concern that it might be brought forward from July to June, yet the day before yesterday when we discussed this measure at least one opposition person said that the review should be expedited and brought forward. This is another example of inconsistent presentation on the part of the opposition in this matter.

PARA.TAB: The review involves consultants, and people in the community—pensioners and ex-service, community and ethnic organisations—will be consulted. People have also been asked to provide submissions to the review. Rather than just having a chat with the head of the review, I suggest that, if the honourable member has actual concerns about the implementation of the measures that are in place in the social security area, for example, he would do well to make a submission to the review listing these problems to ensure that they are taken into account. I urge him to do so if he is genuinely interested in an outcome of the review which does take account of all the problems.

Let me also say that the review committee includes Mrs June Healy, national secretary of the Returned Services League, who was nominated by the RSL to ensure that veterans' interests are represented. I say once again that we do need consistency between the two acts for veterans and other social security beneficiaries. We need this legislation now and the government insists that it be passed.
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Theophanous's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Dr Theophanous) agreed to:
That the bill be laid aside.
Message received from the Senate returning the bill and acquainting the House that the Senate insists upon the amendment disagreed to by the House.
Ordered that the message be taken into consideration forthwith.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Part 7, line 17, (page 51) to line 11 (page 57), omit the Part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House insists on disagreeing to the amendment insisted on by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the third time I have repeated in this House the government's reasons for accepting the amendment to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). I remind the House that if this amendment is again rejected, we will provide a basis for a double dissolution in relation to this bill. I urge the opposition to seriously consider what it is doing before it again rejects this amendment.

PARA.TAB: The bill requires full passage to implement beneficial changes to service pension assessment and to continue the pension assessment link with the Social Security Act. The Senate opposes the managed investment amendments contained in the bill. The opposition wants to delay these amendments until the independent review of the income and assets tests for service and social security pensions hands down its report. The opposition claims that there are winners and losers resulting from the managed investment proposals. The three managed investment proposals contained in this bill are all beneficial to service pensioners with this form of investment. In fact, the beneficial nature of the amendments is demonstrated by the proposals being backdated to commence from 1 April 1993.

The first proposal clarifies the operation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act by ensuring that all losses from managed investments can be offset against profits from other managed investments. The second measure ensures that, where an investment has been held for less than 12 months and only an interim rate of return has been declared, that rate will be maintained as the annual rate of return. The third measure addresses the effect on certain investments caused by industry changes to friendly societies. Where the friendly society converts to a life office and the conditions of the investment remain substantially the same, this measure will safeguard these investments by preserving the current assessment rules.

The opposition wishes to delay these measures until after the review. The review will examine the conceptual framework, design, principles and actual operation of the income and assets tests as they apply to social security, age disability support and sole parents' pensions and to the veterans' affairs service pension. Also part of the review's role will be to examine the relationship between the income and assets tests and the taxation system.

We have said that we need these measures to give consistency across government departments until the process of the review is completed and we will then look at consistent changes, if they are required, in both areas. That is what we have been saying throughout. For the opposition to insist that no changes be made in the veterans' area when changes have been made in the social security area is to insist on this contradiction between the two areas which cannot be allowed to continue if we are to have consistent government administration. We therefore insist that we continue with these changes and we insist that the changes be accepted. That is the position of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as you may have anticipated, the opposition will not agree to the amendment to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Let me make this abundantly clear: if the government had really been talking about consistency in relation to its administration, it would have implemented the amendments to the veterans' affairs legislation at the same time that it implemented changes to the social security legislation. It did not see fit to do so. It brought the changes in at a separate time on a separate basis in separate legislation. It saw no necessity for consistency in terms of application.

PARA.TAB: In the area of social security these changes were made to managed investments and the financial impact was detailed by the government to be negligible. Their operation in the Department of Social Security produced an outcome whereby some people owning managed investments have received significant reductions in their entitlements while other social security beneficiaries may have received modest increases. According to my recollection, the first adjustments that were made produced fairly modest changes in both directions, but the later adjustments that were made—particularly as there were significant increases in the value of the all-ordinaries index of share prices—led to a far more draconian impact than was at first envisaged by the government.

Now the government is saying that it wants to bring the veterans' affairs legislation into line with the Department of Social Security legislation. The impact of this legislation was adverse for some and positive for others, but when the government applies the same test for the veterans' affairs legislation it wants us to believe that there will only be winners. I do not know how the scheme that we are being told we are implementing here, which in terms of application will be consistent with that of the Department of Social Security, will only produce winners when the same scheme has produced winners and losers. It does not make sense.

The failure—because the government wants to make this an issue between the Senate and the House of Representatives—to implement other aspects of the veterans' affairs legislation may have an adverse impact, but let it be clearly understood that any adverse impact of the failure to implement or to pass the balance of the legislation is on the government's head, not on the head of the opposition.

In relation to assets testing, if the government wants to make an issue of the question of unrealised capital gains on shares and its proposals for treating managed investments in the same way as it treats unrealised capital gains on shares, and if it wants to have an election on that matter, it should bring it on. We will fight it on that issue. If the government thinks that is the most important issue upon which its future depends, it should bring it on. Let us have a double dissolution now.

It needs to be clearly understood that these matters are important to the opposition. We believe that there ought to be an interregnum so the inquiry can be fully pursued and that the status quo in relation to these matters ought to remain. As I said earlier in a debate on another bill, the way in which the Department of Veterans' Affairs has implemented the issue of assets testing and the approach in relation to clients is quite different from the approach taken by the Department of Social Security. It has nothing to do with the legislation that is before the House; it simply does it differently.

The fact is that the government did not see fit to make these amendments in legislation dealing with the Social Security Act. If it had seen that these two pieces of legislation ought to be in tandem, that they ought to sit and run together, that changes ought to be effected at the same time and in the same way, it could have implemented that legislation in that way at that time. But the government saw fit to bring it in later, after it had announced the review.

Our view is that the status quo ought to remain. We do not see any hardship in relation to that. We believe that the government should accept the amendments of the Senate and pass the balance of the bill forthwith. It ought to await the outcome of the independent inquiry, when I am sure that on any balanced consideration of income and assets testing the result will be significant suggestions for reform and change.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) is good at shouting about these matters, but when it comes to logic he is somewhat wanting. His problem is that the changes in relation to managed investments in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) are all positive.

PARA.TAB: As we said, an inquiry is taking place into the whole question of assets and managed investments. But each measure in this bill is positive for service pensioners. Because the opposition wants to make a point about its position with respect to managed investments, it has rejected this bill, but the bill is all positive. The honourable member has said that the overall impact in the Department of Social Security is negative for some and positive for others. That is not in issue in this bill. The three measures in this bill are all positive. The government has decided to backdate these measures to 1 April 1993 so that they can have a positive impact for service pensioners.

The reality is that the argument from the honourable member for Berowra is quite flawed. If the opposition wants to take up the principle, it should make a substantial submission to the review. It should put its position in relation to these issues. All it does is say that it opposes this and that. It has not put a comprehensive position in relation to assets and managed investments and pensions.

The opposition is trying to make a political issue out of this matter. As a consequence, veterans who will benefit from this legislation will miss out. This is very positive legislation for veterans. It is a very sad day when, to make a political point, the opposition comes to the view that it will reject a bill which contains positive measures for veterans. We are quite pleased to support this bill and these amendments. We insist on our position.
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Theophanous's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Dr Theophanous) agreed to:
That the bill be laid aside.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 23 February, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support these appropriation bills because they are an essential part of the government's fiscal policy. It is a crucial part of this government's strategy and policy to create jobs and to generate growth and exports for this country. At the outset, let me congratulate the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) on an outstanding first speech. Let me also assure him that he will have my full support for his efforts to obtain an international airport at Badgerys Creek. Indeed, I am Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works and my committee recommended this and it was a great pity that the government did not take up our recommendation. I agree with his comments that this project represents the best opportunity for industry clustering and employment growth in Sydney's west and south-west in the 1990s.

PARA.TAB: As I have indicated my support to him for Badgerys Creek, I am sure he would also support me in my efforts to obtain a new link road from the coast to the highlands and also for the completion of the Maldon-Dombarton rail link, because he knows that these projects would complement the other and we must look not only at the south-west of Sydney but indeed at the south-west of New South Wales. I am sure that the honourable member for Werriwa will have a long and distinguished career in this parliament.

Australia's great export, coal, is under considerable threat at the moment. No industry has been more restructured and no workers have made a bigger contribution to this restructuring than the coalminers. Yet, jobs in the industry today are under greater threat than ever before. This, in no small measure, is because of the inability of the producers, especially in relation to coking coal, to maintain existing prices and volume from the Japanese buyers.

Only a few weeks ago they were called from their luxury hotels in Tokyo to the centralised negotiating team, also in Tokyo. After BHP caved in on prices, the other producers had no option but to follow them. In the past, when prices dropped there could be a volume increase, thus maintaining the share of the market, but this time they caved in on both prices and volumes. This will cost Australia some $370 million.

Coal is far too important to the economy of Australia, to our export earnings, to be left in the hands of the producers alone. A national coal authority should be established to oversee and coordinate negotiations between Australian coal exporters and overseas buyers, especially the Japanese authorities, in order to achieve better pricing outcomes.

There should also be developed a national role in the management and development of Australia's coal reserves and in the issue of new coalmining leases. It is not exaggerating to say that there has been more coal sterilised in Australia than will ever be mined. This coal is lost forever to this country. This has been caused not only by poor mining methods but also because we have never had a national plan for the development of coal reserves in this country.

The United Mine Workers, who will be rallying outside this building next week, are calling on the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) to set up an inquiry, to be chaired by a prominent person, into the effects on the industry of coal price settlements. Terms of reference could be established after consultation. Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, I know that you support this call, as do I, for the establishment by the government of a special fund to assist displaced mine workers.

We often hear the argument that a centralised marketing body for coal would not work. Yet many of those putting this argument have no difficulty with a centralised meat authority, a centralised wheat authority and, until it became unpopular, a centralised wool authority. The Japanese are used to dealing with a centralised authority. It is not as if we are dealing with a small amount. For example, of the 129 million tonnes of coal exported last year, 64 million tonnes went to the Japanese. It is far and away our most important export for coal. As I have stressed, the Japanese are used to dealing with centralised authorities; they themselves negotiate with the owners from a centralised position.

Given the difficulties in this industry, the competitive situation in the world and new entries into the market, there will be changes in the industry and the miners will accommodate these as they have accommodated changes in the past. But they do have an entitlement to some form of security in their employment, especially as they have been in the forefront of restructuring. The coalminers have accepted changed work practices, retrenchments, relocation and mine closures in order to obtain greater efficiency in the industry. They have also accepted them in the so far vain hope that these miners who remain in the industry will have some long-term security of employment. They have made the Australian coal industry a world leader in its field, and this should be duly recognised.

Representing as I do the port of Kembla, I am concerned about the future of Australian shipping. It is nothing short of a national disgrace that Australian exports in the main are not carried by Australian shipping. Indeed, less than five per cent of our exports are transported under Australian flagships.

Some argue that because so little Australian produce is carried in Australian ships, we should sell off what remains of the fleet. Such a view is short-sighted in the extreme. This has never stopped the economic rationalists in the past. The age of world shipping is increasing. Within a few years there will be a massive shortage of world shipping. Indeed, if we started building today there would still be a shortage. This shortage will apply not only to vessels but also crews, especially officers. What is our response to this emerging crisis in world shipping? The response for many in Australia is to sell off what ships we have and to open even further the Australian coastline to the ageing rust buckets of the world.

Few countries are as dependent on shipping for their export revenue as Australia. We should be investigating urgently the possibility of shipbuilding in Australia. I wonder what has happened to the report on the shipbuilding industry entitled In the wake of the `Bounty', a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology tabled in this chamber in May 1982. Why was it allowed to sink without trace?

Sometimes I wonder whether indeed we are the clever country. We most certainly are not a very adventurous country, especially when it comes to investment. We are not good at responding to challenges, forward thinking or planning. If we were good at forward thinking and planning, we would realise that Australia will be hit harder than most by the world shortage of shipping. We should be embarking on a shipbuilding project in Australia now, preferably at Port Kembla, as was recommended in that report. For those who say that it is too expensive to build ships in Australia, my response is: look at some of the shipbuilding nations now. Last June I inspected a shipbuilding yard on the outskirts of Copenhagen in Denmark. Their wage structure and work conditions are very similar to ours. In fact, their wage structure is slightly higher.

This particular yard had one ship being built and another ship on the order book. They would never start building one ship until they had another one in the order book. They have continually been able to do this. If they can do it with their higher wage structure, I do not see why Australia could not do it. Even Japan's wage structure rivals ours. Finland, with a wage structure even higher than ours, has embarked on a shipbuilding project. So much for those who say we cannot compete.

I would like to conclude my comments on a matter of particular interest and concern to me—the recognition of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. I do not want to say anything that might increase tensions between various communities in Australia. We in this country, whatever our background, have always prided ourselves that people have come from many troubled parts of the world to this country and not brought their problems with them.

I was very disturbed at recent activities in Melbourne concerning the property of both Macedonians and Greeks. I appeal to those on both sides not to do or say anything that would increase tension. This appeal must go to those who occupy positions of responsibility in the community, such as the New South Wales Minister for Ethnic Affairs. I thought his statement condemning the federal government's recognition of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia was not only unwise but also uncalled for.

It is not as if Australia is the first and only country to recognise the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. In fact, we have been amongst the last. We waited feebly until the Europeans recognised Macedonia. It was only after the United States moved to recognise Macedonia that Australia belatedly followed suit. So much for an independent foreign policy!

We have unfortunately placed restrictions on the opening of a consular office. I find this strange. I would urge that this consular office be opened as quickly as possible. I represent many Macedonians and I know the difficulty that they have faced in recent years over getting a visa when they wanted to visit the land of their birth or, indeed, as do many people who come from overseas, they wanted to arrange property settlements there. There has been a great difficulty in doing this because there have not been consular facilities in this country.

I also find it rather strange that we are demanding that they not display their flag or any other symbol. It would be like an Australian coat of arms without the kangaroo or emu being displayed and the flag that we share with several other countries, including New Zealand, not being displayed.

If the Macedonians are not to display their ethnicity, it is a wonder that we did not ask them to change their language. We are quibbling over the name Macedonia. What language are we going to say they speak? Are we going to deny that the Macedonians speak Macedonian? It is a nonsense. If a country is having a dispute with another country about the flag or the symbols—and I know that there are strong feelings on both sides about these issues—that is between those two countries. Australia has no role in taking one side or the other, regardless of the pressure that may be exerted by various community groups.

There is also no place in Australia for the hatreds and misunderstandings going back hundreds of years. I urge Greece to lift the embargo against Macedonia and to open the port of Salonika to enable supplies to get to Macedonia. Given the size and population of Macedonia, it is ludicrous to say that it has territorial claims on Greece. Macedonia wants only to live in peace and harmony with its neighbours, and we should encourage that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). These bills deal with the money matters that directly affect the government and every Australian. Because of the wide ranging nature of these bills, it is inevitable that debate tends to range across a number of issues. I note with interest that my friend the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has just dealt with the coal industry, the shipping industry, linguistics and foreign affairs within the ambit of this debate, and quite appropriately so.

PARA.TAB: I will attempt to confine my remarks principally to the issues of taxation. But, in my opening comments, I want to reflect on the principal appropriation issue currently affecting this chamber: that is, the question of the so-called sports rorts and the involvement of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). I am prompted to make a comment not merely because these are appropriation bills but also because of the remarks attributed to Senator Richardson earlier this week. He was critical of the opposition's criticism of the sports rorts affair because—as Senator Richardson said—after all, all the minister has done is ensure that the poorest electorates receive the most attention through this particular scheme.

I cannot let that remark go unchallenged. Had it been a fact that the poorest electorates were represented by the ALP and had therefore attracted the greatest portion of the funding, I would have no grounds for my criticism, but the simple and frequently forgotten reality is that the poorest electorates in Australia are represented by members of the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! People like me.

—As the honourable member for Moncrieff said, regrettably she represents one of those electorates, and so do I. My electorate, on a range of median incomes, is the 10th poorest electorate in Australia. All but two of the 10 poorest electorates in Australia are represented by members of the opposition. As a matter of fact, all but four of the 20 poorest electorates in Australia are represented by members of the coalition and all but 11 of the 40 poorest are represented by the coalition.

PARA.TAB: In the context of that simple reality, we cannot escape the fact that the poorest electorate in Australia, based on median family income, the electorate of Wide Bay, received about $50,000 from the sports grants scheme. I believe that the electorate of Canberra, represented by the minister, received $450,000. So there are no grounds for Senator Richardson's claim that there was some sort of equity in the distribution of this money. Clearly, the electorates represented by people on this side of the House are the poorest of all, based on median family incomes. We are the people who have failed because of the way this scheme has been jaundiced. We have failed to attract appropriate funding for our electorates not for want of adequate representation but because clearly that representation was put under the eye of the minister, who manipulated the scheme to suit her and the government's particular ends.

There is no way that the appropriation of moneys under the sports rorts scheme can be said to have been on the basis of need. Such an argument cannot be defended and should not be advanced by members of the government, particularly someone of Senator Richardson's status. I stand here, as does the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), representing more than my share of people whose incomes are below the national average. It is on behalf of some of those people that I want to address my remarks in this appropriation debate.

I am not suggesting that this is all a one-sided debate. I am not suggesting that everything that we stand for is white and that everything the government stands for is black. The argument is never quite like that. As a matter of fact, in recognition of some of the needs in my electorate, the government initiated an inquiry into horticultural practice in Australia. This week, the horticultural task force, headed by Senator Sherry, handed down its report. I welcome that report and many of its recommendations. I point out for the benefit of the House that, in the election campaign, the opposition proposed to initiate such an inquiry itself. It was in response to that opposition initiative that the government set up its inquiry under Senator Sherry.

What does Senator Sherry recommend to assist the fruit growers in my electorate and some of those in rural areas who earn incomes far below the national median? One of the things Senator Sherry is recommending, which I endorse, is that new horticultural plantings ought to attract some form of tax deductibility. Under the present arrangements—as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, may be aware, given the nature of your electorate—tax deductibility is available wherever trees are put in the ground as replacements for existing plantings, but it is not available where trees are put in the ground as part of a new planting area. If the government is serious about ensuring that horticulture makes a net contribution of $2 billion to our overseas income by the year 2000, then this sort of initiative is what we need. I cannot stand here this morning and commend the government. All that has happened is that Senator Sherry has recommended that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) ought to introduce into the budget provisions that would allow for tax deductibility on new horticultural plantings.

I was interested in this tax deductibility—as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be—because both of our electorates have prominent wine grape growing areas. Quite a controversy was raging following the last budget, when the government proposed to lift the tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent and subsequently negotiated that back to a figure of 26 per cent on the grounds that it would offer the wine industry a package of reforms. Among those reforms was the proposal to allow tax deductibility for the planting of new vineyards. It was that particular reform that gave impetus to this call for tax deductibility for horticultural plantings as well. While the government may have been well intentioned in offering tax deductibility for the planting of vineyards, what it did was open a Pandora's box.

My office was besieged by people, particularly dried fruit growers, who said, `How will the government determine whether the sultana vines I plant are being planted for wine production or dried fruit production?'. Even if we were able—I do not know how—to negotiate that particular minefield, what do I say to my other dried fruit growers who may be planting Elberta peach trees, which could be for either juice production or dried fruit production? Why are they to be disadvantaged as dried fruit growers as opposed to the dried vine fruit growers?

Senator Sherry and his horticultural team have recommended that the government take up this plea to provide an opportunity for tax deductibility to be offered for all new plantings, whether in the horticultural or viticultural area. It is this effort of tax equity that I recognise and applaud. I encourage the Treasurer, as he prepares the May budget statement, to pick up this particular recommendation.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would also be aware because of the controversy that surrounded the wine tax package that there was a small segment of the dealcoholised wine industry which was effectively disadvantaged because tax on it went from 10 per cent to 21 per cent. While it was later pruned back, that represented an effective rise of 110 per cent in taxation simply because these were dealcoholised Yet their segment of the marketplace was not with the alcoholic spirit production but in competing with fruit juices and grape juices. They now find themselves at a shelf price disadvantage.

In a question to the Treasurer I asked that he address this problem, and in fairness to the Treasurer I must say that that day he responded to me and indicated that he would take the matter up. But, rather like the issue of deductibility for plantings, we still have not had any specific action from the government. While I have this opportunity I call on the Treasurer to pick up the issue of the inequity that dealcoholised wine producers are currently facing and the relative inequity that will apply to horticultural production if he does not introduce the recommendations suggested by Senator Sherry.

A further recommendation made by Senator Sherry that I would like to commend him for and bring to the attention of the House is the proposal that fresh fruit juices ought not to attract sales tax. In terms of giving horticultural industry a bit of an impetus, that has a great deal to commend it, but it has even more to commend it in terms of tax equity. After all, if for a typical Australian breakfast people choose to put milk on their cereal they are putting on their cereal what is effectively a beverage which is regarded by the government as food, that is, whole milk. Whole white milk does not attract sales tax and neither should it. But if people choose at that same breakfast to take another—

TALK.START.PARA: —To put wine on your cornflakes!

—The honourable member for McEwen is much too flippant. If people choose at that same breakfast to take another whole food product known as fresh 100 per cent fruit juice, which in terms of its food consistency is no different from milk, they are consuming a product that has a tax on it. So, in the interests of tax equity, if this government is serious, as the honourable member for McEwen so loudly proclaims it is, about tax equity and taxes on food, there ought not be a tax on 100 per cent pure fresh fruit juice. This recommendation made by the honourable member for McEwen's colleague Senator Sherry ought to be picked up and introduced by the government in the budget—not as suggested by the opposition, though we have long called for it, but as suggested by a member of the government Senator Sherry in a report handed down this week.

PARA.TAB: The government has said in this horticultural product report that it believes that horticulture has the capacity to generate $2 billion of net export income by the year 2000. The viticultural section has already indicated its commitment to reaching a target of $1 billion in wine exports by the year 2000. I believe these targets are achievable if the government is prepared not simply to hand down reports that make people feel better about an industry but to take the action recommended in those reports and to take wider action to ensure that horticultural and viticultural practice in Australia is more competitive and more able to meet the sort of competition that it faces from fellow overseas producers.

There are two other areas where I believe the government could do a great deal to assist horticultural producers. The first—and this it is a topical issue given that it has been in the news so much in the last 10 days—is the question of wharf reform. It is a question of recognising that it is not just a matter of producing and growing the product in Australia. It is a matter of getting it overseas at a competitive price and on time. At that point we have in the past the failed. The government has failed to take the positive action that producers deserve when they are prepared to produce quality export products. In the past producers have found their products sitting on the wharf failing to be delivered on time.

The second issue is the question of industrial relations. Of all industries in Australia, the industry that offers the most opportunity for value adding is the horticultural industry. The success of our value adding very much depends on the sorts of industrial relations policies we introduce.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I was interested, as you would have been, to hear your colleague the honourable member for Throsby indicate that the Finnish people had a successful shipbuilding industry with a wage structure not unlike ours. He implied that the opposition would in some way be offended by that and that the opposition's target was to cut people's wages in order to be competitive. He is wrong. There is no way the opposition has ever advocated lower wage rates for Australian employees. In fact we went into the last election saying that we did not mind how much Australian employees earned; the more they earned the better we liked it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No ceiling.

—As the honourable member for Moncrieff has said, there was no ceiling, but it needed to be productivity related. We need to ensure that what we are producing is what people are being paid for. I relate this illustration to my comments about the horticultural industry because the real lesson for me in industrial relations came through my involvement in the horticultural industry. Horticultural fruit pickers, frequently much maligned and seen at the bottom end of the socioeconomic scale, were the people who found they made the most money when they were no longer paid on an hourly rate but paid for what they did. Suddenly the job became interesting, worth while and productive. Their incomes went up dramatically and so did the fruit growers' gross return and net return.

PARA.TAB: What the opposition is saying is that whether people are building ships or producing oranges or wine they ought to be paid for what they do. The honourable member for Throsby's insinuation that we stood for pruning wages deserves to be rejected out of hand. If we are serious about reaching export targets, if we are serious about generating more income for Australia in terms of what we sell overseas, and particularly if we are serious about value adding to primary production, we need to be serious about deregulating our industrial relations structure and allowing people to be more productive and to earn more for being more productive.

I notice with pleasure that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) is at the table. I was in the chair when he was making a contribution in this debate yesterday. The honourable member for Fraser is a member of the government for whom, I believe, all people have a great regard because he is courageous, he believes in what he says and he stands by what he believes in. The honourable member for Fraser in picking up the point that, in his view, we are the lowest taxed country in the OECD made a plea in his speech yesterday for some form of jobs levy because he wanted to see an opportunity for further jobs creation.

I recognise the sincerity with which he made that plea but I reject it out of hand. Frankly, all that the opposition has been about and the focus of our remarks in relation to these bills is to ensure that Australian taxpayers are not frustrated with additional unnecessary tax burdens. I see an opportunity for jobs creation, whether in the horticultural area as outlined by Senator Sherry or in the viticultural area or in any other area of industrial production and export, as we build our industrial base and become a more productive country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the long-term unemployed?

—I pick up the point made about the long-term unemployed. Much of our present unemployment is a reflection of the fact that we have not been about developing export markets and giving the opportunity for more Australians to be involved in a productive way.

PARA.TAB: Look at the comments made, for example, by the regional task force. Look at the comments made about the opportunities that exist in regional Australia for developing export markets. As I said, I recognise the sincerity with which the honourable member for Fraser called for a jobs levy. But the opposition has said that we should resist anything that frustrates Australian employers in employing people. That is why the opposition stood for the abolition of the payroll tax—because it is a tax that distinctly and deliberately discourages employers from employing people. We want to stand for a tax base which is fairly apportioned and which minimises the degree to which employers are discouraged from employing people.

Why have we been opposed to the differential between leaded and unleaded fuel? Because the productive base of Australia, its rural base, would be adversely affected by such a differential. Is it true, as the honourable member for Fraser contended yesterday, that we are the lowest taxed country around the globe? Of course it is not. We are the lowest taxed country relative to the OECD. We do have lower taxes than Belgium, Luxembourg, Holland, Denmark or Austria but we certainly do not have a tax base dramatically lower than the USA, or North-East or South-East Asia. As soon as I say that, the government asks if I want a lifestyle like North-East or South-East Asia. No, I do not.

I am not proposing that our tax level should fall; I am suggesting that as it rises we lose the opportunity to be competitive. If we are serious about generating jobs, we need to be serious about Australia's competitive edge relative to those against whom we compete—the people of North-East and South-East Asia. We in the opposition have stood not for a dramatic fall in tax but for a fairer tax system in order to create jobs. (Time expired)
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Before continuing debate on the appropriation bills, I will allow the honourable member for Fraser to make a short personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to clarify to the House a statement that I made this morning about privilege. I reported to the House that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts had unanimously proposed that the reports in this morning's media about a draft report we have under consideration be referred to the Privileges Committee. I want to make it quite clear that that unanimous request for a referral did not refer to the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) or her remarks on AM.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would just like a little clarification. You indicated that the honourable member for Fraser was claiming misrepresentation. He was surely speaking on indulgence. He cannot claim misrepresentation on the grounds of having said something which gave a false impression. That was surely not a misrepresentation; that was speaking on indulgence. He had not been misrepresented. He had, perhaps inadvertently, misrepresented the committees' position. That is the point.
—The honourable member for Fraser would have been provided with indulgence.
—I just make it clear that he had not been misrepresented.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for there is much we agree on in terms of horticulture and the great wine industry of this country. Indeed, I was very privileged for a period to chair the Melbourne Wholesale Fruit and Vegetable Market Trust. In that role I learnt a great deal about the Victorian horticultural industry and indeed other states' industries as they affected the wholesale supply of fruit and vegetables through the Melbourne market. I concur entirely with him on his general view that there is a long-term export future for Australian horticultural products, which I do not think many industry people fully understand. I think government has a major role to play.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the honourable gentleman, I am personally an interventionist and I believe government has a major role to play in sectoral intervention in certain industries. The government should look very carefully at how, through a whole variety of ways, it can assist the export of horticultural products.

It is not the purpose of my speech to the House today to talk about that. Rather, I want to look at the opposition's economic policies as they were outlined in Fightback, much of which has not been renounced by the opposition in this place, and as they are applied by the Kennett government in Victoria to see the net effect they have on the ordinary men, women and children of Victoria.

One can pick up a Victorian newspaper today, be it the Age or the Herald-Sun, and see a series of headlines which are quite frightening—for example, `Victoria worst hit in record long-term unemployment levels'. There is no doubt that today Victoria is the economic basket case of Australia because of the Kennett government's new right economic policies.

Why are there so many long-term unemployed? One of the reasons is that 30,000 Victorians were put out of work by the Kennett government—a figure it does not deny. Not only are there currently 30,000 people out of work, but more people will be put out of work as a direct result of the Kennett philosophy, the Liberal Party philosophy, of economics.

That is not just my view. The Victorian Minister for Finance, Mr Ian Smith, has publicly admitted that much of the unemployment in Victoria is a direct result of the polices of the Kennett government. In regional and rural Victoria, which so many members of the opposition claim to represent and to have an affinity to, the statistics are nothing short of horrible.

The impact of the Kennett government's economic view of the world is impacting more heavily on rural Victoria than on the city. In education, for example, in my own electorate 11 rural schools have now been closed. In the future a number of other schools will be forced to close, though the Kennett government will say that that is a community response and it is not closing the schools. They will close because the government has, for small one-teacher schools, fixed limits on the number of students before the school will stop receiving funding. We are talking here about very small schools; one-teacher schools, primarily.

It does not sound all that bad when one stands here and says that we can afford to close one school here and one school there, but in rural areas the loss of the school is not just the loss of the education facility. It is the loss of a teacher, the loss of the teacher's wage which will not be spent in the local area. So, the private sector feels that loss of income. It is the loss of the community meeting place. When people move to rural areas the first place of contact with the community, particularly for women with children, is the local school. All of us who have lived in country areas know this. It is an unarguable proposition. If we take away the country schools we impact on the community at large. The local school is where working bees are held, where the community comes together. If it is taken away the social structure of the community is changed immediately. Just in education alone there are now profound effects on rural Victoria.

In relation to transport and the closure of railway lines, it is very strange that on the Melbourne-Sydney line, which runs through my electorate, the trains still run but they do not stop at the stations. It is rather odd that we have people who live in towns with a station who can no longer catch the train because the train does not stop, it goes past the station. The logic of that, quite frankly, totally escapes me. One of the arguments for closing rail links and reducing the rail service was to save money. Of course, the buses are private buses contracted out by the state government. But strangely enough we now find that the state government subsidises the private bus lines for pensioners and schoolchildren. So where are the savings? A good service is removed and replaced by buses that have to be subsidised by the state government in order to get them to work. It is an economic nightmare and an economic nonsense.

For example, in the town of Euroa at the present time the train still stops, but they have closed the public toilets. It is mostly elderly people at Euroa who use the train. If they have a need to use a toilet at their local railway station, one would assume that there is toilet paper hanging on a tree outside the station—because the toilets are closed. This is the nightmare that rural people are facing as a result of the irrationality of the Kennett approach to economics.

Victoria has the highest rate of long-term unemployed in Australia. That is not an accident. What is happening in rural areas? The Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, the State Electricity Commission of Victoria, the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Australia and all of the state government departments are shedding staff in rural towns and are closing down services. Again, we face the simple economic reality: less wages in the town, fewer people in the town and fewer children in the town, placing pressure on school closures and on local shopkeepers who lose the wage spending capacity of the public servants who once lived there, and the town starts to diminish.

All the research done in Victoria—I refer to research done by the Municipal Association of Victoria—is showing a massive decline in regional Victoria. The 30,000 people who are leaving Victoria to get away from Kennett are very largely rural people. They have seen the destruction of their lifestyle and the future, and they know that they will get nothing from this government.

The headline in the Herald-Sun of Monday, 22 November 1993 was `Injured to lose benefits'. There is one thing people cannot afford to be in Victoria and that is an injured worker. We keep hearing the Liberal Party softeners saying how they care for people, workers and wage levels, but what do they care about injured workers? It is pretty simple—3,200 injured workers lost their Workcare payments in Victoria in one blow, one fell swoop. We listened to their softness and caring about wage levels, but what did they do when they got government? The reality is that 3,200 Victorian injured workers were told, `Sorry, no benefit; out you go'. This is a very caring Liberal Party indeed!

Looking at the health issues in Victoria, if we pick up the headlines in the Age 17 February 1994, what do we find? `The ambulance dispute drags on in deadly earnest'. What have the Liberals done? They have brought in a hit man, Mr Firman. All of the senior public servants in Victoria today are hit men or hit women. Their sole purpose in life is to impose budget cuts. There is no conceptual understanding of service delivery; the whole program is about budget cuts. We do not know what we are going to get at the bottom end because it is not about a social program; it is about cutting money.

The ambulance service of Victoria has now got to the stage where people are losing their lives because the ambulances are not getting there on time. Four deaths this year in Victoria are alleged to have been caused by poor ambulance service. Again, we hear members of the Liberal Party talk carefully and we listen to their softness, care and concern for ordinary Australians. If we look at the $10 billion cuts proposed in Fightback, which have not been renounced in this place, we see that Kennett is applying those same policies. What do we find?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is trying to fix up the mess your blokes have made.
—We get this wonderful interjection, `What have our blokes done?'. Let me tell you a simple fact of life—
—I didn't say that; I said he is trying to fix up the mess your blokes made.
—I am happy for the interjection.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—I am not happy with the interjection. We will not have any more interjections. The honourable member will respond through the chair, not to the interjectors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I accept your ruling. In the run-up to the last state election the Kennett government, with the support of Piers Ackerman, the editor of the Herald-Sun, who must have been a card-carrying member of the Liberal Party, convinced the Victorian public that Victoria had outrageous debt levels and that because of this massive debt problem there was only one solution: to rip into the public purse. But, if one bothers to actually have a look at debt levels as a percentage of state gross domestic product in Victoria, we find that the Labor government left a debt percentage of state gross domestic product which was half of that of Sir Henry Bolte's.

PARA.TAB: Sir Henry Bolte is seen by most Liberals in this place as one of the great Liberal leaders of Victoria. If we dared to suggest to the Liberal Party that he was a financial incompetent, it would attack us all over the place and say that he was the great white knight of Victorian liberalism. Under his regime, Victoria had twice the debt level as a percentage of state gross domestic product that the Labor government left. This is the nonsense that we get in economic debate in Victoria. Jeffrey Kennett, to his credit politically, has managed to convince people that this is the major problem. It is not, but because of that the Liberal government is getting away with these massive cuts.

I do not disagree that there is a role for case-mix funding in hospitals, but case-mix funding can be carried out in a number of ways. Case-mix funding can recognise in its funding program and levels that smaller hospitals require contributions from the public purse to pick up those non-profit areas that occur in rural hospitals. The Minister for Health Services in Victoria, Marie Tehan, who happens to occupy a seat within my federal boundaries, has cut something like $480 million from the state health budget. According to Dr Robyn Mason of the Australian Medical Association, research done by the association shows that over 50 rural hospitals will close in Victoria.

One can argue that there should be some rationalisation of health care, and one can find good arguments for why we should look at the way in which we deliver health in economic terms, but rather than sit back and say `How can we achieve a health result and save money at the same time?' this government cuts and then tries to work out what will be left at the bottom. For example, Heathcote, in the shire of McIvor on the northern highway, has a small hospital with 10 acute beds. It will be closed within 12 months under the current system. What will happen to trauma patients? Is there any proposal to put forward a system of trauma patients being stabilised within the town before being transferred to a regional hospital? No, none at all. The hospital will close. Someone will then have to work out what to do with trauma patients. The northern highway is the major link between Echuca and Melbourne. It carries large numbers of tourist traffic and large numbers of traumas occur on that road.

Honourable members may be interested to know that there are no longer any obstetric services in Heathcote. A pregnant woman has to go to Bendigo for all obstetric services—the caring Liberal approach to health that we hear so much of. Again, when the policy is applied we find that the town will not deliver the very basic medical requirement of most people—obstetrics. It is no longer there.

Seymour has a hospital and this year it is estimated to run at a loss of $120,000 under its method of case-mix funding. It cannot continue to run at a $120,000 loss. Another hospital will close. But what happens to the town? If a hospital closes, we lose nurses. Nurses are paid wages. The wages are spent in the local community. Again, the town loses wages. Nurses are parents; they have children. So the school loses children. The infrastructure of another rural town gets ripped apart and the town diminishes in size and with that the flow out from regional Victoria.

Hospitals are important; they employ people. Quite apart from providing necessary medical services for rural people, they are important in terms of income to the town. So teachers will be going; nurses will be going. In the same area five community nurses have been given their tickets and told, `We don't want community nurses'. There will be no more community in Seymour and Broadford. Soft, caring Liberal Party philosophy! Jeffrey Kennett is applying Fightback's policy of cutting $10 billion and the end result is unemployment, a drop in services and the devastation of rural Victoria. That is the policy.

It is all very well to talk about cutting income tax, imposing a 15 per cent GST—and industrial relations. Let us look at the Victorian industrial relations system. What a ripper! It does not work. There is no industrial relations system in Victoria. The legislation of two-bottle Gude—he is known as two-bottle Gude, as the House probably knows, because he said publicly that he drew up the Victorian government's legislation on industrial relations over a weekend with two bottles of scotch—is a joke. It does not work.

Most state members of parliament of the conservative right wing persuasion—I hesitate to call them liberals these days—will tell us quite bluntly, `We've got to do something about it'. We read in the papers that Mr Gude is probably going back up to his mountain retreat. He might take four bottles of scotch this time to help him get the system to work again. Maybe four bottles will produce something better than will two. We might then get some kind of industrial relations system going in Victoria which will at least give both employers and employees some degree of hope.

There has been another attack on the family. The Herald-Sun of Thursday, 17 February 1994 ran a story with the headline, `200% kinder fee increase'. We have another example of the soft, caring, concerned attitude towards families—families with children, families on wages. I heard the honourable member for Wakefield say that the coalition supports unlimited wages, yet I am not quite sure whether it was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who once said that there should be a $3 youth wage. I might have missed that somewhere along the line. I accept that we want unlimited wages, yet we find that fees of some Victorian kindergartens have risen by up to 229 per cent. It is worth while reflecting on that. These are the people we hear our conservative opponents say they are concerned about, care about and want to do something for. Those policies are put in place in Victoria and there is a 229 per cent increase in kindergarten fees.

The Age of 3 December carried a report from the OECD in relation to classroom sizes. What do we find in Victoria? The Kennett government's education cuts have increased the number of pupils to each teacher, bringing the Victoria ratio closer to the national average. But, in reality, according to the Age, we now have the highest classroom levels in the OECD. We are the clever country which says, `We understand that we need to produce education results for our children so that when they leave and come into the work force they will be cleverer and better educated'. Victoria says, `We can do that with the highest ratio of teacher to pupil in the OECD'. It is very simple. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills are for parliament to approve the expenditure of the government. We would expect from the government a good listing of exactly what is being spent. Today I want to address the absolutely appalling standard of the financial reporting from the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the program performance statements for 1993, which came out several days after the actual budget papers, and to the budget papers, which give just the large appropriations.

PARA.TAB: When we look at division 270-3 in budget paper No. 2, we see allocation for the environment program of $37 million for 1993-94. That is an overall number and is obviously not much use to anybody looking at that program to see where the expenditure is being made, what the money is going on and whether the Australian taxpayer is getting value for money. That is why we have the program performance statements.

This year I waited eagerly for the PPSs to come out so that I could see how the department of the environment was spending taxpayers' money—on what programs and whether these programs were worth while. The department of the environment divides its programs into nine subprograms. I will ignore subprogram 1.1 because it is just a policy program and has expenditure of less than $1 million. Subprogram 1.2 is climate change and environmental liaison. If we turn to that in the program performance statements, we find that there is an allocation for running costs of just over $1 million and for administrative expenses of $190,000. So far, so good.

What we really want to know beyond that is where the money actually goes in environment programs. We find an amount of $9,660,000 allotted to the environment program. That tells us a lot. Where does the money go? How much goes to which programs? What programs are included in this allocation? There is no information in this section at all to tell the taxpayers how their $9 1/2 million has been spent except that, quite interestingly, in an environment portfolio it has gone on an environment program. We would not be surprised about that. So much for subprogram 1.2.

Perhaps subprogram 1.3 on environmental planning is a bit better. Again we find an amount for running costs—salaries and administration—and the bulk of the money going to an environment program. There are no details. Of course, there is a reference to division 270-3, back in budget paper No. 2, which, as I pointed out before, is just a global allocation. Under `environmental program' we have absolutely no idea where the expenditure will be, to what programs it will be made or anything else.

Let us look at subprogram 1.4, conservation. Again, we have salaries, administration and something called, funnily enough, an environment program, which has an allocation of $5 1/2 million. But we look down and find no information at all. What programs come under the environment program? There is no indication. There is no indication of how much goes to what programs, what programs are included in it and how much the allocations are. There is some text which refers generally to strategies without actually mentioning any of these programs' allocations—whether they get a large or a small portion of that $5 1/2 million.

Subprogram 1.5 is natural resources management and again we have an environment program allocation of $3 million. We look at ANCA, which for those who do not know the portfolio is the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, at subprogram 1.9. Here we have quite a large expenditure of $42 million in, would you believe, a program. There are no details about what program and nothing about how that $42 million would actually be expended. There is also no indication as to where we might find the information, not even a reference to the original budget papers—simply an appropriation for the program of ANCA of $42 million.

Trying to get these figures to add up and match the actual budget paper becomes quite a mystery tour. If we look at Budget Paper No. 2, we find that the actual figures given there for the environment program do not add up. Budget Paper No. 2 states that ANCA gets $62 million in appropriations. However, the PPS states that it is not $62 million but $67 million. There is no explanation as to why the two are not reconciled.
