Under that subprogram there is capital works expenditure. The PPS refers us to section 848-2 of Budget Paper No. 2. The program performance statement gives a fairly clear capital works expenditure of $7,190,000. However, when we actually go to where it should be reconciled with the budget papers, we find that the Australian Nature Conservation Agency allocation for capital expenditure is actually $5 million with, again, no explanation as to why that $5 million does not line up with the $7 million in the PPS.

These might seem rather esoteric figures and dry financial statements, but this goes to the heart of parliamentary accountability. If we cannot look at the financial statements given by the government to see how the parliament is approving money to be spent, what is the point of accountability? There is no accountability. I know that the sports program, which is administered by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, has had a lot of questions on its administration. I would suggest that this goes through the whole department.

Getting back to this discrepancy between the $7 million and the $5 million for capital expenditure, I have no question that this is a legitimate expenditure, but I question the way it has been reported. I understand from the department that the discrepancy is because certain moneys come in as income for the department and that is then expended, but they are not reflected in the appropriations because that does not come out of appropriations. That is one of the most sloppy pieces of reporting that I have yet to see. No business that I know of could possibly get away with this type of non-accounting.

I thought I would check with another department and see whether this was common to all departments. Another department in which I have a particular interest is the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I did not check through all the program performance statements, I just opened the performance statements of this department to see what that department gives. It gives the staffing and the administration. Then we have subprogram 1.2: Crops. On page 37 we have running costs for the Australian Horticultural Corporation of $2 1/2 million. It then says, `Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee—Allocation of tobacco charges under the Tobacco Marketing Act'—a very specific allocation of money for a very specific purpose. Anybody looking at the program performance statements can follow quite clearly where that money was going and why parliament was appropriating it to be spent by that department. Internal organisations contributions amount to $55,900; the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation is then listed. They are well set out so that the parliament and the people of Australia know where the money is being expended.

In subprogram 1.5, under the heading `Appropriation Bill (No. 2)' there is a payment to the Northern Territory and a payment to New South Wales. Under the heading `Appropriation Bill (No. 1)', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth defence of common law action arising from atomic test.

That is a specific entry which allows people to see where the money—$846,000—is being spent, which is a bit different from the $34,000-odd spent by ANCA or one of the other programs. ANCA might have another book that it puts out, but at the moment I am just referring to what is available in the program performance statements. There are other sections of the environment portfolio that have no other annual report. Allocations are given for the management of former atomic test sites. There are also international organisations contributions and allocations to the Joint Coal Board.

PARA.TAB: Although that is not a sampling of all books, I did have a look through other program performance statements and it seems that they did give a clear listing of what was spent. It is only when we come to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories that we have this total non-accounting for money. This is not good enough. It is the sloppiest kind of reporting that we could imagine. I cannot imagine a sandwich shop turning in such incredibly poor lists. What would they say: appropriations on food, $500,000, and that is it? Even that would be better than we get in the program performance statements where we find that an amount of $9,660,000 has been allocated for the environment program under subprogram 1.2: Climate change and environmental liaison. What does that tell us is being done and spent on climate change? There are nice things that the department is looking at. The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: .Resources assigned and action commenced to develop a National Greenhouse Gas Inventory.
But it is not listed there. It continues:
.Climate change impacts were factored into national strategies on forestry—
How much did that cost? It further states:
.Support was provided for climate change impacts research on:
—assessment of vulnerability to sea level rise;

How much did it get—$100, $200, $2,000 or $2 million? There is no indication in these books at all. As I said, no business could get away with this. If it did, there would be severe questions by the shareholders, the Taxation Office and everybody else. Yet this government, with appropriations of $60 million-odd—depending on whether one reads this book or that book; they vary—can get away with just lumping everything into the environment program. If honourable members look it up and add it all up, they will be able to get an allocation for salaries and administration. Then there is an enormous lump sum. The summary table lists the programs from one to nine. What sort of accountability is that?

PARA.TAB: I call on the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to address her department as a matter of urgency before the May 1994-95 budget so that we can see how that department spends its money. It should not go in for this totally inadequate, totally sloppy administration of its funds. We should introduce some accountability into the portfolio. If accountability becomes a part of the Department for the Environment, Sport and Territories, perhaps we will not have such sloppy accounting procedures in future and we might avoid such obvious disasters as the sports rorts affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the appropriation bills before the chamber. They deal with a range of financial appropriations for the purposes of the budget. In speaking to the House today on these appropriation bills it is opportune to have a look at the general state of the economy and where our budget and other strategies have placed the nation. There can be no doubt that the Australian economy is now in a position which is the best it has been in for some 30 years. The economic performance in the nation has been widely acclaimed by commentators within Australia and abroad. At the outset, I would like to mention some of the independent assessments that have recently been made. The Westpac Bank's most recent publication, Market Insights, deals with assessments of the Australian economy and other key trading partners. In its January-February document, when commenting on Australia, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: The economy enters 1994 in its best shape in years. The business cycle has turned up. Exports continue to do well. Sustainable growth is expected over the next three years.
Inflationary pressures will remain low and interest rates will not rise until 1995.

I was particularly bemused at that last comment because I recall the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) a few days ago asking what was the silliest question any of us can recall being asked in this place, seeking an undertaking about interest rates and what level they might be at for the rest of the year. Having acknowledged the stupidity of that question, though, I thought it interesting that the Westpac publication, which was produced only a few weeks ago, made its assessment stating that it believed interest rates would remain low and not rise before 1995.

PARA.TAB: The Westpac publication also includes some estimates of how it sees the economy going into the future. Its latest assessment of the growth of the Australian economy estimates that real GDP is now growing at 3.4 per cent in Australia. That is a level which is not matched by any other OECD country. Every nation in Europe would love to have a figure like that and would love to have economic growth travelling along at nearly 3 1/2 per cent; most of them would love to have it travelling at three per cent. The fact of life is that we are one of the few countries in the world and the only country in the OECD currently recording economic growth at those levels.

The other countries in the OECD table which are performing comparatively well—New Zealand and the United States—still have a growth rate well below that of Australia. On latest figures, Westpac's estimate for New Zealand's rate of real GDP growth is 2.9 per cent and for the United States it is 2.8 per cent. Our major trading partner, Japan, is estimated to have a growth rate of 0.5 per cent. In that lies one of the difficulties we have in maintaining our exports to Japan, which is presently going through a period of severe economic difficulties.

If we look further into the future, we see that the Westpac assessments for 1994 and 1995 provide an even more glowing endorsement of this government's economic strategies. Its forecast for 1994 is an economic growth rate in Australia of 3.5 per cent. That figure has been revised up by the Westpac bank. In 1994 New Zealand's rate of growth is expected to be three per cent and for the United States it is expected to be 3.2 per cent. The story gets better; Westpac's assessment for 1995 is that not only will the Australian economy continue to grow but it should increase its growth to record a four per cent growth rate in 1995. New Zealand's rate of growth is expected to decline to 2.7 per cent, with the United States growth rate remaining steady at 3.2 per cent. Pleasingly, Westpac estimates that the Japanese economy will experience significant growth in 1995, recording a growth rate of about two per cent.

The very clear picture we get from that is that Westpac's assessment of the Australian economy is not just that we are doing well but that we are doing better than any other comparable economy. As Westpac commented in its summary:

SPEECH.PARA: Recovery is firmly established in the US, Australia and New Zealand. But Europe and Japan will endure another tough year in 1994.
Business and consumer confidence in Australia has improved markedly and the leading economic indicators are also clearly positive.
Specifically in relation to Australia, Westpac said:
The economy finished 1993 on a high note: solid employment gains have discarded the "jobless recovery" tag, while retailers enjoyed good Christmas sales.
Better economic data has quashed any chance of lower short term interest rates in 1994 and has supported a recovery of the AUD—
the Australian dollar—
from its 1993 lows. The GATT agreement is good news for exporters.

The Westpac assessment is unequivocally supportive of the outcomes that this government and its economic strategies—primarily through the budget but also through other instruments of government policy—have been able to deliver for the nation.

PARA.TAB: It is not just the Westpac assessment that has come out in the last few weeks that we can be proud of. The Business Council of Australia is not an organisation which often commends the government for its economic and industrial strategies. However, when the Business Council conducts its surveys, even it has to live with the outcome. Members of the opposition often quote the Business Council of Australia in this place. But they have been particularly silent about the Business Council's most recent survey of its members' views of how the economy is travelling. The Business Council Bulletin of December last year reported on the council's seventh survey of business conditions. The overview of results was:
For the six months to 31 March 1994, respondents expect:

SPEECH.PARA: .growth in sales volumes and values;
.growth in exports, but stronger growth in imports;
.growth in capital expenditure, at a faster rate than in the April 1993 survey;
.an improved outlook for employment;
.low inflation.

That demonstrates the confidence amongst the members of the Business Council of Australia in the underlying strength of our economy. The Business Council then divided up the responses, looking at the manufacturing sector and the non-manufacturing sector. In relation to the manufacturing sector, the Business Council stated:
The outlook for the total sales volume of manufacturers is for a continuation of positive growth . . .
In relation to the non-manufacturing sector it commented:
The outlook . . . remains positive. Ten out of 11 respondents expect growth in real terms in the coming six months.

The Business Council went on to make the observation that the expectations in its previous survey in April 1993 were actually surpassed by the performance in the economy. Mr Ian Salmon, the chairman of the economic and financial panel of the Business Council said:

PARA.TAB: Results of the . . . Survey . . . show a strengthening of the economic recovery. Sales volumes are expected, on average, to grow by 7% per annum in the half-year to 31 March 1994 . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is an amazingly good performance. Importantly, the number of survey respondents expecting to increase investment expenditure jumped from 55 per cent to 72 per cent. So 72 per cent of the membership of the Business Council of Australia say that they intend to increase their investment in the six months ahead. The Business Council, Westpac and a range of other commentators say that economic growth is not only doing well but doing better than it was last year and it is doing better than growth is in any comparable country. All these matters are in the public domain. Indeed, the Business Council of Australia is in regular contact with members of the opposition, particularly the opposition frontbench. But we have not heard a peep out of them on any of these matters because it does not suit their current purpose.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, the most recent National Australia Bank quarterly business survey reinforces the position of both Westpac and the BCA surveys. The report of the NAB survey for the December quarter for 1993 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As foreshadowed by the previous survey, results of the latest . . . Business Survey indicate that . . . conditions improved markedly during the December quarter 1993. Indeed, employment growth exceeded expectations for the December quarter and there was a sizeable increase in capacity utilisation.
That is a particularly important issue. There is no issue more significant to me, to my electorate of Brisbane, or to the government than the increase in employment.

PARA.TAB: It was a source of great pleasure and pride to members on this side of the House that earlier this year the Treasurer (Mr Willis) was able to announce in the parliament a revision of Treasury estimates of our economic growth. Less than a year ago, we estimated our economy would be growing at a rate of about 2 3/4 per cent. As I just mentioned, we know that it is growing faster than that, and Treasury has revised the estimate up to 3 1/2 per cent. But, very pleasingly, we have also seen an increase in job growth beyond the forecast contained in last year's August budget. In this financial year an additional 100,000 new jobs will be created over and above the budget estimate. The budget estimated the creation of an additional 100,000 jobs. That figure has been doubled. That is a very substantial outcome and is directly attributable to the increased economic activity and the growth which the government has been able to engender through its industry policy, through its budget strategy and through its industrial relations policies. The

SPEECH.PARA: National Australia Bank commented on the Labor market circumstances and also noted:
During the December quarter firms in all states reported an increase in employment except Tasmania where it remained unchanged. The largest increases were recorded in Queensland.

I am very pleased to record in this House that a Queensland state Labor government has not only very properly and effectively administered an economy for the benefit of the business community but also ensured that the proceeds from the wealth that is created in Queensland are more equitably distributed. As a member from that state with a Labor government, I am delighted to be able to record that sort of performance for Queensland, which is leading the nation in employment growth.

PARA.TAB: There are a couple of other areas that are important in this mix of policies that has seen Australia's economic growth reach the top of the ladder. It is no accident that in the United States the Bill Clinton administration is now looking at Australia to study our industrial relations system; nor is it any accident that last year representatives from the United States administration were seeking advice from Australia about our health care system and about Medicare.

The issues of industrial relations and health care were central in the election 12 months ago. The policies that those opposite put to the people of Australia in the areas of industrial relations and health, which were so resoundingly rejected—and rightly so—have now been discarded by governments in most parts of the world. It is only the hard-nosed right-wing ideologues scattered around some parts of Europe—but appearing in a bit more abundance in this place—who want to stick to that hard ideological position on industrial relations and health care.

The United States Clinton administration now looks at us as one of the two or three nations in the world from which it believes it can learn some things in those important policy areas. This is against a background of the Australian taxpayer now paying the lowest percentage of income of any citizen in any nation in the OECD. The OECD's figures released at the end of last year show that, in Australia, as a percentage of GDP, all government taxation combined is now the lowest of any nation in the OECD.

So this economic performance and the social equity that has come through industrial relations, Medicare and other activities have been achieved through efficiencies and restructuring. They have also allowed us to achieve a position in which we are now the lowest taxed nation in the OECD. What have we seen on the opposition benches while all this has been occurring? There has been a fair bit of disarray on the opposition benches for the last 12 months, but that has certainly been heightened in recent weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the last few years.

—As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence points out, this has been the case for the last few years. In that time there has been a bit of a merry-go-round. We have the revolving door of the leadership challenge. The question is not whether or when they will have a leadership challenge; it is how many people will fit into the revolving door.

PARA.TAB: It is not that long ago that there were only two people in the revolving door. Obviously it has been redesigned, because now there is a list as long as my arm. It is not just the old Howard and Hewson and Peacock show any more. Indeed, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) is touted as a potential leader. We also have Senator Bishop, whom we expect to have in this place—if there is room on that ever-expanding front bench to physically locate another human being. There is also the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). The list goes on. Watching Four Corners these days becomes an entertaining exercise as we see opposition backbenchers trot out their latest theory on who should lead them. Not too many tell us that the current Leader of the Opposition should continue to lead them.

So whilst the government has been about establishing an economic record which is the envy of the OECD world, the opposition has been very deeply involved in internal navel contemplation. If there was any doubt about the prospects for the Leader of the Opposition's longevity in that job, I think the preselections in Warringah put paid to it. I think the person who missed out most when Mr Abbott was selected for the Liberal Party was not the person he defeated but the current Leader of the Opposition.

What has been the response of the Leader of the Opposition and his team to all this? The first thing they did was to try to enlarge the front bench. This is the growth industry of the opposition in this place. Those opposite have enlarged the front bench to the point where there is literally no more room to sit anybody. I think the observations of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), a National Party member, on that issue are as useful as any. The honourable member for Cowper wrote to his leader about the problem of having 37 chiefs and not many Indians left. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a Shadow Ministry of 37 . . . verges on the absurd and taints us as well as the Liberals.

He said that, as one of the few Indians left in the opposition, he felt that the Nationals were under-represented in the shadow cabinet. It may well be the growth industry, and it may well be a tactic to try to extend the life of the Leader of the Opposition in his current position, but it ignores the main game. So too does the other tactic of those opposite. Apart from worrying about their backs, their other tactic in last few months has been to turn attention to the bit shows, the sideshows, rather than to the main game. Sports grants and the minutiae of them are not big national issues. They are not part of the big picture. They are not about job creation. They are not about equity in the distribution of wealth. They are not about ensuring the rights of people. They are a useful diversion for the political leadership in the opposition, which is severely embattled at present.

PARA.TAB: I want to mention a couple of very specific issues in relation to the operation of government industry and budgetary policy. In my view the export market development grants scheme has been very successful and has ensured that a lot of Australian firms have gained access to export markets which would not have been possible without the assistance of the scheme.

I am concerned that the tourism industry is still outside the mainstream umbrella of the EMDG scheme. I take this opportunity to urge the government to review the EMDG scheme as quickly as possible and to ensure tourism's access to it. Tourism, of course, is now the largest single export earner for our nation. It is a key industry—not just for states such as Queensland but for the nation as a whole—and we should be doing all we can to support it. The government deserves to be commended for its economic management. There is no doubt that the economy is now in strong growth and in the best circumstances that it has been for many decades. The Treasurer and his predecessors in the Hawke-Keating governments can be well proud of their efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the speeches of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis). The honourable member for Werriwa is typical of the new wave ideologues coming out of the Labor Party. His speech was a very articulate exposition of the principles of the Labor Party in Australia today. The honourable member for Brisbane is a very articulate and intelligent member of parliament. He is more pragmatic and realistic, and he is a bit more grown up and mature than the honourable member for Werriwa.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the comments of the honourable member for Werriwa first. Constantly throughout his speech we heard the aspirations of the economic rationalists. Once again we heard a defence and statement of those principles of economic rationalism. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . accelerate the pace of micro-reform and competition policy throughout the national economy . . . the great competitive weakness of regional Australia, that is, inadequate transport . . . road, rail, sea and air.

This indicates just how naive some of these people are. He is defending a government by stating these factors. It was this government that almost doubled the price of fuel. The most expensive transport component is the cost of fuel, and this government has almost doubled the price of it; first, because it has no antitrust laws and, second, because it has dynamically and dramatically increased the amount of taxation levied upon fuel in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turn it down.

—Well, the sound can be turned down because I will speak at the level that I want to speak at. The government has hugely increased the cost of transportation. It is interesting that a member from Sydney will talk about transportation costs. I represent an area in which, on average, the 10 major towns—all with over 5,000 people—are nearly 300 or 400 kilometres apart. So if it is a problem for the honourable member for Werriwa, I will leave it to the imagination of the House as to what sort of problem it is for a person representing an electorate with a bigger population—last time I checked, anyway—and with all of the population centres an average of 200 or 300 kilometres apart. Imagine the cost of transportation for us, and it has been doubled by the actions and the policies implemented by this government.

PARA.TAB: There has only been one huge cut in government allocations for transport in the last three budgets. It has shaken and rattled people's teeth. The government has cut the funding for roads clean in half. I agree with the honourable member for Werriwa that there needs to be a system of high-speed spoke roads coming out from our cities; I do not deny that for a moment. But his government has not increased the amount of money provided for that purpose. In fact, it has cut it clean in half.

The great exponents of economic rationalism talk about competition. When speaking recently in this place on the subject, people interjected, `Let's have the days of John McEwen back again, haw, haw, haw'. They made a number of disparaging comments about John McEwen and his policies. It is unfortunate for them that people write history books and Australian year books. Such people list the figures that will indicate to future generations how successful a policy has been.

Let us look at the so-called bad old days of John McEwen. When John McEwen left this House, unemployment in this nation for the last half of 1971 was 1.6 per cent. It is now 10.7 per cent. Bankruptcies were running at 2,428 in 1971. This last year ended, they ran at 14,718.

We always say the words `current account deficit' as though they formed a single term. In 1971, there was a current account surplus of $691 million. This year, there is a current account deficit of $15,473 million. The budget in 1971 was a meagre and minuscule $8,000 million. The budget now is $115,000 million. It was a balanced budget then; it is now an unbalanced budget to the tune of $15,000 million.

In those days, $US1.40 would buy $A1, and Y376 was needed to purchase $A1. Only Y70 is now needed to purchase $A1, and only US70c is needed to purchase $A1. That provides some idea of the relativities and how Australia has fallen so dramatically behind the other countries of the world. Finally, in those days, we were the third richest nation on earth.

This is the judgment upon the McEwen era. There was 1.6 per cent unemployment then versus 10.7 per cent now. Bankruptcies then were approximately 2,500; now they are approximately 15,000. In those days, there was a balance of payments surplus, while now there is a balance of payments deficit of $15,000 million per year. There were then budget outlays of a meagre $8,000 million per year, while now they are $115,000 million per year. At that time, $US1.40 was needed to buy $1. It is now half that figure. The change has been far more dramatic in terms of the yen: the amount of money needed to buy $1 has dropped from Y376 to Y70.

I can say with great pride that I am a very strong supporter of the McEwen era. McEwen had the right approach in what he attempted to do. History proves conclusively that he was absolutely correct. It also proves that the recent implementation by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, of his policies of economic rationalism and deregulation, et cetera has been absolutely disastrous for the Australian nation.

A previous speaker said that the Australian economy was running marvellously. He spoke of the captains of industry in Australia. I have a certain amount of contempt for the spokesman for the captains of industry of Australia. Once upon a time when I used to buy the Bulletin I saw in it photographs of Mr Bond, Mr Elliott, Mr Skase and Mr Holmes a Court. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who is at the table at the moment, said, `There they are again on the front of the Bulletin'.

A recent Bulletin article referred to all the same people. All those who had been lauded on the front cover of that magazine appeared again. This article said that those people raised $22,000 million from the public of Australia—principally the banks of Australia—and that it has now all gone; it has vanished off the face of the earth. These men have been responsible for creaming and thieving $22,000 million from the Australian public. Please excuse me for not taking much notice of these people—they have been on the front pages of all the media throughout Australia and on television—who constantly told us how wonderful things were in the early 1980s. The early 1980s was a boom period; it was a time when we had the greatest Treasurer on earth.

Those opposite say that things are going well in the nation. They are not going well for the one million people who are out of work. There are 2.5 million, arguably three million, Australians living in families where there is no wage earner. That is a fair proportion of the Australian nation.

Worse still is the fate, the year after next, of 70,000 Australian families who will have become technically bankrupt. I do not know of anyone who has gone bankrupt. I cannot name a single person I know who has gone bankrupt. However, I do know hundreds upon hundreds of people who have gone completely broke. There is not a great necessity to claim technical bankruptcy; very few people walk down that pathway. For every person who becomes bankrupt, at least 10 would have gone completely and utterly broke. Seven hundred thousand broke may be over three million Australians in families that have gone broke.

Going broke is not like losing a job; one still receives much the same income. Those who go broke carry debt with them. If their business goes belly up, their creditors are still baying at their heels for perhaps $100,000. They have to pay back that $100,000 for the rest of their lives. Many of these people are honourable and hard working. It is part of the principles by which they live that they will pay back that money. So for the rest of their days they will live in an environment where it will be very difficult to find enough money to feed themselves and their kids. That is literally happening.

I can give names of people I know personally who are in those sorts of straits. They are very honourable people, in sharp contrast to the charlatans who seem to be constantly lauded by our media and constantly quoted in this place as though they were great geniuses. They have been terribly intelligent in taking money from people. To me, the only difference is that they did not use a gun.

Labor is the party that is supposed to represent the working class and the employees of Australia. It has been in office over 10 years. It is rather interesting that Gough Whitlam doubled average weekly earnings throughout Australia; he doubled the wage structure. Everyone said, `Isn't he a wonderful man?'. During the same time, he also doubled the consumer price index. In fact, at the end of that three-year, arguably four-year, period people ended up in exactly the same position as when they started. There had been no growth in real incomes. Interestingly, in the four or five years prior to that there had been nearly a 30 per cent growth in real incomes. The CPI was restrained and average weekly earnings went up very dramatically.

The most fascinating phenomenon is that, for all those who vote for the Labor Party and enjoy average weekly earnings—wages or incomes, if you like—in Australia, under the government that is in office now, the CPI has risen 62.9 per cent and average weekly earnings have risen 49.4 per cent. So the average Australian is 13.5 per cent worse off.

If we take into account the dramatic drop in the Australian dollar, from 95c to 70c as against the yen, the average Australian's purchasing power is eroded by another six per cent. Taxation has more than doubled under this government over a period of eight or nine years. It has risen from $41,000 million to $96,000 million and most of it has been through indirect taxation increases. Those increases take another 11 per cent off the average weekly earnings of Australians.

The great argument that members of the government used against us before the last election, in an exercise in arch hypocrisy, was that the GST was going to make the average Australian poorer, and yet they are the people that instituted and dramatically increased indirect taxation on every single Australian. In fact, if my memory serves me correctly—and I am flying by memory here—the government has almost doubled indirect taxation in Australia in its period in office. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you I am not flying by memory on all my other figures; they are all very tightly nailed down. As I have said, that carves another 11 per cent off the average weekly earnings of Australians.

If we add those three components together—the dramatic increase in taxation, the loss in the value of the Australian dollar, and the average weekly earnings versus CPI figure—we have a loss of income of over 30 per cent. People want to know why they cannot afford to buy a new car. People want to know why they cannot afford to keep up their house repayments. The reason is that their real incomes have dropped dramatically, by over 30 per cent—30.5 per cent, to be specific.

The honourable member for Brisbane told us about the great new world—the socialist paradise—that we are moving into. The remarks of the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Brotherhood of St Laurence are most pertinent. In the same week they both made the same comment, which was a bit redundant although it was very prescient and very pertinent:

SPEECH.PARA: About 40 per cent of the Australian nation is tossing the coin to decide where they are going to dine tonight; the other 60 per cent is deciding whether they can dine at all tonight.
No longer do they have the sort of money that will enable them to have a house, a car, and a decent meal on their table of an evening.

PARA.TAB: It is said that we are walking into a great future. Let me just bring some realities into this House. We are opening up the Australian economy to totally free trade. We heard all that from the new honourable member for Werriwa. That means that anyone who produces goods outside Australia can bring those goods into Australia. If we are not internationally competitive then, of course, we will see our industries vanish—and at the present moment they are vanishing at a great rate of knots.

To be specific, the only industries in which Australia can compete are the agricultural industries and the mining industries. Outside of those two industries there will not be a job in producing anything in Australia because we are not cost competitive. I say that with such vehemence and passion because last year, out of $61,000 million worth of commodities exported from Australia, only $4 1/2 thousand million worth came from the manufacturing sector, and probably a third of that was as a result of the round robin subsidy on motor vehicles which will not exist over the next two years. So the real figure is about $3,000 million. As the Australian economy is opened up to competition, through GATT, the internationalists and the globalists—the international commodities brokers, if you like—having their way, that competition will come in and will cut down every single industry in Australia, every single producer in Australia with the exception of those in the agricultural and mining sectors.

It gives me no joy to tell this House that the agricultural sector is in desperate trouble. Our major input item, if you like, is interest rates. Our interest rates are 50 per cent higher than those in the United States; they are 9.5 per cent in Australia and 6.5 per cent in the United States, who is our biggest competitor in the field of agriculture. Our fuel price is 42c a litre even with the tax taken off, but it is 25c in the United States. Fertilisers—urea, or nitrogenous fertilisers, being the most important—cost $203 per tonne in the United States and $396 in Australia. Water charges are $3.90 a megalitre in California and $30 in Queensland. The honourable member for Brisbane praised the Queensland government, but that is how competitive the Queensland government has made Queensland, with water charges at $30 a megalitre. We pay $10 an hour for labour. I am not critical of my nation; I am proud that we pay the highest labour costs anywhere in the world. In the United States, California specifically, the labour cost is $4 an hour—and it is the biggest agricultural producing state in the United States.

How can we be competitive in the field of agriculture? We are not competitive because our farmers are working below the cost of production. A recent survey shows that 74 per cent of the graziers in western Queensland were not paying their way; they were drawing on savings or they were getting money from jobs in the town et cetera. So those farmers are subsidising their product. They personally are working at a loss. They are non-competitive now, and it is only a matter of time before the door is closed and production ceases.

What future is there for agriculture in Australia when we are nearly 100 per cent more expensive in fuel, nearly 100 per cent more expensive in fertiliser, 50 per cent more expensive in interest rates, nearly 1,000 per cent higher in water charges and 100 per cent higher in labour costs. Interest rates are set by the federal government, water charges are set by the state government, labour charges are set by the government as well. The government is responsible for all of those things. As I say, labour is a good thing, it is not a bad thing—I am talking about the cost of labour, not the Labor Party, which is a dreadful thing. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the appropriation bills before the House I would like to direct my comments to a matter which is relevant to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, in particular the question of East Timor. Honourable members will be aware of reports that appeared in last week's media concerning allegations of a second massacre in East Timor, one which immediately followed the much publicised initial bloodshed on November 12, 1991. The allegations appeared in most of the major press and are attributed to Max Stahl, a British photojournalist who was responsible for footage of the Santa Cruz cemetery massacre. This footage was smuggled out of East Timor and caused both national and international distress at the time of its release.

PARA.TAB: This original footage, shown on the Four Corners program in February 1992, presented us with the horrible images of Indonesian armed forces firing unprovoked and indiscriminately into a crowd of unarmed East Timorese. The footage also displayed the soldiers beating members of the crowd after the firing had ceased, and a man who was stabbed five times and died shortly afterwards.

We all remember what happened on that day in 1991. We may also remember that, initially, the Indonesian military put the death toll at 19 people. Later, the government increased the figure to 50 people killed in the graveyard at Santa Cruz—that is, 50 people that the Indonesian government is prepared to admit to in this incident alone. Of course, as honourable members are aware, this figure is not accepted by most international agencies and certainly is not accepted by the East Timorese. It is clear to all that the number murdered that day is much higher.

In 1993 the United Nations Commission on Human Rights voted to condemn Indonesia as that country had never satisfactorily explained what happened to 207 demonstrators missing since November 12, 1991. The Indonesian military carried out what it described as an extensive investigation into 66 people reported missing since the day of the massacre. It found two. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) said in the Australian on Monday of this week:

SPEECH.PARA: There's still obviously some uncertainties about what actually happened and how many people are still missing and how many of those are dead.

The allegations of a second massacre are not new. Not unexpectedly, their denial is not new, either. Firstly, though, I would like to look at the allegations that have been raised in the new film and demonstrate that they are in fact consistent with many other reports which came from Dili directly after the massacre. Late last year Mr Stahl sneaked back into East Timor and filmed interviews with eyewitnesses to the second massacre. The interviews form part of a documentary which was presented on British television yesterday and which I hope will soon be shown on Australian television. It is my intention to try to gain a copy of this film and show it here in the federal parliament as soon as I can.

PARA.TAB: The two eyewitnesses in that documentary claim that, following the carnage at the cemetery, scores of bodies were piled into trucks and taken to a nearby military hospital. One of the eyewitnesses reportedly survived the firing by hiding behind a tree. However, after the shooting the soldiers advanced, telling survivors to stand up, upon which they were stabbed. The East Timorese eyewitness was discovered by the armed forces and they beat him with rifle butts until they thought he was dead. Taken to the military hospital, the man, pretending to be dead, saw other survivors stabbed, or fed with poison. Others he said, `were badly wounded and lay there screaming; he'—the Indonesian soldier—`threw a rock on their heads, just once, and, if they survived, he threw it again at their chest. It made a loud noise. It sounded like coconuts as they fall from a tree to the ground'. He believed that in total 10 trucks carrying bodies were taken to the hospital.

Another eyewitness was a laboratory assistant on duty at the military hospital when the trucks arrived. He said that there were Indonesian soldiers surrounding the hospital when the trucks started to arrive so that no-one could get in or out. He said that the wounded were just thrown on the ground and some of them were run over by the trucks in which they arrived. He says in the documentary that the troops asked him if the hospital had any poison which would kill people quickly. He did not, so they were given some tablets that would kill people slowly. These were used on many of the people.

We will have to wait until the documentary is broadcast in this country before we know the full extent of the allegations, but there can be no doubt that they will be gruesome and that we will be appalled and that we will express our unmitigated outrage, as we always do. But the question is: will we do anything? The Indonesian government was very quick to deny the second round of allegations. It has done this, as far as I know, without raising a finger to at least check their validity. I very much doubt—unless pressure is brought to bear—whether it ever will.

Although vehemently denying the allegations, the Indonesian government is willing to admit that the allegations are not new. Why it has not chosen not to investigate them, knowing about them for all this time, will remain a matter for speculation and incrimination. In fact, the allegations raised in the documentary are totally consistent with reports which emerged from Timor immediately following the massacre. Stephen Cox, a British photographer, was quoted in the Northern Territorian newspaper five days after the November massacre as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The dead and wounded had been unceremoniously loaded onto trucks by the Indonesians, most of them Javanese, and driven away.

Mr Cox said he saw about 50 corpses but had no doubts that others were killed elsewhere. Six days after the massacre, a second Australian diplomat was sent to Dili to investigate accusations of a second massacre. According to accounts, army trucks loaded with as many as 70 people left Dili and headed west. The witness, who called for an international investigation said:
The people were naked, blindfolded, with their hands tied behind their backs, and were driven away by members of Indonesian battalions 700 and 744.

Two months after the killings, several witnesses were quoted in the Indonesian press telling of violence they had seen in the wake of the shootings. One parliamentarian was quoted as saying that he saw troop members stab wounded people after the shootings. Immediately after the November 12 killings I was personally contacted by three East Timorese families here in Australia, who told me how some of their family members were rounded up by Indonesian troops on the night of the massacre and taken away. These people, by all accounts, have never been seen nor heard from since. When I was contacted I without delay contacted officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, asking them to investigate these claims and ascertain the whereabouts of the people concerned. To this day I have not heard what happened to most of these people. The Indonesian government has never investigated these allegations and, if its track record is anything to go by, it never will. Basic human rights will continue to be abused in East Timor if things are left to the Indonesian government and the Indonesian military.

PARA.TAB: The Indonesian government did run its own inquiry into the allegations surrounding the Santa Cruz massacre. It was of course not the first massacre perpetrated against the East Timorese—murder, torture and political incarceration are no strangers in East Timor. This particular massacre is simply a continuation of the Indonesian military's oppression in East Timor since they landed there in 1975. Initially the military confirmed that 19 people had died in the graveyard at Santa Cruz. The government's commission of inquiry later revised this figure to 50 and, as I said earlier, has admitted that many people are still missing. But where are these missing people? Some have undoubtedly fled the country. Others probably went into hiding, such as the two whom the Indonesian military were able to find. Most others are obviously dead and may never receive the justice to which they are entitled.
It is interesting to note, however, in regard to these allegations that the Indonesian commission found:

SPEECH.PARA: The handling of the dead bodies of the victims . . . was not carefully managed and identified accordingly. The opportunity to identify the victims was not given to their relatives or friends.

Since then, the Indonesian government has been very stringent with whom it allows into East Timor and under what conditions they may enter. Until recently, Indonesian journalists themselves were disallowed from entering for a period of six months. The International Red Cross has had tremendous difficulty in gaining access to prisoners in East Timorese gaols. While free enterprise marches on in Indonesia, freedom, it seems, does not enjoy the same prominence.

PARA.TAB: This brings me to Australia's position on human rights, particularly in East Timor. The standard outcries at the time of the Dili massacre were expressed and were properly taken up with the Indonesian government. This parliament passed a comprehensive motion, which those opposite tried to water down, that called on the Australian government to do a number of things. We expressed our sympathy, our condemnation and our repugnance. We noted that the Indonesian government planned a commission of investigation and hoped that it would be conducted properly. Subsequently we expressed concern that it was not done in a fair and just manner. We sent our diplomats, our foreign minister and our Prime Minister to ask the appropriate questions. But still the answer as to what happened on that November day remains ambiguous at best.

We have tried to bring justice to the East Timorese people using diplomatic channels and we have failed. Perhaps the best testimony to this failure and the best indication of blatant abuse is the trials which followed the events of November 12. The results of the trials were that only 10 soldiers responsible for the killing of at least 50 people and probably over 150 were given 18-month gaol sentences, which in most cases were suspended. At the same time, the unarmed protesters were handed out sentences ranging from five years to life. This is justice Indonesian style.

A further example of the failure of justice and lack of respect for basic human rights in Indonesia was provided in the mockery of a trial given to Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao. Gusmao was denied fair representation, and was prevented from making his own statement to the court in his defence. I would like to remind members of some of Xanana's comments which he was denied the opportunity to deliver in the court. He pleads:

The question of East Timor is the responsibility of the international community, a question of international law. It is a case in which universal principles are at stake, a case where the decolonisation norms of the U.N. have been manipulated, a case where Indonesia has disregarded the resolutions of the U.N., a case therefore of the flagrant violation of the principles of the Non-Aligned Movement and of the universal pattern of law, peace and justice.

I appeal to all friends of East Timor, parliamentarians from Europe, America, Japan and Australia, to go on pressing their own governments to change the double standards applied to similar cases where systematic violations of U.N. resolutions occur, as in the case of Indonesia's behaviour regarding East Timor.
I appeal to the Secretary General of the U.N. to ensure that the solution he seeks for East Timor is based on universal principles and international law.

SPEECH.PARA: The East Timorese people, not 300 kilometres from Australia, are being persecuted by the Indonesians while we talk about the diversity of our relationship and getting on with business. When will the rights of humanity be given the same importance as the rights of trade? Is free enterprise not founded on freedom or will economic accessibility continue to take precedence in Australia's consideration of Indonesia?

PARA.TAB: Australia has expressed limited support for further United Nations examination, not only of the matter of the Dili massacre, but also in respect of the entire human rights situation in East Timor. My plea is for this to be taken much further. There have been a number of visits of United Nations envoys to Indonesia to look at the situation there. All have come out with a list of concerns and recommendations that they believe the Indonesian government should implement.

The special rapporteur on the question of torture expressed considerable concerns and the special rapporteur on judicial summary or arbitrary executions expressed similar views. The working group on enforced or involuntary disappearances also expressed very serious concerns, but still the killing goes on. All these expressions of concern led the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to release a resolution which again called on the Indonesian government to end human rights abuses in East Timor and to open the island up to greater international scrutiny. The Indonesian government worked tirelessly to try to ensure that this resolution was not adopted. It seems a pity that it is not as interested in working tirelessly to protect the rights of the East Timorese people with the same level of effort.

The Indonesian government, like Australia, is a signatory to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It is clearly not fulfilling its obligations. Last year the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade released its manual on human rights. Page 2 of the manual looks at the interface between economic interests and human rights. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government . . . does not consider that economic rights should be accorded priority over civil and political freedom. A society which respects and promotes individual rights, with the physical and intellectual freedom they involve, is more likely than not to be in a position to enjoy economic growth.

This was also raised last year by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, of which I am a member, in its report entitled Australia's relations with Indonesia. On the matter of East Timor, the report states:
It could be argued that Australia should do more, such as making East Timor an issue at the UN.

Other key recommendations of the committee are to reopen Australia's consulate in Dili and the re-establishment of a direct Darwin-Dili air service. This would demonstrate to the rest of the world that the East Timorese people are treated in the same way as the rest of the population.

PARA.TAB: I raise these issues for it is clearly time that Australia took a new approach to human rights with our nearest neighbour. It is all well and good for us to pursue their money and their trade, but surely such contact must also bring responsibility. Surely we must ensure that the people and governments with whom we trade allow their populations to enjoy the spoils of increased economic growth.

This is particularly important now that we have heard the announcement of the discovery of oil in the zone of cooperation in the Timor Sea. We need to ensure that the East Timorese, who, along with Australia are the legitimate part-owners of this valuable resource, are able to share in the benefits that this discovery will bring. While there is no doubt that increased trade and investment with Indonesia will bring increased prosperity for both of our nations, one of the benefits of increased wealth, as the human rights manual of the department indicates, should be increased freedom. By this I am not referring to the prospect of independence, to which many people in East Timor still aspire, but simply the freedom to live without fear; fear from the constant threat of torture and freedom to live without the horrible threat of death which exists every day in East Timor.

So what is to be done? Clearly, it is time for the United Nations to become involved in a much more comprehensive manner, not just by sending special envoys when the situation becomes unbearable, but by being involved at a variety of levels and in a constructive manner. Indonesia can assist by opening itself up to a full, independent, international commission of inquiry by the United Nations, not just into the massacre but also into the entire human rights situation on that island.

The Indonesian government should ensure that witnesses who choose to appear before an inquiry are given absolute and unconditional protection. Indonesia has nothing to fear from such a proposal and everything to gain. Only when it faces up to its international obligations to which it has committed itself can that country expect to gain the respect of the international community. Until that time, Indonesia will continue to be treated with suspicion and contempt for its flagrant abuses of human rights, like the ones that were committed on 12 November 1991.

The Australian government should use its good relationship with Indonesia to convince the Indonesian government that the conduct of such an inquiry, and the implementation of whatever recommendations may flow from it, will enable Indonesia and East Timor to move forward with some hope for peace and reconciliation. This is in everyone's interests, including Australia's. I sincerely hope that both governments have the maturity and the commitment to the spirit, principles and conventions of the United Nations to follow this course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills cover nearly every aspect of defence funding. Before turning to the bills, I want to make some very relevant general points about policy. The Liberal and National parties have a strong and proud record in defence issues going back a very long time. For example, the Labor Prime Minister Chifley is often praised for the work that he did as Australia's wartime leader. Of course, he did a good job in the time that he was leader but it is also true that the Australian defence effort during World War II was largely underpinned by the organisation put in place by Liberal leader Robert Menzies in his first term as Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: It should also be remembered that, in the period after the war during the 1950s and 1960s, many members of the Australian Labor Party were isolationist and many of their fellow travellers were constantly campaigning to undermine Australia's strategic alliances which have been so important in maintaining Australia's national security. Without revisiting the Vietnam War and whilst recognising that it is fair enough to criticise government policy, Australia's defence personnel copped pretty rough treatment from Labor and from the unions in the late 1960s. It is true and it should not be forgotten that members of Australia's defence forces, some soldiers, were advised that they ought not to wear their uniforms when they left their bases for fear of the public reaction to the military at that time. The coalition parties were the backbone of the successful resistance to these campaigns of an isolationist nature during those years, much of it emanating from the Labor Party and its industrial supporters.

In the late 1970s and even in the early 1980s the socialist left in the Labor Party was able to significantly influence Labor Party policy so that attacks on ANZUS were commonplace within Labor ranks. This anti-American and anti-Western alliance trend in the Labor Party saw influential figures in the Labor Party attack Australia's contribution in the Sinai and reject the Fraser government's policy of allowing both United States and United Kingdom ships to enter Australian ports.

Against this background of antipathy to Australia's role as an active member of the western alliance, the Fraser government in the 1983 election was able to campaign on its good record, which included a $6 billion defence re-equipment program, including 75 new FA18 fighters; new frigates; a commitment to and an established program for new airfields and naval bases; a good record of close cooperation with our ANZUS partners and other allies; increased surveillance of the Indian Ocean; additional support for Australian defence industries, including increases in exports of munitions; support for the Australian aircraft industry, including restructuring of the industry; the implementation of the offsets program; and many other important initiatives. Some of these decisions paved the way for the reorientation of equipment and personnel in the north and furthered the establishment of the two-ocean navy.

By the end of this parliamentary term, Labor will have been in office for 13 years and for 16 of the last 23 years. Many people either have not experienced or have forgotten the political situation facing the last coalition government. It makes an interesting contrast to the experience of the Keating government and the Hawke government before it.

On many of the major policy issues faced by Messrs Hawke and Keating, Labor has had the policy support of the coalition. Often our policy differences have been that the government has not gone far enough, not that it has introduced the wrong reforms. For example, with the deregulation of the financial markets, we have said that Labor has not gone far enough and that it should have also moved to deregulate the labour markets. We have supported financial deregulation, but we have called on the government for complementary measures such as the better supervision of the banking system, which may have provided a means by which the problems of the state banks of Victoria and South Australia could have been mitigated.

A similar theme is discernible in the defence area. In the defence area, Labor has done many of the things which were commenced by the previous coalition government. It is not surprising that we have publicly endorsed the intention of some of those policy positions of this government. But when we were in government and Labor was in opposition, Labor was actively opposed to many of the policy positions of the Fraser government.

So, in defence and foreign policy, many elements of the Labor Party were totally opposed to the broad thrust of the coalition government's policy. Labor was basically anti-US, anti-ANZUS, and anti-Western alliance. This is not to say that this was the view expressed by the leadership of the party at all times, but it was always a factor in policy deliberations within the ALP. Against this background, bearing in mind the many initiatives of the previous coalition government, the coalition has a proud record in defence issues. When we are back in government, we will give defence the high priority that it should have.

Obviously, as I have held the position of shadow minister for defence for only a few weeks, there are many issues on which I intend to focus as the opportunities present themselves in the time ahead. However, I want to start today by recognising the high quality and professionalism of the personnel of the Australian defence forces. Australia is well served by the men and women in both the Public Service and the military. They have dedicated their working lives to Australia's national security interests. Australia is fortunate to have people of the very highest calibre and motivation who are prepared to give their talents and energies in the public interest. These Australians follow in the footsteps of their predecessors, who have established an international reputation and recognition which compares favourably with other countries.

Time does not allow me to comment further on some of these personnel issues, but I want to say that we are concerned about ensuring appropriate conditions of service for all members of the armed forces. This issue is current and live and will continue to attract the strong attention of the coalition parties. We were strong in our opposition to the government's budgetary measures which were pushed through the parliament at the end of last year and which so significantly reduced the pay and conditions of those particularly at the lower end of the pay scale within the Australian defence forces.

Although the coalition's policy stands as printed, policies may be reviewed. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has established a review process. At this early stage, I am not flagging any areas for review, although obviously, as circumstances change, I will be very carefully monitoring policy. This is especially the case in 1994, as the government has just released its 1993 strategic planning review and, probably during the second half of 1994 or early in 1995, we will introduce a defence white paper.

The one policy area which is likely to be reviewed is the existing policy to cut defence expenditure by $200 million. In A Strong Australia, which was the excellent policy prepared by one of my predecessors, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the intention was to cut $500 million from existing programs and to introduce initiatives worth an additional $300 million, leaving a net cut of $200 million. The government described this as vandalism during the 1993 election, but after the election it proceeded to introduce its own cuts of a similar dimension.

Australia does spend a lot on defence. Looking at our region, using 1991 figures converted to US dollars at 1988 prices, we see that we spend more on defence than the combined budgets of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. On those converted figures, Australia's expenditure is $US6,158 million compared with $US5,783 million. A lot of people are involved, although Labor is cutting back the numbers. There are about 60,000 full-time regular members of the Australian Defence Force and 21,000 full-time civilians. In other words, about 80,000-plus people are involved full time with Australia's defence effort. In addition, there are about 26,000 army reservists, about 8,000 in the other two services and many other Australians involved indirectly.

The defence forces represent the second biggest employer after Coles-Myer in Australia. Excluding transfer payments for the Commonwealth government, defence is its biggest expenditure item. Defence spending per head in 1992-93 was $561.84. So with an average family size of about four people—it is a bit less on average—we spend about $2,000 per family per year for Australia's defence.

A commonly used measure of defence expenditure is to equate it as a measure of gross domestic product. During the Fraser years, defence expenditure, as a percentage of GDP, was 2.4, 2.4, 2.3, 2.3, 2.4, 2.5 and 2.6 per cent. In 1983-84 it started at 2.6 per cent for the first four years and since then, under this Labor administration, it has been 2.3, 2.1, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3 and 2.4 per cent. The estimated figure for the 1993-94 year is 2.3 per cent. If the figure remains down at 2.3 per cent or less, then it will mean that during the Hawke-Keating years defence expenditure, as a percentage of GDP, never rose above that spent during the Fraser years. Furthermore, except for the first four years of the 13-year period of the Hawke and Keating governments, defence expenditure will have been as low as or lower than defence expenditure in any of the Fraser years.

The opposition was quite right to argue, in the period leading up to the March 1993 election, that there are savings to be had from efficiency measures in the defence vote and that that will continue to be the case for many years to come. The real issue is whether or not any savings so achieved should be directed elsewhere out of defence. Given the expenditure cuts already introduced by Labor and the declining trend in defence expenditure, obviously that existing policy commitment is properly the subject of a review.

The fact is that we made the commitment to defence expenditure restraint in Fightback prior to settling on our defence policy. Defence policy should flow from an assessment of Australia's strategic circumstances. Our approach to whether we should review our current policy on funding will be affected by a number of factors which themselves have been changing since the commitment to the cuts was announced in Fightback in November 1991.

Significant elements of our strategic assessment contained in our defence policy in 1992 have been endorsed and updated by the government's strategic review released this week. I have already spoken about the review in parliament this week, but I think some basic points are worthy of emphasis. There are five factors that I want to mention today. Firstly, economic growth and modernisation in South-East Asia will continue over the next decade. Perhaps that is a very clear and obvious point to make, but it is an important one because of its implications for the strategic assessment. With greater economic strength, the review notes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the challenge will be to maintain the regional standing of the ADF as our traditional capability-edge narrows . . .
Secondly, the review notes:
Asia is one of the few areas of expanding arms sales.

The review also says that we do not have an arms race, but it is also a fact that, with the building industrial base and the greater economic success of our neighbours, their capacity to build their military forces is greatly enhanced. Secondly, with more open economies there should be greater political representation of the emergent middle classes and continuing political stability. In turn, the review states:
. . . the prospects are good for our active involvement over the 1990's in a `regional security community'.

Thirdly, the review points out that the strategic thinking of the United States has changed since the end of the Cold War. Dick Cheney, the former US Secretary of Defense, expressed the view recently that the US is more isolationist. Whether we accept that view or not, there is no doubt that we have seen a reduction in its military presence in our region and that has an impact obviously on our own strategic assessment. Fourthly, on page 14 of the strategic review 1993, it concludes:
Our strategic outlook for the 1990's is more complex and uncertain, although not immediately more threatening.
Fifthly, the review notes:

It is important that Australia contributes to global endeavours to develop new multilateral security mechanisms and to prevent proliferation. New international security mechanisms can only complement the security we gain from a strong, independent defence posture focused on the defence of Australia, strategic engagement in our region, and the vigorous alliance with the US.
Let me synthesise that into two points. Firstly, Australia's situation is not more benign. Secondly, the role of the Australian military forces in the years ahead will be a changing one.

PARA.TAB: In respect of both of those factors, we should ask ourselves: if our circumstances are changing—which is going to cost us money in the end—and, secondly, if our strategic assessment is not more benign, then how does the government justify slashing funding? I think that is a very significant question. The significance is perhaps sharpened by the government's current approach. When it comes to money it was outlined recently in a Jane's Defence Weekly interview with the Australian Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) that:

We made the judgement in 1991 that there would be no more real increases in defence spending this decade. Therefore to meet some of those capital equipment requirements we have to generate internal savings. What we will face over the next four years is a 2.25 per cent reduction in spending. That won't make it easy but we have indicated we wouldn't want to go any lower. I'm not expecting to go back every year to fight off another series of cuts. The Finance Department may have some views on that and we'll see who'll win.

SPEECH.PARA: Exactly! We will see who is going to win in this tug of war over the question of the ongoing financing of Australia's defence efforts. But, as the minister himself makes quite clear, this government's policy is to cut defence spending.

PARA.TAB: Cutting defence spending has an impact right across the defence portfolio, particularly when the government has already entered into a series of commitments to purchase capital equipment. In other words, we have been on a program, going back to the Fraser years, to buy a lot more equipment for our defence forces. So the government is locked into purchasing a range of capital equipment which means that if we want to cut the defence expenditures then, because we are already committed to buying a new ship, aeroplane or whatever, the impact of those cuts tends to be on the personnel side. When we think about it, ultimately the success of our defence effort is reliant on our people. Yet we have seen in recent years a considerable emphasis on cuts to personnel expenditure. We have also seen cuts to the operational readiness as the government has tried to make do with the limited dollars that it has.

In conclusion, my message is that the defence of this country could not be more important. The funding of it is a critical issue. It is one which is very high on my list of priorities as the incoming shadow minister for defence. If there is one message out of my remarks today for those interested in defence issues, it is that I will be campaigning strongly to ensure, both in coalition and in government policy, that the necessary expenditure for our proper defence of this country is made available by the political process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay The Hon L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to these appropriation bills, I take the opportunity to commend the government for its continuing diligence in effectively tackling the tough issues. The appropriation bills confirm the government's commitment to implementing important social justice initiatives like the labour market program, the child care fee relief program and improved retirement living standards for older Australians.

PARA.TAB: Although in the main the appropriation bills are concerned with minor variations across a wide range of programs, departments and agencies, I draw the attention of the House to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and the government's additional commitment to aged and retiree care. In allocating another $15.2 million to cover the associated running costs of extending fringe benefits to all pensioners and $14.6 million for the care of veterans in non-departmental health institutions, the government is ensuring the effective implementation of policies that guarantee all our elderly, whether they be pensioners, veterans or self-funded retirees, a secure and better quality of living.

The extension of fringe benefits to part-pensioners, and from July to self-funded retirees on low incomes, reflects the Labor government's dedication to ensuring the needs of older Australians are properly and adequately met. Taking care of the elderly not only is morally and socially right, but under the Keating government is a priority.

This government's record in this area speaks for itself. We have enabled aged retirees to stay in their own homes, comfortable in the knowledge that the government has provided and expanded home and community care services. It was also the Labor government which linked social security allowances and benefits to the consumer price index, reviewing pensions twice a year in line with the CPI.

As result of this and many other initiatives, the standard of living for our elderly has improved by about 14 per cent in real terms. Pensioner incomes have improved by as much as $30 a week for some pensioners. This is in sharp contrast to the situation under the previous coalition government, when pensions fell by 2.3 per cent in real terms.

Initiatives such as the extension of pensioner fringe benefits and concessions to assist part-pensioners reconfirm the continuing commitment of the Labor government to improve the standards of living for older Australians. In July this year, all retirees of pensionable age who have limited income, that is, below the pension cut-out point, will also receive the new all-in-one fringe benefits seniors card. This seniors concession card initiative means that self-funded retirees on fixed incomes, who previously missed out on assistance because they were only moderately asset rich but income poor, will now become eligible for government assistance.

In recognition of the difficulties that face people over 60 years of age trying to find full-time work, from 20 March this year a mature age allowance will be introduced. This allowance is voluntary and is specifically for people over 60 who have been registered as unemployed for one year.

Never before has a government focused so directly on aged and retirement policy, meeting the needs of all our elderly and ensuring peace of mind and dignity for those who have worked all their lives for this country. This is a generation of people who went through the hard grind to get Australia where it is today. These are the people who grew up during the Depression, who went to the war and who are now living their lives in a country that they made what it is today. It is most appropriate that the government should try to do whatever it can to ensure that they have both security and dignity.

Bettering retirement standards of living is an issue that I have had an interest in since coming to this parliament in 1979. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, I was the chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure inquiry into aged care policies, which came up with proposals that became the home and community care program. In the late 1980s, I was the chairman of the Prime Minister's aged care task force which went around Australia talking to people about what the government could do to improve the living standards of retirees. The seniors concession card is a direct outcome of the work of that committee.

I think we on this side of the House can say with some pride that we have indeed delivered on the pledge that we have made to older Australians. We have made the big yards with sweeping reforms to ensure that people can lead a dignified old age.

It seems the biggest hurdle we face in meeting the growing demand to look after the greying population is the indifferent approach by state and local governments. Honourable members will recall the difficulties that we had last year with the New South Wales government, which was not willing to meet its contribution to the home and community care program. The Fahey government was so parsimonious that it would not match the Commonwealth's grant and people in my electorate found that their services had been reduced—a scandalous approach by the New South Wales government.

It seems that local government as well is not shouldering its share of the burden. I find it unfortunate to have to talk today about the Rockdale Municipal Council and Hurstville City Council in my electorate. These two councils, with their multimillion dollar budgets, have decided to axe the voluntary rate rebate to concession card holders. These are not councils that are poor. The Hurstville council has very significant assets, a very significant rate base, a very large income and very highly paid staff. The Rockdale council is very much the same. But it has decided, in a very parsimonious approach that is typical of the approach that the Fahey government has been taking in New South Wales, to do away with this concession. At a time when the Commonwealth government is trying to expand the benefits that are payable and provided to older Australians, these parsimonious local authorities are trying to wind back provisions.

In the case of the Rockdale council, by cutting the voluntary component of rate rebate it will save a total of $60,000. In the case of the Hurstville council, it will save $115,000. They are small amounts, but they mean a lot to the people who are losing the concession. As many of the distressed constituents who contacted my electorate office this week pointed out, the savings are minute.
