They could have easily been made by cutting out some ratepayer funded junket that aldermen on local government authorities in New South Wales are often quite happy to go on. It might be a good thing for the Hurstville and Rockdale councils to send one fewer staff member or a few fewer aldermen to some parks conference or something such as that and start to put some of the effort back in for the people who elect them to the local council.

For a few thousand dollars, hundreds of pensioners throughout the St George area have been made to suffer because of these two councils' uncaring attitudes. I have received dozens of phone calls and letters from distressed and angry pensioners in my electorate about the cutting of these rebates. These cuts represent between $20 and $80 a year to most of these people. That does not seem like a great deal of money, particularly to people on high incomes such as us. It does not mean that they will go without food and clothing. It is simply a matter of dignity and, for some, the difference between being able to buy a present for a grandchild and lashing out and buying a new piece of clothing for themselves.

Only yesterday, I received a call from an 81-year-old pensioner, Mr Curtis of Millet Street, Hurstville, saying that on his estimation he was going to lose about $3 a week because of the meanness—and that is all it is—of the Hurstville City Council. Mr Curtis said he lives just near the Hurstville and Kogarah councils' boundary. It is interesting to point out that in the St George region of south-western Sydney there are three local government authorities—Rockdale, Hurstville and Kogarah. Mr Curtis lives on the railway line—adjacent to the railway line in Hurstville. I think Mr Curtis wishes that most of the aldermen lived on the railway line and the six o'clock train was coming through in a bit of a hurry.

He said that as he looks out his front door across the railway line to Kogarah council he sees houses that are not all that much different to his. When he goes for a walk on the other side of the railway line, the people over there—the same sort of people—get the benefit because the Kogarah council, at least in this instance, has been decent. Mr Curtis, like thousands of other pensioners in my electorate, cannot understand why these glaring disparities in areas so close and similar to each other are allowed to exist.

As Mr Curtis pointed out, the property values on which council rates are based are increasing while pensioner incomes are pretty much fixed. Mr Curtis and other pensioners who have rung me have pointed out that they were really able to use the benefit that the Commonwealth had given them by expanding the concessions to include people in this category. For most of them, it was something that they would look forward to for a year or so knowing that it was going to be a little bit extra in their pocket. They would get a little bit extra in their pockets if they lived in Kogarah, but not if they lived in Hurstville or Rockdale.
A typical letter that I received this week is from Mr Harry Hutt of Churchill Street, Bardwell Park. Mr Hutt summarises the actions of the Hurstville council like this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Federal Government under Paul Keating has demonstrated in many ways that it cares for pensioners, for example:
.Its decision to grant very worthwhile tax concessions to pensioners, so that many pensioners pay little or no tax.
.Its decision to grant all pensioners fringe benefits—a substantial concession of significant financial assistance to pensioners.
Mr Hutt continues:

Rockdale Council's decision negates Federal Labor policy to pensions in that Council has taken away a previous entitlement of pensioners. In other words Council has negated Federal Government policy on fringe benefits.

Perhaps that is not entirely accurate because in New South Wales there are minimum mandatory rate rebates, which were legislated by a previous Labor government. Nevertheless, I, like thousands of other people in Watson, find it absolutely scandalous that Hurstville and Rockdale councils want to take between $20 and $80 a year off a pensioner. As Mr Hutt said in his letter, `Surely this comparatively trivial amount could be saved in other less harmful ways'.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that with a bit of creative thought Hurstville council could save $115,000 somewhere in its budget, and that Rockdale council could save a lesser amount, to allow this rebate to continue. As I said earlier, maybe they could give less thought to some of the things they send people to. These aldermen are very busy at present asking the state government, through the so-called local government remuneration tribunal in New South Wales, to pay them more. It makes me wonder how much it will cost Hurstville and Rockdale councils to pay these greedy aldermen a bit more and how better that money might be spent to help those people who have been ratepayers, in many instances, all their lives.

These people have paid council rates all their lives. When those ratepayers retire Hurstville and Rockdale councils say, `You have been pretty good living here all your life; you have paid your rates and you have been a decent person, but don't ask us to help you any more. Even though the Commonwealth and state governments are willing to give you a rebate, don't ask us to keep the concession going. But the aldermen do need a little more pay, the aldermen do need another trip, and we will waste money in that way'. Maybe a few less new cars for the council officers and a few less civic receptions might be better than taking this concession off the pensioners.

What raises my wrath is the fallacy that these councils are claiming that they cannot afford the rebate because of the additional number of part pensioners who became entitled last April to the seniors concession card and the associated fringe benefits. Earlier last year the councils were trying to weasel out of giving the rebate. They said, `It is not quite clear what the Commonwealth is going to do and we have to get compensation'. The Commonwealth said that it was going to provide compensation because of this concession card.

The Commonwealth did not shirk from its responsibility. It said, `If we are going to ask other agencies, such as state and local authorities, to provide to part pensioners the same fringe benefits that full pensioners get, then we will give you some compensation'. We stood up and did what it cost us to do, but these weaselly local authorities are saying that it is very unclear. It is not unclear. They know what the facts are; they know what the truth is. It is time the voters in the municipalities woke up to it.

The Commonwealth government has given state and local government additional funds for the costs that were associated with the expansion of the fringe benefit concessionary entitlements. We have allocated in total $86.638 million to state governments as part of an ongoing compensation package. New South Wales got over $50 million in compensation that will assist with the cost of extending the fringe benefits to part pensioners.

I mentioned earlier that old Premier Fahey does not let a little money slip through his hands without having some of it stay on his hands. We saw the scandalous arrangement last year when he held on to Commonwealth money under the HACC program to balance his books before passing it on to the local HACC committees. He has done the same thing with this program.

We have given the New South Wales state government $50 million to help compensate it for the cost of this concession card. It is hard to discern exactly what is happening because the councils have not made any mention of compensation. It is difficult to even get a figure out of them as to how many concession card holders they have. I do not know how much in compensation the councils have been able to apply for, but I do know that they have been able to apply for compensation from February this year, again in June and then each quarter from then on.

With the few figures that I have to hand from Hurstville council, I know the argument that it cannot afford the voluntary rebates because of additional concession card holders is completely and utterly spurious. Last year Hurstville council had 5,511 pensioners on its books receiving a rebate. This year the numbers increased to 5,856—345 more than last year. It is easy to see that the Hurstville council will probably make money by putting the squeeze on the pensioners. Anyone can tell by looking at these numbers that it will come out very nicely with its compensation funding and with the money it will save in future years from the cutting of this rebate.

It must and should be remembered that rebates were introduced to ease the financial burden of people on fixed incomes to meet council rates, which are based on property values. Hurstville and Rockdale councillors should hang their heads in shame for putting the squeeze on pensioners, particularly when, as I said earlier, they are pushing for an increase in their aldermanic allowances.

These same councils refused to even give a part rebate to new concession card holders last April. They claimed that they could not give the rebate unless people had a concession card at the beginning of the year, in January. So they stole half the year's rebate from pensioners. These councils failed to tell their ratepayers that under another section of the Local Government Act voluntary rebates are made at the discretion of the individual council. They know that they could have given the rebate, but they told the people, `Unless you had the card in January, we cannot help you'. They obviously copped so much flak last year for this low act that they have decided to avoid the problem all together this year by scrapping the rebate.

These councils may and often do justify their actions by talking about the great service they provide for the elderly. It is just sad that they are usually referring to programs which are funded in large amounts by the Commonwealth, such as the home and community care program and the Meals on Wheels service. As honourable members know, the predominant funding for those programs comes from federal and state governments, not from the local authorities. The actions of Hurstville and Rockdale councils in taking this rebate away from elderly ratepayers are nothing short of disgraceful. They should think again. I intend to remind voters when the next election comes around just how miserly these councils have been. They ought to take a bit of a pay cut themselves. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this very broad matter of the appropriation bills, I refer to what will be a great moment in Australia's political history—tomorrow's COAG meeting in Hobart. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has attempted to hijack the agenda for this meeting with his incorrect claims that only the states must complete the micro-economic reform agenda. The real issue at this meeting must be to properly define the constitutional powers and responsibilities of state governments and the consequent rights of the people of those states.

PARA.TAB: It is an established fact of the democratic process that the centralisation of power in a single legislature creates all the opportunities for a totalitarian or dictatorial regime and, because of the most recent abuses of our constitutional division of powers through the use of the external affairs powers, Australia has never been closer to that situation. I was alarmed recently whilst in formal discussions with representatives of the Australian mining industry to be informed that the Australian mining industry is in negotiations with certain committees of the United Nations to establish its rights to participate in the Australian mining industry.

Put simply, Australian businesses, and presumably in time individual Australians who can afford it, must travel overseas to clarify their right to do business or simply raise a family in this independent nation we call Australia. I find a great irony in our Prime Minister telling us that we must cut whatever tenuous links we have with the United Kingdom today while he goes off week after week signing away the rights of Australians to the United Nations.

This sell-out of the individual rights of the people of a state, particularly when in a country the size of Australia their needs are so diverse and, in some cases, their proportional representation at federal level is so limited, is a national disaster. My state of Western Australia has 14 seats in this parliament; the state of New South Wales has 50. The only means by which such erosion of the rights of the individual of a state can be averted is by the eternal vigilance of state government members and those elected from a state to the federal parliament.

It is irrefutable that state premiers must first argue for the rights and interests of the people of the state they represent and that those elected federally work assiduously to ensure that the acts of a federal government do not reduce such things as employment opportunities and the financial future of the people who have voted them to office within that particular state.

One would also hope that such representatives would bring to Canberra a commitment to and a history of the very highest standards of personal integrity and propriety in high office. In this regard, the candidates contesting the Fremantle by-election provide an interesting case study. At the Prime Minister's personal request, the defeated premier of Western Australia, and until recently leader of the state opposition, Carmen Lawrence has been endorsed as the ALP candidate for Fremantle. I must submit to this parliament that if the people of Fremantle elect her they can expect none of the criteria that I have just delineated to be met.

It is of some irony that certain newspapers are speculating today that, upon her arrival in federal parliament—an outcome I will contest till the last vote is counted—the discredited minister for sports rorts will be replaced. Such an action would be one of replacing a vampire bat with Dracula at the blood bank. Where Ros Kelly has dipped an egg cup into the barrel of public moneys, Carmen Lawrence has dipped a barrel. What is more—I will elaborate on this later—in Carmen's case the blood, in the form of a woman's life, is still on her hands.

Carmen Lawrence was, in my judgment, the most devious, dishonest, incompetent and centralist premier of the WA Inc. era. It was she who went off to the first COAG meeting in Brisbane not, as Richard Court will do tomorrow, to defend the rights and interests of the people of Western Australia and the future of their children, but to sell out to a centralist government where Western Australia's vote did not count. At the end of that first meeting she had signed a blank cheque, a blank piece of paper, no conditions, to hand over our standard gauge railway—the only profitable component of the entire proposed national grid—and the jobs of all those who currently gain employment from that particular piece of railway line. I represent a number of those people in places such as Merredin. They were all to go and they knew it. She sold out on the rights to license and establish licence fees for our extensive state road transport network, which would have resulted in such licence fees quadrupling, at a cost to all those consumers in Western Australia who have no choice but road transport.

She is the ardent supporter of the intrusion of federal laws into Western Australian jurisdictions, be it in the area of the environment, industrial relations, land administration or mining. Furthermore, her procrastination in important decision making totally destroyed business confidence in Western Australia and denied many Western Australians any job opportunities subsequently, one outstanding example being the essential Marandoo iron ore mine in Western Australia's Pilbara, which is now running approximately three years behind schedule. It was not a new mine as such. That was a mine replacing Hamersley's worked out current mining activities and necessary just to maintain Australia's export effort, something which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) like to stick their chests out and boast about.

This is not a case of a representative for Fremantle. If Carmen Lawrence is elected, it will be Keating's woman in Fremantle, not Fremantle's woman in Canberra, which of course it should be. Marandoo mine is three years behind schedule, a real downside to our export effort. She could not make up her mind. There were too many people coming knocking on her door instead of getting on with the major mining project.

Notwithstanding Prime Minister Keating's arrogant and uncaring statement that Western Australia would be the state which would be most disadvantaged by his Mabo legislation, Carmen Lawrence has again nailed her colours to Mr Keating's Mabo mast. If the people of Fremantle believe Mabo has no chance of affecting them, let me say that already a number of Western Australia's fishermen are in receipt of Mabo writs entangling them in certain Kimberley land claims. Some may be residents of Fremantle, but all Fremantle fishermen can rest assured that, in time, all the areas which they are entitled to fish, and which are clearly not areas where native title is extinguished—there is no freehold out in the sea—will be the subject of Keating Mabo litigation at great cost and possible loss of fishing entitlements.

Of course, it is the cost that is the big issue. This particular writ that I have here is not one that particularly wishes immediately to take away the rights of certain fishermen. It will just entangle them in the court process, costing them tens of thousands of dollars. Any person, owner or deckhand who votes for Carmen Lawrence is voting for the possible death of their livelihood. As I have already said, Carmen Lawrence is no stranger to death. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table a copy of just one writ that has been handed to me and delivered to a number of fishermen in my electorate.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) might like to have a look at it and see whether it is a writ. He has some legal background, I think. The list of indictments of Carmen Lawrence's stewardship as MP and premier is much too long for this speech, but the supreme irony is that she is touted as a replacement for the discredited Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) who has clearly been caught on three occasions misleading this parliament, notwithstanding the attempts of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) not to deny that but to define them as technical. I am very interested in what is a technical misleading of the parliament. I would have thought that that sounds worse.

PARA.TAB: Carmen Lawrence has also lied to the people of Western Australia more recently when she repeatedly told them that she would not be leaving the Western Australian parliament for a seat in Canberra when clearly at that time, at the time she was giving those assurances publicly, the only impediment to her going was her concluding a deal on her political future with Paul Keating. She was working out what spot she was going to get on the frontbench, yet she was telling the people of Western Australia, `No I will not desert you. I am in here for the long haul. You need my protection'. Of course she was coming; she just had not finalised the deal.

Throughout her evidence to the royal commission on WA Inc., her consistent response to all questions was, `I cannot recall'. You may not be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, but in Western Australia they actually made a tie with the Latin for `I cannot recall' printed on it. It was called the WA Inc. tie and many people were seen to be wearing it. Her other words, of course, were, `I cannot remember'. She sat through years of cabinet meetings where all those dirty WA Inc. deals were done, apparently with plugs in her ears. She is clearly a liar. She did know what was going on, and do not tell me I cannot call her a liar. She is not here yet and there is no way that you can say that this is not a relevant speech because you know it is the appropriation debate, so do not waste my time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I warn you: I will be seeking for you to be dealt with.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw attention to the language that has been used. I believe it is unparliamentary to be using that form of language and I ask you to ask the speaker to use normal parliamentary language in the chamber.

—As the parliamentary secretary may have noted, I interrupted the member for O'Connor. The honourable member for O'Connor was out of order, regardless of the language used, in addressing his remarks to the parliamentary secretary and not through the chair, as the member for O'Connor is aware. While it is true that the anticipated honourable member for Fremantle is not here and therefore that particular standing order is not offended, I do think it is unnecessarily provocative for the member for O'Connor to continue in that vein.

—Thank you for your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. Her evidence to the royal commission is a matter I have dealt with. I have made those remarks and I now add some evidence for the parliamentary secretary. There is also her involvement as a member of parliament and a minister in the sale of the Midland Abattoir for $450,000 to a Labor mate. The site, of course, was worth millions. The Midland Abattoir was an area of 65 hectares located within the Perth metropolitan area.

PARA.TAB: The purchaser recovered the $450,000 from the sale of plant and the present state government has been forced to pay over $2 million to resume a small area comprising the associated saleyards. She put her name to a report saying that the deal was proper, then arranged to have all the evidence shredded. Not for Carmen the simplicity of a whiteboard. She chose the more respected Labor device of the shredder.

Earlier I claimed that Carmen Lawrence had blood on her hands. I meant the statement literally. I cannot accuse her of murder because she did not connect the hosepipe to the exhaust of Penny Easton's car or provide her with the pills, one of which things killed her. But the only reason Penny Easton is not alive today is Carmen Lawrence.

When one considers the similarities between Carmen Lawrence and the Prime Minister, the comparison is frightening. I have just been told not to say that she is a liar, so I will say she tells porkies; she is an administrative incompetent; she is a centralist; she has an arrogant disregard for parliament or proper procedure and the rights of individuals and their personal privacy.

She also, like the Prime Minister, takes little account of her financial affairs. You might be reminded, Mr Deputy Speaker, how the Prime Minister forgot to put in two tax returns. Just prior to her elevation to Premier, Carmen Lawrence received a government cheque for overseas travel allowance of $5,000. She did not use this money, which remained in her bank account for—surprise, surprise—two years and, as with the Prime Minister, two tax returns. Apparently her tax agent never said to her, `You seem to have some unexplained money in your account'.

Eventually the matter became a subject of police investigations and, of course, impending political embarrassment. Did Carmen Lawrence decide to take it on the chin? No. She set about to conspire to entangle one of the then members of the opposition, in fact the then Leader of the Opposition, Richard Court, in a matter entirely unrelated to him in order to create a smokescreen. The conspiracy required the allegation of perjury in the Family Court against two innocent women, to say nothing of the invasion of their privacy, which was supposed to be legally guaranteed through the Family Court legislation.

Her lieutenant, John Halden, consequently tabled a petition from Penny Easton's divorced husband making allegations of perjury against Penny Easton and her sister, Margaret McCauley, both of whom were practising lawyers. Lawrence's reason for this attack was that apparently on one occasion Penny Easton visited Richard Court when he was in opposition to request further detail on allegations he had made in the parliament of government golden handshakes to certain persons, including her husband, which her husband denied in the Family Court that he had received

Mr Court apparently referred her to the public record, his speech in parliament, but Carmen wanted to prove that Court had released confidential information and was subject to some police inquiry, due to Easton laying a complaint. This was a very tenuous link but this allegation of perjury made in the parliament and given wide publicity had such an effect on Penny Easton that she committed suicide within days of the allegations being made in the parliament by Carmen Lawrence's lieutenant and with her knowledge and consent. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, these things do not happen without such arrangements. Furthermore, in this case she was the author of this thing—just to protect herself from the fact that she had kept $5,000 of public moneys in her bank account. What is more, Carmen Lawrence had good reason to know that Penny Easton had not committed perjury in claiming to the Family Court that her husband had received additional government golden handshakes, because Carmen Lawrence knew that Easton had secretly received such moneys from the government. With all this knowledge, she callously conspired to cause an innocent woman's death simply to gain a political advantage.
Let me say consequently to the Prime Minister that he will have to move over. Even he would not have stooped, and I do not think will stoop, to such depths in his pursuit of the political game.

They are just a few of the matters that I could raise about this woman that the Prime Minister has asked to come, at his personal request, to represent the people of Fremantle in Canberra. As I say, they are not going to receive representation from her. Western Australia is not going to receive representation from her. All the evidence is that during her term as Premier she sought to give away everything that Western Australians hold dear, everything they need for the future of their families, to a central government. She stormed out of the parliament in Western Australia when Richard Court passed a piece of Mabo legislation that was our state's legislation. It is the people of Western Australia who have the constitutional right to decide how land will be managed. Of course, she has supported wholeheartedly another piece of legislation which has more to do with stopping Court's legislation than having it go through the proper processes and being tested in the High Court.

It is not that we have a conflict of principle. Court's legislation could have been tested on principle. No, we have a contest in the High Court as to who has the overriding power. Carmen Lawrence has supported that wholeheartedly and criticised Court at length, yet her own Prime Minister, this person who has invited her—in fact, has inveigled her—to Canberra, who has given her a deal including a front bench position, told Western Australians with callous disregard that Western Australia would be the state most disadvantaged and hurt by his Mabo legislation.

That alone should be the reason why this woman, if she had any concerns for Western Australia or the electorate of Fremantle, should have said, `I could never do business with you'. But she has jumped in here at a second's notice and is asking the people of Fremantle to vote for her as a representative of Western Australia.

She is no representative of Fremantle or of Western Australia. She is going to be the Prime Minister's representative in Fremantle, not Fremantle's representative in Canberra. I encourage everybody in the Fremantle electorate to consider this woman, consider what she did against Western Australia's interests and vote for our candidate—Geoff Hourn—who will give them the sort of representation they desire. He has a background of honesty and decency and service that warrants his election.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—The honourable member sought leave to table a paper. Does the honourable member still seek leave to table the paper?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but is the government going to give me permission?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat through a lot of speeches in this place and listened to people denigrate other people who are not here to defend themselves. I think it is the lowest act that any member of this parliament can participate in here. The person referred to by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) cannot defend herself. To use parliamentary privilege to indulge in the kind of comment that we have heard from the honourable member for O'Connor really debases the parliament. That is why people in this country are getting fed up with the performance of parliamentarians.

PARA.TAB: What we have heard from the honourable member for O'Connor is the very kind of performance that debases the standing of this parliament in the minds of the public. I have heard lots of disgraceful performances but that one takes the prize. He is really making a terrible mistake if he thinks that voters and the community generally are so stupid as to be influenced by somebody who uses the privilege of this parliament, the powerful tool that that is, to denigrate somebody and persuade third parties to support a Liberal Party candidate. Really, it is a pathetic performance from a pathetic member.

Carmen Lawrence, were she here, would be well able to respond to his comments. I do not doubt she will reply when she gets here. That is what he is afraid of. He is afraid of her getting here, so he is prepared to debase this institution to try to counter his own fears. No matter what that pathetic speaker had to say a few minutes ago, people in the electorate of Fremantle will judge Carmen Lawrence on her merits, not on the basis of a 20-minute tirade of abuse in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. At the first opportunity available to me I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member can make a personal explanation but not during a speech by another honourable member.
—I do not know that that is the case. I am taking a point of order to that effect—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I will say that again when she comes here. I will accuse her of those things when she is here, because they are true.
—You won't say it outside. You are a brave man! You are a wonderful man! You are an honourable man! You are an honourable and wonderful man! You are a courageous man!
—What about John Dawkins before I came here? Go and check the records.

—Go and have your tablet; it is time for your tablet. Carmel Lawrence will be judged by the people of the electorate of Fremantle as they know her, not on the basis of a tirade of abuse and denigration delivered by a member of this parliament who, in the process, has debased the institution of the parliament. When she comes here she will have her opportunity to refute what he has had to say, and I have no doubt she will do it very ably. Carmen Lawrence will bring to this place a strong voice for the electorate of Fremantle in a stable government that is steering our economy through a pattern of growth and improvement, an economy that is performing better than any of the other Western economies.

PARA.TAB: People can choose very easily in the electorate of Fremantle. They can choose a voice in the wilderness with Geoff Hourn and thereby support the tirade of abuse and personal denigration we have heard from the honourable member for O'Connor, or they can choose a competent, able, dedicated woman in Carmen Lawrence, who will bring to this place a very strong voice as a member of a government that listens to people and that is steering this economy into growth—the highest growth we have seen for many years—higher employment and stability. That will be their choice.

I want to devote the rest of my remarks to the appropriation bills before us and say something about the improvement in the economy as well as comment on the coal industry and the effect it has on employment in my electorate. This year we are beginning on a much better note than last year; there is growth now in the economy. The figures that came out in the revision of the budget estimates a few weeks ago show that the growth in the total value of goods and services produced in this country this financial year is expected now to be 3 1/2 per cent rather than the 2 3/4 per cent that was forecast at budget time. That is very good news. We are looking at a growth rate of four per cent next financial year.

That 3 1/2 to four per cent increase in gross domestic product is the magic figure whereby we then start to pull down the pool of unemployment. Until we get beyond that 3 1/2 per cent, particularly as the participation rate changes, we will have difficulty in trying to reduce the pool of unemployment. There is one problem for us in that: as the number of jobs grows and the opportunity for employment increases, people who had previously dropped out will be coming back into the work force.

The employment growth in 1993-94, forecast to be three-quarters of one per cent at budget time, now is at the level of about 1 3/4 per cent. We had expected an increase of 100,000 in the number of jobs created in this financial year, but that has now been revised to 200,000. Those figures really give hope to the rest of the community and to those people seeking employment. As well, we had expected to see a reduction in the forecast inflation rate, or the consumer price index, of the order of 3 1/2 per cent, but it is back to under two per cent.

When we look at an increasing growth rate, the lowest interest rates in 20 years, the lowest inflation rate in 30 years and the lowest level of industrial disputes since the 1960s, we can see that there is a good, stable base being established in the economy and very good prospects for growth.That is best reflected in the growing optimism among people that we are seeing now right around Australia. Things are getting better; we are past the worst. The growth is not coming fast enough at this stage but it will improve. The important thing is that the worst is behind us.

The outlook for the year ahead of us is much better than the outlook at this time last year. It was then much more spotty. We thought there would be improvement, but the rate of improvement did not develop as fast as we had hoped. To take an external index—an outside referee—the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment shows that consumer confidence is at its highest level for five years. In my own area, the central coast of New South Wales and the Hunter, there is a much more optimistic outlook. All the jobs have not come there yet but people are feeling more optimistic. Things are starting to happen and new jobs are starting to be created. The task now is to accelerate the growth, and so create new jobs, as quickly as possible.

I now want to turn to the coal industry. It is an industry which produces $A7.5 billion per year in exports, but it is open slather in that industry. No clear strategy for the coal industry has been put forward by the government, by the industry itself or by the trade unions. They have been working on developing a strategy, but what we effectively have is open slather.

The coal reserves are under the control of state governments and, particularly in New South Wales, it is just open slather. Underground coalmines, with valuable coal reserves intact, are being closed down. The coal is being squandered or sterilised, and new mines are being opened up with overseas investment. It is a very clever strategy of our buyers, particularly the Japanese, to invest in coal loading facilities and new coalmines and to open up new sources of coal supply so that they can keep a lid on Australia's demand for better prices. In that way they can generate more supply and so ensure that the price is kept within the margin that they want it kept within, without regard to the effect that it has on Australia.

Under this open slather policy, organised buyers—and Japan takes 50 per cent of our coking coal—are getting together and working out a strategy. They have a clear strategy—which I referred to in this House the other day—which is set out in the Akira Chimura report which was published a few months ago. It is a clear strategy by organised buyers of our largest export to depress prices, generate oversupply and benefit Japanese steel mills at the expense of this country's foreign earnings, its coal workers and the Australian coal industry.

When a coalminer loses a job in the Hunter region you can bet your bottom dollar that three other people will lose their jobs as well, because that is the rate of the multiplier effect. The businesses that supply and service the equipment in the mines and supply the materials that go to underground and open-cut coalmining will be affected. So when one coalmining job goes three other jobs go, and the loss of those jobs will be to the benefit of purchases of Australian coal by Japanese steel mills.

The Japanese invest in those coalmines and in the loading facilities. They then have full access to the cost structures of the mines or facilities that they are part of. They are in a very powerful position to know what they can extract from their suppliers and what the mills can extract from the suppliers of coal in terms of price reduction.

They mouth the words when they say, `Since the Japanese steel mills want certainty of supply, then they should ensure that there is investment in Australian facilities to maintain that continuity'. However, that is not the real reason. The real reason is to get access to the information, to get the guts of their opponents' business, to know how hard to squeeze without strangling.

They can squeeze right down until the industry is just surviving, but not actually dead, and that is what is happening in the Hunter region. That is what is happening in the Australian coal industry. Effectively, what has happened over the last 10 years, and particularly in the last five years since 1988, is that the benefits of improvement in the coal industry—with changed shift arrangements, changed working arrangements, multiskilling, better training, altered roster arrangements, around-the-clock working, seven-day working—all those productivity benefits, substantial as they are, have gone to the Japanese steel mills in respect of coking coal.

Japan has a similar strategy in respect of steaming coal. Let me just say that there is nothing wrong with airing this issue here. The Japanese are our customers, but they are much more open about this as an industry in Japan. They are dealing with buyers. They want to buy as cheaply as they can. They prepare their strategy papers. They publish their strategy papers. They meet as a group. They organise. They plan. However, in this country what we have is a group of unorganised sellers and producers who are competing with each other, and yet they are trying to deal with a group of highly organised, competent and sophisticated buyers in the Japanese steel mills and even in the purchase of steam coal.

In many ways, all of those difficulties bring the industry to a sad and sorry state. In 1970 there were 37 underground mines in my region, in the Newcastle and the Central Coast regions. Today there are 17. Thirty-eight per cent of the industry is said to be making a loss. That is despite the productivity improvements. This is really a reflection of the depression in coal prices over the past five years particularly.

The Japanese have gained through price cuts in the last 10 years an amount that is equivalent to one-fifth of our overseas debt: $A31.2 billion dollars. That is the dollar value of what they have extracted from the Australian coal industry over the past 10 years. So the sacrifices are made; the changes are made; the restructuring goes on. But all the benefit of that has been passed directly to Japanese purchasers of Australian coal.

Over 1992-93, 1,500 mineworkers were retrenched in the Hunter region, mostly in the Newcastle area. Only 150 of those persons have been re-employed over the last 12 months. At the current rate of re-employment, it may be five to six years before those men can expect to get back into regular employment. In comparison, during 1987-88, 2,000 mineworkers lost their jobs in the Hunter but most of them were able to get back into work by 1991.

In my electorate of Shortland, two years ago there were seven underground mines operating. Today there are five: Newvale 2, Wallarah, Chain Valley Bay, Wyee and Munmorah. The Friday before last, Moonee Mine at Catherine Hill Bay joined the other closed mines of the area. Moonee was putting out 311,100 tonnes of saleable coal over 1992-93. It has 15 million tonnes of good coal, valuable coal, untouched. This is another 15 million tonnes of coal that is being squandered in this country with the closure of that mine. Newvale 2 is operating at a rate of 470,000 tonnes a year, reduced from 630,000 tonnes. Chain Valley Bay and Wallarah are in the process of undergoing cutbacks with the retrenchment of a further 60 workers. Both those mines are under contract, but the new owners are not committed to the current level of output of 1.8 million tonnes. Wyee mine supplies Vales Point power station with 1.65 million tonnes of coal per year and Munmorah mine supplies 1.1 million tonnes, which is split between Munmorah power station and Vales Point power station.

Right across those underground mines, good coal—not coal that is of low thermal value—is squandered, wasted, buried forever because of the commercial practice and because there is no clear, firm industrial strategy for the coal industry. Most of all, in New South Wales, there is an open slather policy. Catch-as-catch-can, they can go in: whoever wants to invest, can invest and open up new mines, close down existing mines, without any regard to the longer-term benefit to this nation. They will rue the day when those who follow us look back and see what we did with those valuable energy reserves.

In New South Wales the treatment by Pacific Power of its employees, as it has closed mines down, is nothing short of despicable. I do not think that I have seen, in all my experience in industrial relations and transport in this place and elsewhere before I came here, an organisation which handles its employees as badly as that organisation. It effectively amounts to terrorising employees. First it says, `Jobs are going to go. Your pit may close', then, `We are not sure about it', then, `It looks more likely', then, `We think 40 per cent of the work force is going to go, but we can't tell you which ones'. And so it goes on and on. Then decisions are made to shift the market across to private sector mines at the expense of the publicly owned mines such as Pacific Power. If ever there was an organisation that needs the cleaners through it and needs the top management looked at, it is that organisation.

The thing that I feel so strongly about is the despicable way in which it has treated miners, and their families, whose life's work has been for the Electricity Commission of New South Wales. The workers have been treated with total disregard. The commission lives in an ivory tower. It does not seem to understand the anxiety and the worry of families when the income earner is threatened with unemployment.

That is the message I bring to honourable members in the parliament today. It is very difficult for the economy to grow fast enough in our region to make up for the jobs that have been destroyed in the Hunter region and the Central Coast region by the government of New South Wales. In areas such as mines, power stations, the bus services, the railways, the health services and all of those sectors where there are people with special trades and skills, one cannot suddenly just take, say, a mineworker who has been thrown out by the state government and transfer him to a position as a tourist guide. One cannot retrain people and swap them around like that, so families continue to be affected by trauma and suffering.

As I said earlier, honourable members should not forget that there is a multiplier of about three to one in the mining industry so that, when one miner goes, four jobs are lost—his and the jobs of three others. That is the effect of unemployment in the Hunter. We have had difficulty in creating jobs fast enough for those people.

I look forward to the statement from the government at the end of April on employment and its consideration of the problems of the regions such as ours. I ask, as strongly as I can, that special consideration be given to long-term unemployed persons, the persons who are semiskilled or trade skilled, who have more difficulty than anybody else in trying to find employment again once they have lost their job. I put that request to the government in the expectation that it will be strongly and favourably responded to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sports rort affair has given all Australians a clear indication of how this government spends taxpayers' money. The Labor Party, it is now evident for all to see, has made pork-barrelling an art form and has apparently done so with impunity. In the whole of this sports rorts affair it has become quite obvious that there are substantial benefits for those who are fortunate enough—and I use those words fairly loosely—to live in a safe or marginal Labor seat. There is no doubt that, on the measure of the sports rorts affair, safe Liberal seats are very much at the end of the government's priorities.

PARA.TAB: It is possible to argue, as the honourable member for Canberra and Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has, that demographics demand more spending in Labor electorates because in many respects they are poor by virtue of their being Labor seats, but I want to tell the House today that this is not always the case. A socioeconomic status index based on the latest census actually ranks my electorate of McPherson ninth lowest of 147 electorates in Australia.

The electorate of McPherson, which is based on the Queensland Gold Coast, actually has a number of what are perceived as negative factors in making this calculation. We have, for example, the highest proportion of people over 65 years of age. We have one of the highest unemployment rates and, interestingly, at the other end of the scale, we have a very high proportion of families with incomes below $16,000. We have a very low number of families on incomes above $60,000—just 10 per cent. Overall, we are ranked 127 out of 147 electorates in terms of the highest levels of unemployment. So on the basis of the census statistics, my electorate of McPherson and, to a very large extent, the adjoining electorate of Moncrieff—the Gold Coast as a whole—actually ranks in some respects as poor. Of course, the Gold Coast has many positive aspects as well, but in demographic terms we might well be regarded as poor.

We have been ranked very low because both of those electorates, fortunately—and I certainly give credit to the constituents in my electorate and in the electorates of my colleagues for their sound judgment—have chosen to make themselves safe Liberal electorates. This is reflected, of course, in the level of services that we actually receive from the government. There are a number of glaring examples of the treatment of the Gold Coast generally compared directly with the adjoining seats of Richmond and Page just on the other side of the New South Wales border, in the northern rivers area of New South Wales.

The other thing to say about the Gold Coast in this context is that it is also the fastest growing part of Australia and yet government services consistently fail to keep up with that growth. Often that is purely as a result of poor planning by governments at both federal and state levels. I could give a number of example of this. We have on the Gold Coast the Gold Coast University College of Griffith University. I have consistently pointed out in this place how inadequately funded it is. It has never been able to go anywhere near meeting the demand for places in it. Total QTAC preferences for courses at Griffith in 1994 were 14,821 and yet only 1,097 new places were provided at Griffith University on the Gold Coast.

The increase in total QTAC preferences this year was 21 per cent above last year's figure and yet the government goes nowhere near meeting the demand for places at that university. Interestingly, across the border in the electorates of Page and Richmond the government has plans to spend $50 million building the Southern Cross University. That is an example of its priorities.

Talking about veterans affairs matters, my electorate has a very large number of veterans. For some time I have been attempting to have a Veterans' Affairs office opened up on the Gold Coast. One has been promised for early this year and that after a lot of hard lobbying. However, the northern rivers had one opened just before the last election. It also had, at the same time, a permanent office of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service put there.

The interesting fact is that the Gold Coast has twice as many veterans as the northern rivers area. We have 500 Vietnam veterans and 432 of their dependents as well compared to the northern rivers area of 298 veterans and 294 dependents. But we have to wait. The government gives the excuse that we are close to Brisbane but for anyone who knows the difficulties associated with travelling from the Gold Coast to and from Brisbane, that is a very poor excuse indeed. The fact is that Richmond and Page on the other side of the border are marginal Labor electorates.

The Family Court Counselling Service is another example. This service has only just this week been reinstated on the Gold Coast. It was taken away in December 1991 because it was being over utilised and counsellors could not meet the demand for their services. When I took this matter up with the Attorney-General he said it was the Family Court's fault for not allocating funds to the Gold Coast. However, the Chief Justice of the Family Court told me that it was the Attorney-General who had not given them enough money to do it. The fact was it took us two years to get this vital service reinstated on the Gold Coast. It took an enormous amount of effort, not only on my own part but also on the part of a large number of local residents.

Another federal government service that is provided to Australians generally is ABC radio and yet on the Gold Coast, believe it or not, we are still waiting for the ABC Radio National and fine listening service. My predecessor, going back a number of years, had been pushing for this. Promises have been made consistently by ministers to him and to me but they have always been broken. We are still not sure when the Gold Coast is going to have this very basic ABC service.

Let us go across the New South Wales border into Richmond and Page and what do we find? Of course, it is not difficult to guess. They have ABC Radio National on both the AM and FM band and they also have the ABC Triple-J service as well, which is not available on the Gold Coast either.

It boils down very clearly to a matter of planning and priorities. The Gold Coast and the federal electorates that are based there have been given no priorities for planning to take account of the incredible growth there. After listening to the debate over the sports rorts affair it has become quite obvious to all what many of us knew anyway, that this is the way that the Labor party runs the country. I think that that is a very poor state of affairs indeed.

The corrupt way that the Labor Party wields power is not confined to pork-barrelling. In many respects, unfortunately, most people seem to think that pork-barrelling is somehow normal or excusable, although the extent to which Minister Kelly has taken it has put it beyond that situation.

I now want to spend a few minutes looking at the ABC. Many Australians are concerned about the perceived Labor Party bias in the ABC. When we look at the situation, we can see that there are obviously some very strong and longstanding connections between the ABC and the ALP. One wonders, for example, whether the new screening time for the rebroadcast of question time, that is, 1 o'clock in the morning, is as a result of the Prime Minister getting on the phone to his mate David Hill. We also know David Hill's background, the boss of the ABC: strong ALP connections going way back to the time he worked for Mr Wran, who was then the Premier of New South Wales.

So now the Prime Minister has said to Mr Hill, `We have downgraded question time. We do not want to be too accountable for our actions, so let us make sure that the bulk of Australians that want to watch the rebroadcast of question time have to stay up till 1 o'clock in the morning to do it'. I do not think any of them are going to be too enthusiastically waiting up until 1 o'clock to see question time.

I have here the latest report of the ABC board. It is not a very large board, but a prominent member of it is a lady by the name of Janine Walker. She is an official of the Queensland State Service Union. She was once an ALP candidate and she is a member of the ABC board.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what!
—If the honourable member listens, I will tell him so what, because I am making a very strong case and, hopefully, it is not going to be lost on him. Another director of—
—There are a lot of Liberal Party supporters on boards, too.

—The honourable member does not like it. Another director of the ALP is Rod Cameron. He has worked for the ALP for years. He has been its official pollster and he has been appointed to the ABC board. Not one of the seven principles which are on page 1 of the annual report refers to independence. There are all sorts of other you-beaut things the ABC is in favour of, like being identifiably Australian and so on and so on, but nothing about it being independent. One can seriously question whether it is when it is run effectively by mates of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: The recent sacking of Pamela Bornhorst, who was the ABC's 7.30 Report presenter in Queensland, was politically motivated. I asked some questions of the then Minister for Communications here about that. Of course, he said it was not, but it was quite clear that her sacking was politically motivated. Premier Goss had refused to be interviewed on the ABC's 7.30 Report in Brisbane for some time. Miss Bornhorst herself said at the time that she was `out of favour with the government'. There is plenty of evidence, I believe, in the sacking of Mrs Bornhorst that there was direct and indirect involvement, not only by Mr Goss but by some of his other people, particularly Minister Mackenroth.

The 1992-93 annual report of the ABC shows that ABC revenue from the government was $575.6 million. That is 9c a day for every Australian. It used to be 8c. People will like to know that it has gone up to 9c a day that we are all paying for the ABC. Every Australian has a vested interest in the ABC; we own it. As we own it, we have a right to believe that it will present a wide diversity of views. But it very often does not. One of the complaints I often get from people who listen to the ABC—and I must say that I spend a good deal of time watching and listening to the ABC—is that it is not entirely independent. The point I am making today—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) does not like it very much, but let me make the obvious conclusion—is that it is not entirely independent, not only because of the composition of its board but because of a whole lot of other connections, which I do not have not time to go into today, although I might do so on another occasion, that exist between the ALP and the ABC.

Talking about Australians owning the ABC—which we do—let me say to the House today that the ALP's decision to televise what they call the `highlights' of Sydney's annual Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras should concern most Australians. It would probably be fairer to say that they are going to be televising the `lowlights'! It might well be that many Australians might want to withhold their 9c, at least on the day that that is televised. A recent poll showed that 75 per cent of Australian people were against the televising of this particular event. Surely the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras in Sydney is against normal community standards. Yet, when this was taken up with the ABC, an ABC executive by the name of Vaughan Hinton said:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the ABC is concerned, we have a charter to reflect Australian life in all of its diversity, and the mardi gras is part of that diversity.

I would like to say to him that many would regard it as perversity, not diversity. In any case, even if there were an argument for televising that particular event, perhaps he would like to run the same argument that maybe we see that paedophiles or rapists or murderers are part of the diversity too—but that does not mean that we encourage them.

PARA.TAB: But it is worse than that. The ABC actually plans to televise the highlights, or lowlights—however you see it—of this event at 8.30 p.m. on a Sunday night, 6 March. I do not want to give it any commercials, but I want to say that 8.30 p.m. is family viewing time on a Sunday night for a lot of kids these days. I do not particularly mind if people want to go to Sydney and watch the parade—it might be quite a spectacle. But I really question whether we want it televised into our lounge rooms at 8.30 on a Sunday night. In this year, the International Year of the Family, that seems to be ironically inconsistent. Surely, if they have to telecast this event, they could do it at 2 o'clock in the morning, after question time.

It shows something interesting about the ABC's priorities that it wants to rebroadcast the lowlights of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras at 8.30 on a Sunday night, but that it puts question time on at 1 o'clock in the morning. The connections between the ABC and the ALP run very deep, and that should concern Australians, since we own the ABC. Much of what the ABC does is commendable. Many of us spend a lot of time watching the ABC. I reckon I get my 9c worth a day. But we ought to be concerned to ensure that, firstly, it is independent, and, secondly, that it does not get too carried away by some people who want to push agendas such as the televising of the particular event I was just talking about.

It also should concern Australians that this country is run by the ALP, with many of its union mates calling the shots. The Cooke inquiry in Queensland exposed the backroom deals and highly questionable behaviour that are commonplace in the trade union movement and in the Labor Party. The New South Wales right wing, in particular, is running the country from Canberra, and that is the reason that the honourable member for Canberra remains as Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.

That observation brings me back to my starting point. The minister is part of the royal family which is headed by Emperor Keating. It is obvious to us—and, I am sure, to everyone on the other side of the House—that that is the reason that she is still in her position today. She and her activities as minister stand as a dreadful indictment of the way the Labor Party runs this country: on the basis of patronage and of vote buying and, ultimately, of what one can only regard as being extreme political corruption.

If the sports rorts affair has done nothing other than to make that fact obvious to every Australian, then the minister has done us a great service because, to all Australians, obvious it has now become. In the context of the general remarks I have made in this debate, I would like to sum up by saying that many people despair of the way the fabric of our society is being shredded at the moment by the Labor Party and by this government. I hope that the next election, which may be as long as a couple of years away, will not be too late for the people of Australia to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the previous speaker, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), I will deal with realities rather than theoretical rubbish that I think he spoke of. I would like to draw to the attention of this House the recently announced strategies for growth in Australian horticulture by the federal government's horticultural task force. Whilst talking about the merits of this report, I would also like to take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the House the positive growth and direction that have been taken by the primary industry groups in Tasmania and, more particularly, in the Huon and Channel regions in my electorate of Franklin.

PARA.TAB: The report of the horticultural task force has been forwarded to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) for his consideration. The task force was established in response to the Industry Commission inquiry into horticulture and was asked to develop an export growth strategy for the horticultural industry. This export growth strategy was based on the ongoing work of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation and the Horticultural Policy Council.

The report of the horticultural task force impacts upon industries within the southern part of my electorate, namely, the apple and pear industry, the small fruit industry, the wine industry, the stone fruit industry and the fertiliser industry. On 30 November last year I arranged for the horticultural task force to meet with representatives of these industries, with a view to the task force familiarising itself with the specific concerns of this region and for those concerns to be put to the task force directly by industry representatives themselves. I would like to take this opportunity to report to the House what this horticultural task force found when it visited these industries in the Huon and Channel area of Tasmania and the consequent report by the horticultural task force in relation to these specific industries.

The first stop on the task force itinerary was an establishment called Tascrays, a seafood catch and processing industry which has diversified into fertiliser products. The fertiliser developed by Tascrays is rather unusual in that it incorporates fish waste in combination with forest waste—mostly chips and bark—mulching this into what can only be described as a superb compost. This fertiliser, named OR-90, is currently being trialled by different sections of the horticultural industry, including the apple and pear industry and the Department of Transport and Works roadside planting division.

This compost, made completely from primary industry waste, has the wonderful capacity to not only promote tremendous growth but to also balance the pH levels in poor soils common to this area. The Huon Valley suffers badly from acidic soils, and currently the orchardists use sulfates, phosphates and nitrates as fertilisers and are dependent then on using lime to neutralise the acid content of their soils.

Following the closure of Benders Quarry—a rather contentious subject in my electorate—local farmers lost their local and reasonably cheap supply of lime. Although at that stage I was not in agreement with the closure of Benders Quarry, the closure is now a fact of life.

Local orchardists do have a continuing problem with their acidic soils, so methods must be found to solve those problems. The cost of lime to orchardists has increased due to the transportation costs involved in moving the lime from the only area available at present, which is in the north of the state.

When faced with problems like these, sometimes it is necessary to not just look at solving the problem by replacing what has been lost but to look at other methods that may be used to reduce dependence on certain commodities such as lime. I see my role as one of instigating avenues for research into alternatives for the reduced use of lime by orchardists, and I am hopeful that the compost produced from seafood and forestry waste may just be that alternative.

I must add here that the state Liberal government and the Minister for Primary Industry, the former Premier, Robin Gray, have been sitting on their hands on this issue. They must come on board to help solve the problem of acidic soils and the supply of lime. It is not just a case of the federal government picking up and running with the issue. It is a matter for state and Commonwealth cooperation.

It is no longer the time to attack the federal government over its closure of the Benders Pty Ltd quarry. As I said previously, the quarry is closed and that is that. We must now work together to solve this problem so that our horticultural industry can prosper and develop further.

The next stop on the itinerary for the task force was to visit representatives of the stone fruit industry of Tasmania. This industry is in a very positive position for growth, following a number of years of decline. Although, currently, the industry is only able to supply mostly domestic markets, its sights, like those of many other industries in Tasmania, are set on the South-East Asian region.

Tasmanian primary producers have enthusiastically taken up the message of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Australian industry about focusing on our region for trade. The stone fruit industry in Tasmania is in an ideal position to target Asian markets due to a number of factors, including its fruit-fly free status and its clean green image. In addition, there are no codling moths in the orchards. If this were properly recognised by markets in Japan it would be an added bonus to the industry.

Demand certainly outstrips supply in the stone fruit industry. The industry is now set to grow markedly. I note in the report by the horticultural task force that the transportation of horticultural products is now critical to the development of this industry. The task force, in one of its many recommendations, said that a technical committee should be established involving airfreighting providers and users to identify trends that will impact upon the availability and cost of airfreight for horticultural products, and to develop programs that ensure the cost-effective and reliable utilisation of airfreight by horticulture.

Recommendations on handling methods and training schemes for airline staff need to be implemented quickly so that groups such as the stone fruit industry can be confident when their precious cargo is flown to export markets. If these recommendations are implemented soon, the Tasmanian stone fruit industry will be well placed for export expansion at this time when the industry is in a growth phase.

It was interesting to note this morning that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) mentioned in his speech that the transportation of goods is a problem and one which he feels has not been adequately addressed. If he is aware of any specific problems, he should immediately take up those concerns with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I can assure the honourable member that his problem will be quickly addressed.

Last year we had the situation where a Tasmanian shellfish exporter had extreme difficulties with airfreighting his products to Japan. I immediately contacted the then Minister for Transport and Communications, now Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, about this problem. Following my representations, new procedures were introduced within Qantas to solve the problem that beset the Tasmanian shellfish company. These changes and procedures will now benefit all companies around Australia. I implore the honourable member for Wakefield to come forward with details of his concerns over the transportation of primary industry goods because they can and will be solved.

Many honourable members would already be aware of the fine wines produced in Tasmania. During its visit to southern Tasmania the horticultural task force visited the Elsewhere Vineyard. Representatives of the wine industry had the opportunity to put forward the views of some of the wineries, such as D'Entrecasteaux, Hartzview and Elsewhere. Concerns over the recent federal budget decisions were mentioned, and there were rather frank and fruitful discussions.

It is my belief that, when the industry has a difference of opinion over government decisions, the best way to find solutions to these types of problems is to see the industry directly involved. To that extent, I see myself as a conduit between the industry and the ministers responsible. The local wineries were particularly concerned with land use and the influx of residents buying out small parcels of land, thereby causing a rise in prices and having other implications that impacted on their industry.

I am pleased to note that the horticultural task force has responded to that concern by recommending that the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council develop regional approaches to structural adjustment in the horticultural industries, utilising interest subsidies, re-establishment grants and land trading to restructure production in regions where property sizes are too small to be viable. Consideration also needs to be given to providing funds directly from the Commonwealth through appropriate regional organisations, including private agricultural firms, farm organisations or local government, to farmers and farming groups.

The apple and pear industry in the Huon region is one which I am very close to and one with which I intend continuing a close working relationship. The apple and pear industry in the Huon is a very progressive group aggressively marketing its products into the Asian region. Unlike its mainland counterparts, its industry is export driven. The Huon apple and pear growers are leading the nation in this regard. The Huon region is unlike any other in Australia. It has particular qualities, and fortunately those qualities are what Asian buyers are looking for. The climate in the Huon ensures a particular type of apple, one with a hard skin and crisp bite.

The Tasmania Apple and Pear Growers Association has had difficulty in getting value for money through its relationship with the Australian Horticultural Commission. This is primarily due to its export drive and its specific regional qualities. These concerns have been taken on board by the horticultural task force and I am pleased to see that the task force has recommended that the Australian Horticultural Commission continue to review its operations to enable it to operate flexibly in order to meet the diverse needs of different commodity groups, particularly in relation to the need to place an increased focus on export market developments.

Here I would like to pay tribute to the President of the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Growers Association, Mr Tim Reid, who has shown the kind of leadership that is required in the modern world to promote the industry he represents. There will be continuing good news from this group in relation to export dollars and an increase in local jobs. I expect some further major announcements in relation to this in the near future. The Huon and Channel region is showing excellent prospects for economic and employment growth and has set in place the type of structural change that is required to propel itself into further export growth.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to Senator Nick Sherry, the chairperson of the horticultural task force, for his hard and dedicated work. Senator Sherry has effectively, through the report of the horticultural task force, assisted the industry in the Huon and Channel region to set itself up ready for the turn of the century and beyond.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak this afternoon about the problems the townspeople of Wilcannia are experiencing. It is a town which has been in the news a lot lately and received nationwide publicity a month or two ago after some outbreaks of violence in the town.

PARA.TAB: Before doing so, I would like to set the scene. Wilcannia is a town in western New South Wales, is based on the pastoral wool industry in a fairly arid area and is situated on the Darling River, 250 kilometres west of Cobar and about 200 kilometres east of Broken Hill. It contains some very beautiful sandstone buildings, including the post office, the police house and the court house. There are other sandstone buildings which have been abandoned and are derelict.

Once upon a time Wilcannia was known as the Queen of the West. It was one of the biggest inland ports, if not the biggest, in Australia. Wool was loaded onto the paddle-steamers that went down the Darling. Today most shops have been either closed or abandoned. Every shop in town, I think, is up for sale but one could not sell any of the shops; in fact, people cannot even give them away. The two main shops left are the main corner store, the grocery shop, and also the service station, and both of those are in danger of closing in the coming months. Incidentally, I bought petrol in Wilcannia the other day and paid 89.9c a litre, which contrasted rather markedly with the 54.9c a litre I paid in Sydney some time ago, a 35c a litre difference. That is something that country people have to put up with which city people forget about.

When one drives into Wilcannia, one sees Aborigines scattered around the town. Children will be hanging around street corners, and it seems to be immaterial whether school is on or not, and also a number of adults. There is very high unemployment amongst the Aboriginal people in Wilcannia, in excess of 95 per cent. These sorts of problems have been present to one degree or another for decades, but I believe the position has worsened considerably over the last 20 years. There is a fear in this town that if something is not done soon the town will close and, regrettably, it will end up as nothing much more than a glorified Aboriginal mission.

The town has been torn apart in recent times by violence and vandalism aggravated by alcohol abuse. It has driven many fine citizens out of the town, both black and white. Every business, as I say, is up for sale and for many the situation is one of despair, and they feel nobody is interested. I believe that violence combined with alcoholism amongst the Aboriginal people on the scale that I alluded to is a relatively recent phenomenon in Australia and reflects many things, such as the disillusionment building up over time, and drug abuse creeping in. No-one in Australia knows yet how to deal with this problem, and the difficulty is that it is usually situated in small isolated towns, far from the big cities; Wilcannia is 1,000 kilometres from Sydney. It has been ignored largely. Nobody is particularly interested in it, but to solve the problem is going to need a lot of time and thought given by the best available people that we have in this country. There has to be a recognition that we have to do something about this problem. It has to have a special focus of attention and patience is going to be needed.

I say to the House that time and effort expended in this area, though a considerable effort may be needed, will be well worth while because, if we can find a solution to help the Aboriginal people and help these towns, it will provide a blueprint for application elsewhere. I cannot overemphasise the magnitude and seriousness of the problem that exists not just in Wilcannia today but in Bourke tomorrow and Brewarrina the day after, and it is even building up in larger centres like Wellington and Dubbo. Nearly all of those towns, of course, are in my electorate.

I believe that any effort toward success, if it can be achieved, will be repaid a thousandfold, because we will not be just saving a town or towns. If we walk away from this problem, we are condemning a race of people to oblivion, and I believe that Wilcannia today offers the challenge. Crunch time has arrived for a decision to do something about this. If the problem is allowed to drift, if we just continue to salve our conscience by sending an extra policeman to the town or another social worker or whatever, as important as these things may be, we are avoiding our responsibility and the problem will continue and worsen.

Before I offer solutions, I would like to examine the situation in a little further detail. As I say, unemployment in the Aboriginal population is over 95 per cent. There is a lower education standard amongst Aboriginal people than I believe there needs to be. There is almost total loss of tribal elder authority, which I find very sad. The Aborigines in that town own virtually nothing. They do not own any business at all. They hardly own a house between them; the houses they live in are rented.

All those things added together are the ingredients for a cauldron of trouble, disillusionment, despair and apathy. There are no meaningful pursuits for people to occupy their time. It is bad enough not having a job in, say, Sydney or Melbourne, but people without a job can occupy themselves in other ways. They can join various organisations, go to the beach or play sport, but unemployed people do not have most of those options in Wilcannia.

Let us look at what it does to Aboriginal youth. There is a very high truancy rate in Wilcannia as well as a drinking problem and petrol sniffing, and I believe that drugs alarmingly are creeping into the town. Then there is every degree of mischief available, from the milder types of vandalism to the more serious break-ins, and thieving in houses, shops and of cars right through to violent assault, which is a fairly new phenomenon. In one case recently a teenage youth belted a person staying at the caravan park over the head with a tree root just to steal a few dollars. The person who got belted over the head was in hospital in a coma for some months. These youth problems seem to start from about 12 to 13 years on. When they are combined with poor education and the fact that many of these children are subject to sexual abuse and that we are about to breed another generation without work—probably the second or third generation—we can see that the problem is very serious indeed.

As I said, the adults have no jobs, and there is no incentive amongst the Aboriginal people to self-start with jobs because welfare, as we know, is fairly easy to get. Of course, all this ultimately leads to a lack of pride, a lack of purpose and a loss of dignity amongst these people. They soon drift into alcoholism which becomes entrenched and they end up with a total loss of self-respect. Amongst some Aboriginal people this breeds a resentment mentality. They end up with a chip on their shoulder against the law, against society as a whole and against history, some of which seems to be being rewritten for them. They end up with a negative outlook and with a `don't care' attitude. Their health suffers.
