PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The blatant maladministration and biased disbursement of grants under the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this debate was adjourned for question time I was talking about some of the regional tourism strategies that have been developed and particularly how they will benefit the south-east region of New South Wales and the ACT. I might also mention some other great benefits that have occurred from government policy. Two or three nights ago, I unveiled a plaque at the Eden swimming pool. Honourable members would never have guessed that the extension to the swimming pool was built with funds provided by the sporting grants. I will just briefly mention those grants because they were an important part of the appropriations in previous budgets. I strongly support the moves made by the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) within the government party to continue those sporting grants. They have benefited a number of towns—Eden, Narooma, Bungendore and Cooma. These towns have taken advantage of the grants.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a couple of points about issues that were raised by honourable members opposite—that these grants were not allocated on the basis of issues such as equity and fairness. A number of honourable members raised the fact that in their electorates there was a greater proportion of poor people. When one looks at the electorates, certainly from an income point of view, their electorates do show a lower average income. If I look at my own electorate, for instance, the people of Queanbeyan have a much higher average income than the people of Bombala, which is a rural area. But on the other hand—the ABS statistics do not show this—if we were able to look at the comparative assets of the areas then we would find that the people in Bombala have a higher level of assets on average than the people in Queanbeyan. When we look at the two areas we find more poverty in Queanbeyan. That does not mean that Bombala is a wealthy area nor does it mean that it should not be eligible for grants.

I think it is fallacious for honourable members such as the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) to talk about their electorates as if they were the poorest. They may be the poorest in income, but certainly they are not the poorest by any means in assets. In fact, when I go around the electorate of Eden-Monaro the only complaints I hear about the sporting grants are from people that did not get them.

I got far less allocation, for instance, than the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) did, and I am supposed to hold a marginal Labor seat. I got less than the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). I got less than the Treasurer (Mr Willis), who does not have a marginal Labor seat. So I do not believe for one minute that the allocation was on the basis of marginality; I believe it was substantially on the basis of need. The only criticism that I have, and it is the same as the criticism of the Auditor-General, is that records should have been kept. I felt that the way grants were allocated on previous occasions, where priorities were given and honourable members were allowed to comment, was a good basis. Certainly, I go no further than the Auditor-General, in fact I would agree with him that there is no evidence of political bias and no evidence of fraud.

On the subject of employment, which is another important issue: there have been calls, especially from some of the social service organisations and from this side of the House, that the government ought to consider a jobs levy to solve the unemployment problem, particularly the problem of long-term unemployment. Rather than do that, we ought to learn a lesson from what happened in December when there were substantial income tax cuts for a number of people, and confidence in the community started to turn in favour of a growth economy. People started to believe that the economy was growing because there was more money to spend on the needs that people had had for sometime. They found they had more money. I believe that the tax incentives from lower taxation had a dramatic effect on the economy, on consumer confidence and on business confidence.

I call on the government to look at tax incentives rather than at a jobs levy, as the tax incentives are associated with the recovery that has already happened. For instance, the Department of Employment, Education and Training has its task force on management in Australia. We have had some micro-economic reforms in so far as workers are concerned, getting more productivity. So let us now look at management.

I am delighted that the department has a task force on management. The best of our managers are equivalent to the best in the world but the standard does drop somewhat, particularly in small business. I have tried to refer people to business enterprise centres in New South Wales—I congratulate the New South Wales government on the formation of those centres—but very often those people feel that they have nothing to learn. They say they know their trade pretty well and very often they do know their trade pretty well, but that does not always mean that they are good managers; nor does it mean that they are able to do the cash flows and look at the productivity of their enterprise in the way they should.

We need to develop an attitude to improve productivity. I believe we should start at school. A lot of people in small business are underemployed. I was in small business for 25 years and a lot of them are underemployed. If we are looking at productivity we ought to be looking at what is happening in small business. I look forward to the report from that task force on management.

I also commend a project, by Peter Morris of the south coast Business Enterprise Centre, on venture finance. He suggested that venture finance be provided to businesses by providing tax incentives to private enterprise to encourage them to invest in venture finance. I hope to talk on this at a later time, but I commend him for his suggestion which has gone to Treasury. I think it is a great suggestion. I also commend the Jones committee on long-term strategies, which is looking at alternatives. I believe we should look at tax incentives to encourage employment in areas where there are not high levels of employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and on the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program. I want to firstly read out an editorial which appeared in the Bendigo Advertiser this morning. It is entitled, `Do us a favour please, Ros'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Come on, Ros Kelly. Face the facts. You have been sprung and no amount of backsliding gibberish is going to hide the facts.

PARA.TAB: As Federal Sport Minister you displayed a disgraceful bias in the way you and your department handed out public money to so-called sporting groups.

SPEECH.PARA: This is editorial comment:

PARA.TAB: If the people of Bendigo had a Labor MP, you probably would have funded more of our projects.
In fact, the local Labor candidate at the time let it be known that organisations wanting sports grants should have gone through him rather than through the sitting Liberal MP Bruce Reid.

SPEECH.PARA: What a disgrace. The editorial continues:

PARA.TAB: Doling out public funds as political patronage is bad enough. But from a political perspective, it was not as bad as being caught. Your actions were naive in the extreme and contemptuous of convention.

In clinging desperately to your job, Mrs Kelly, you have become more than a figure of bumbling incompetence within the government. You now represent the dangerous arrogant strain of the Keating Government.
Paul Keating always had more than a healthy helping of personal arrogance with a contempt for public opinion.
But in Ros Kelly, his Government has a new focus of public loathing: a minister who even after she has been clearly, unquestionably caught out, refuses to pay the accepted price.
It is said Mrs Kelly, that you're a close personal friend of the Prime Minister and that Mr Keating has so far tried to shield his friend from the full impact of the Sports Rorts Affair.
But either you must resign now, or Paul Keating will have to carry an increasingly odorous albatross to the polls. You owe it to your friend and to us to quit in shame.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I raise this matter is that I have had personal experience of the campaign of political bias that was carried out under this program in my electorate. As you know, 66 per cent of the total funds under this program went to ALP seats. But that omits the amount of money that went to marginal seats, like the seat of my colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) and my seat—marginal seats which the ALP tried to win.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unsuccessfully.

—Unsuccessfully. But it did not stop the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) from saying what she did to representatives of the Bendigo Regional Recreation Board when they went to see her about an indoor swimming centre project. This indoor swimming centre had the support of the municipalities in Bendigo and the YMCA, and the Victorian state government had allocated $500,000 to the project. It had the broad support of all of the people in Bendigo; they wanted this indoor swimming centre. I gave it my absolute and utmost support.

PARA.TAB: But the minister came to Bendigo and met the Bendigo Regional Recreation Board on 4 March 1993 and told it that the Labor candidate, Mr Helper, was the person to see to obtain funds for the indoor swimming centre. Have you ever heard anything like that? It is an absolute disgrace. It is shameful. The advice to the Bendigo Regional Recreation Board was that the project met the criteria. We have already had evidence from the minister's own mouth that some of the projects that were funded were ineligible and did not meet the criteria.

Here we have a project that was supported by everyone in the Bendigo community, yet because of political interference and bias people were told by the minister to go and talk to Mr Helper, the Labor candidate, because he was the person to see. Not only do we have the minister saying it; we also have a statement in an editorial today in the Bendigo Advertiser that in fact—no ifs, no buts, no maybes; but in fact—the local Labor candidate at the time let it be known that organisations wanting sports grants should have gone through him rather than through the sitting member. There we have it, from both sides of the equation.

The minister probably gave the candidate the instructions to go out and tell people in sporting organisations: `You go and tell them that, if they do not deal through you, you will not get any money'. That is the sort of caper that they have been up to—political bias and collusion between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the minister and corruption of the electoral system. That is what we are talking about. I have absolutely no doubt in my mind that the Prime Minister went to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and said, `Here is $30 million. You go and buy me an election'. That is what it was all about. And every member on that side of the chamber over there was a party to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had their snouts in the trough.

—Yes. They were all a party to it—corruption of the electoral system. What they were doing was being a part of that. The Prime Minister was giving $30 million to this program and saying, `Go out and buy me an election win'. That is what it was all about. Then the minister had the gall to go to ALP candidates and tell them to tell the sporting organisations that they must deal through the ALP candidates. It is absolute corruption of our electoral system to use a program in that way. There was collusion between the ALP candidates trying to win marginal seats held by me and by the honourable member for Ballarat. I might add that we were not the only ones; there were others.

PARA.TAB: I have recently had correspondence and inquiry from the town of St Arnaud. The St Arnaud Council put an excellent submission to me. It fitted right into the environment, sport and territories portfolio. The project the town put up for funding was going to take care of an environmental problem and provide water resources to a golf course. Do honourable members think that would get up? I would have thought it had a pretty good show. In fact, the minister wrote back to me and thanked me for indicating my support for this project: `I will bear it in mind when I consider the allocation of funds under the program'. That is what she told me. What the project was doing was taking sewage effluent, treating it and then relaying that water onto a golf course. So it would have fixed two problems: it would have fixed an environment problem in the township of St Arnaud and it would have also provided much needed water resources to this golf course.

It put in an excellent submission. It was one that I supported. It was looking for $223,500, so it met the criteria of the program. The sum of $250,000 was the maximum amount that one could get. It had the support of the St Arnaud Golf Club. It had the support of the town of St Arnaud. It had the support of the neighbouring municipalities. What they were doing was seeking money for an environment and sport issue that fitted into two of the areas that this minister is responsible for.

They could have recycled that sewage water. It could have been spread on the golf course and St Arnaud would have had a magnificent golf course. The honourable member for Ballarat and I would have been pleased to have played at their opening. But, no, the minister did not see any value in that at all, because she was too busy looking at the marginal ALP seats and looking after the people on that side who all had their snouts in the trough and all had their handouts. She was looking at the Mackerras pendulum, ticking them all off as she went through the programs and saying, `Here's one. He needs a bit of help'. I understand that a private golf club did get some money. And guess where it was?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—In an ALP seat. It is quite remarkable. The corruption of the electoral system that has been carried out with the Prime Minister, the minister and the members of the government team in collusion is just so blatant. This is why they put up such a performance today. They cannot let the minister go because they have all been in it too. They have had their sticky little fingers right in the till. They cannot let her go.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister cannot let her go either, because the minute that he decides that the minister is going to go she will say, `Hang on, Prime Minister, you gave me $30 million to win an election. I won the election for you and now you're going to turn on me'. This is what we are talking about. This is the bare bones of it, the nitty-gritty: `Here is $30 million. Go out and buy an election win'. She did that all right. The Prime Minister cannot desert the minister, because she has the backing of every one of those members opposite, all of those people in those marginal seats who held their hands out and got some of that money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The re-election was bought.
—It was, absolutely.
—You got a little bit of it.

—I got money. I am not complaining about the money at all. What I am saying is that some of the projects which were funded were ineligible and they did not meet the criteria. The only reason they got the money was that they were in ALP marginal seats. The honourable member for Lyons knows that.
—That is not proven.
—Of course it is.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will not use his contribution as a chance to have a conversation with other members and other members will not interject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was being intimidated by the honourable member for Lyons. I have mentioned a couple of projects but one of them, which the St Arnaud Council put to me, was a most worthwhile submission on every point. It met everything that was required of it. It not only dealt with a serious environmental problem but it also was to the advantage of a sporting organisation. I would have thought that would have been right up the top of the list. But, regrettably no, it was not, and the minister funded other programs. I think the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Lavarch) had a program funded which was quite clearly ineligible. It did not meet the criteria and the minister admitted that in the House. I find it quite tragic that good projects which were put forward were discriminated against because of political bias.
—It was disgraceful.

—It was a disgraceful effort. It is quite obvious that not only were the ALP members of this House party to this; so also were the candidates. It is probable that the design of the program was meant to inform the Labor candidates that money was going to come into the electorate that they were standing for.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, I heard about the funding that was to come into my electorate from some other sources. I found out before the other candidate was able to be advised. I note the wry smile of the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns), who is at the table. He probably wonders how I got it. I can assure the assistant minister that I did find out before the other candidate. I had the pleasure of announcing all of these projects in the media. Of course, the ALP candidate then missed out on getting that.

Many of those worthwhile projects have now been completed. I am now having the pleasure of going around my electorate and opening these very worthwhile projects. I got $426,000 out of the program and I welcome every cent of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You worked hard.

—I worked hard and supported every one of those projects, as the honourable member for Moore says. They were all good projects. I supported more than the ones that were funded. I supported the golf course project from the town of St Arnaud which would have provided a very good answer to a serious environmental problem as well as providing water to a golf course.

PARA.TAB: The program was probably based on some fairly sound principles. It was one way of getting some money into sporting organisations. But the Auditor-General and the parliamentary committee have already found that the minister was deficient in her administration and kept no records except the whiteboard. What way is this for a government to run a program of that size? She was carrying around 2,800 applications. Is that why my golf course fell off the whiteboard? Did it simply get rubbed off the board before it got proper consideration or did she look at the Mackerras electoral pendulum and say, `No, that can't be funded. It is not a seat that we can put some money into'. It is absolutely blatant.

The Prime Minister has been right up to his neck in this. There is no doubt that he has been in collusion with the minister over the allocation and application of these funds for that program. It all went to ALP seats. It went to marginal seats where the ALP thought it could win the seats away from Liberal sitting members or National Party sitting members. We have already had evidence of that from members of the National Party.

We now know that the program was quite badly administered. No records were kept. Ineligible applications were funded. Projects that did not meet the criteria in any shape or form were funded by the minister. Good projects with massive community support, total community support did not get any funds at all, because they did not deal with the ALP and its candidates. It is as simple as that. It is absolutely straightforward, no question at all.

There was political bias in this program with 66 per cent of the total funds going to ALP seats. But that does not even mention the marginal seats that the ALP did not win. The total amount of money that was spent trying to hold the ALP seats and trying to win the other seats that were marginal would probably represent something like 70 per cent or more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty.

—It might be as high as 80, as the honourable member for Indi says. I think we need to do some more work on that. We need to have a look and see how much money went to marginal seats that the ALP did not win as well. It is quite clear to me and it is quite clear to everyone in Australia. That is why the very well respected Bendigo Advertiser, without fear or favour, wrote this editorial this morning. It is headed `Do us a favor please, Ros'. The final message was `. . . quit in shame'. These editorials are not written lightly. It states:

PARA.TAB: In fact, the local Labor candidate at the time let it be known that organisations wanting sports grants should have gone through him rather than through the sitting Liberal . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The minister even told people at a deputation that Mr Helper was the man to talk to about funding for the project. We had credible witnesses. The chairman of the—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) gives me an opportunity to speak on the subject of education, for which I have a great deal of feeling. We need to put more resources and effort into education in order to improve our overall education system in this country.
—Blackboards, not whiteboards.

—There has been a lot of talk about whiteboards and blackboards lately. We need more blackboards and whiteboards to improve our education system. I have been involved with literacy in Tasmania for many years in order to improve the lot of people seeking assistance in that area. I was President of the Tasmanian Literacy Council and a member of the International Year of Literacy Council in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: There are many ways for us to get on top of some of these problems, and I want to discuss these today. What can we do about this situation? Schools are still turning out people who are illiterate and who have numeracy problems, and we need to turn that around. The young people coming out of schools today with these difficulties are at risk of becoming the next prison population. The highest level of illiteracy in any population group in Australia today is in the prison population.

Nobody condones the breaking of laws, but anybody who has taken the time to get involved in assisting prison groups would know that there is always a reason for people being in prison. It often comes down to frustrations associated with unemployment, low self-esteem, lack of money, lack of family support or the inability to express oneself. There is a link between illiteracy and prison, and we should accept that and society should come to grips with it. These days young people are most likely to be unable to cope with the pressures of being illiterate. Having no education can result in people ending up in prison.

We need to allocate money and resources in areas which will address this problem. Let us look at the figures. The average cost of keeping somebody in prison for one year is $45,000. There are also costs involved prior to the person being convicted, such as the costs of police, the court, social welfare, vandalism and health. The cost of keeping a child at primary school for one year is $3,500. That is pretty efficient for most state bureaucracies today.

How does this relate to tackling the problem of illiteracy? If we could put money into improving basic education, literacy and numeracy difficulties of children at preschool, we would overcome many of the problems associated with people in prison. We should also continue to endeavour to lift the lot of those in prison with difficulties.

The difference in the cost of education of a primary school student and a secondary school student is $1,596 a year. That figure comes from the report of the national schools program, which was tabled in the parliament a couple of weeks ago. There is a critical need to close the gap with respect to cost between the primary education level and the secondary education level. If we achieve that in the next few years, then in 10 or 15 years time we will have cut down the prison population of Australia. But in order to take advantage of that great opportunity, we will need to provide our education system with not only money but also resources. We can decrease the illiteracy rate of prison populations in 10 or 15 years time if we are determined to put in the effort.

Those people in society who argue for more police, heavier penalties and longer terms in gaol for people who break laws should also be lobbying for more resources for our primary school system. If we target that system, we will end up keeping people out of prison. If we put money even into preschools, we will start to overcome some children's difficulties. If we can help the children in the school systems who are at risk, we will end up keeping people out of prison. We need to focus on that point and we need to make sure that the government does too.

Some schools operating today are taking a much more positive view of illiteracy and they are looking at it in a different way. They are endeavouring to come to grips with the problem. Some isolated schools are trying to help their children under great difficulty. We need to give them assistance. We also need to give assistance to our teachers, particularly our new teachers, who need to be trained to understand the direction that they should go in. As the state education departments are cutting back on teaching numbers, there are fewer teachers in our school system, which causes difficulties such as increased numbers of students per class. They are also cutting back on resources.

As I said, the cost of education at primary schools is $1,500 less than that at secondary schools, and this should be looked at. Most of the teachers at secondary schools are female, and many of them are younger females. They have little clout in the overall politics of education departments and they probably have little clout within their union to raise the issues of educational needs. So we have a section within our education system which is neglected and which needs assistance.

There is a need to act in the area of early childhood support. The government has set up a review, following the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Literacy challenge. The government will need to act on some of the recommendations resulting from that review. The government will need to have ministers who will take up the challenge to pursue that and it will also need a cabinet to give it support. I believe the government will need to get the states and the territories on side in order to pursue new policies and new ideas in this field. I believe that, by starting a program, we could eliminate illiteracy from Australia.

Some years ago the world took on the elimination of smallpox from the world. Through the World Health Organisation smallpox was eliminated. That was a great achievement. I am sure thousands of people dedicated themselves to achieving that goal. As a nation we could show the world what we can do with education in Australia, and we should endeavour to do that.

The formative years of young people—between grades 2 and 3—are critical. More and more evidence is coming forward to show that during and prior to these years children are at risk of not getting the basic skills and understanding of numeracy and literacy which they need. So it is this age group that we must focus on and which the government must focus on.

I do not believe it is just the federal government that needs to focus on this need. We have to make sure that every state and territory education department focuses on this need also and that their ministers are aware of the difficulties and tackle them in a positive way. They need to say, `This is a problem and we are going to tackle it'. Let us all put education for young people first. Let us change the prison population in 10 to 15 years by putting resources into education. Let us make sure that our children can read and write before they leave primary school. Later is too late.

I will now deal with an issue that many members of the House have raised during this debate and that is the issue of the family. I have been a little concerned that those opposite have endeavoured to define the family. I think it is very difficult for this parliament or any political party to come up with a definition of what is right or what is good as a family. Modern society is very diverse. I know of lots of different sorts of families. In the broader sense, a family consists of people who support each other in day-to-day life. That is very important and I would have thought that that is what being a family is about.

People from dysfunctional families and people who do not belong to a family structure or support group are the ones that have the most difficulties. When those people have a problem they have nobody to assist them and nobody to lean on. People without support systems, particularly young people, are those most at risk.

When we talk about the family we also need to talk about support for people who may not have traditional families. We need to continue to give support, which has been considerably lacking in the past, to homeless youths. I also believe that we should be positive about the family and family life whether it is traditional or not. I would define the family more broadly than those opposite. They seem to cling to the idea that Australian society is made up of families of mum and dad and two kids. Our statistics show us that that is not so and that our society is much broader. I rebut the idea of some of those opposite who blame this government for somehow changing the family. I do not believe that is true. I believe our society changes and governments have to come to grips with those changes and support those people who need it as a result of those changes.

As a relatively new member of this House, I would also like to comment on the speech made today by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I was appalled by that speech and appalled at the way he attacked somebody who is not a member of this House. I believe he brings only disrespect on this chamber and the Australian parliament by using that cheap political tactic. I condemn that action. In conclusion, I support the Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available I would like to refer to a greater problem than that of the Kelly affair in this parliament, and that is the waterfront strike in Sydney. Some 55 personnel are holding up the whole waterfront of Australia—every port around the country—because of an industrial dispute. Whilst we are excited to know that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) will be resigning some time in the future, I think all Australians are very concerned that the exporters, the miners and the farmers have been affected by the activities of one stevedoring union, the maritime union in Sydney, which has seen fit to renege on an agreement that was signed some 18 months ago.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the waterfront has been a major difficulty to exporters and all Australians over the last 25 years, it is fair to say that a lot of progress has been made on the waterfront because of mechanisation, changes in attitudes and, more particularly, reductions in the number of personnel. In 1985-86 there were 8,000 waterside workers around Australia in the various ports. In 1992-93 there are about 4,000 waterside workers conducting the same amount of activity and obviously doing it a lot better with the aid of modern mechanical equipment, containerisation and cranes. The bulk commodity area has historically worked very well apart from the intransigence of the unions.

We have made a bit of progress in this regard. This government has even made a little bit of progress although it is not as much as the ministers would have us believe. We have this very unfortunate and, in my view, critical situation with the monopoly by the stevedores in the Maritime Union of Australia, as it is called; it is no longer the wharfies union. They have a more respectable name but obviously they have maintained the same attitudes.

Fundamentally, the dispute revolves around the redundancy of 55 waterside workers who are part of a union, who entered into an enterprise agreement under which the job for life attitude that has been endemic on the waterfront would be removed and those waterfront workers who were no longer required could be declared redundant.

I clearly indicate to the House that on 28 March 1994 the Brereton industrial relations proposals will come into effect. What the government and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) would have us believe is that enterprise agreements under these new industrial relations arrangements will be of a first-class nature. But the reality is that the enterprise agreements are between the management of any particular company or firm and the union involved. In this case, with a long tradition of union domination and union monopoly on the waterfront, these enterprise agreements are between the union and National Terminals (Australia), which is a stevedoring company.

The fundamental point I wish to make is that industrial relations in Australia will change after 28 March. If the minister does not bring forward the proclamation of the new industrial relations, when these laws come into effect it will be more difficult to put personnel off. I think that is very clear; greater procedures will have to be undertaken to remove people from the work force. In light of these events, 55 people at Sydney have seen fit to hold up what is going on and renege on an agreement that was entered into in good faith.

On 1 November 1992, National Terminals entered into an agreement with the Maritime Union in good faith. It resulted in long discussions with the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, WIRA, which is well known to members of this House and people associated with the waterfront. Of course, all honourable members of the House would be aware that employment on the waterfront was for life—having a brother, father or a son on the waterfront was the only way to enter that particular mode of employment and once a person got the job he would be there forever no matter what his performance was like. In addressing the issue of employment security—nice words for jobs for life—WIRA, in its final report dated October 1992, made this suggestion:

SPEECH.PARA: Commitments to employment security contained in Clause 8 were honoured during the period of the IPA—
that is, the interim arrangements—
In the Review discussions the Parties agreed that Future Employment Arrangements including employment security are matters for negotiation between individual employers and unions.

Quite clearly, everyone had agreed that there was scope for negotiation to solve this problem of there being too many people on the waterfront. Whilst there had been great strides in reducing personnel numbers from 8,000 to 4,000, it was obvious a few more should go.

PARA.TAB: Subsequent to that report, Australian Stevedores entered into a retirement and redundancy agreement effective from 1 November 1992. It was signed by John Coombs on behalf of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, which has since merged into the Maritime Union of Australia. That agreement was signed and both sides understood the impact of the arrangements—that this very touchy subject of redundancy and reducing the work force would be addressed in a negotiating style and that both parties would hopefully benefit.
Under section (f) of that agreement, a company has the right to declare a redundancy situation and to call for volunteers from the employees. The agreement says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event that sufficient volunteers are not forthcoming as a result of the application of the above procedures, the Company, the Unions and employees shall confer prior to the Company commencing required retrenchments.

It is quite clear what was agreed to. I think arrangements were reached after extensive negotiation. It is worth noting that during this period the company sought volunteers, paying more than $22 million to 282 volunteers. That is almost $100,000 per man. That has been the sort of payout, depending on the entitlements, made to the waterfront volunteers involved. They have come out of it very well.

PARA.TAB: Given that background and given the spirit of the stevedoring company, one would have thought that the union could have negotiated a further arrangement. But that was not to be the case. The 55 members of the union maintained their position and they said that they wanted to have their jobs back at any price. It is worth noting that ports around the rest of Australia, as I understand it, have agreed to these terms and conditions, have negotiated contracts and have agreed to changes in work practices—which is essential to the outcome of improving waterfront efficiency. These changes include using updated equipment and generally improving output to try to make Australia, as an exporting nation, somewhere near world standards in terms of moving containers quickly, getting a quicker turnaround of vessels and generally cleaning up our waterfront.
Members of one particular group of the Maritime Union are now saying that they will renege on an agreement which was signed by their secretary and agreed to by everyone, and

SPEECH.PARA: that they are going hold up the whole of Australia. I think this is a total disaster for the Australian economy and for the waterfront in particular. It means that we are seeing a test run of the sort of problem that I predict will happen under the new so-called enterprise agreements put forward by Minister Brereton. When the real pressure comes on in relation to redundancies and sacking people because of changed circumstances under the new arrangements it is going to be much more difficult. We are seeing a bit of a test run on the waterfront, where it was agreed to make these changes, to gradually reduce the work force and to allow a more productive arrangement. With only two stevedoring companies and one union on the waterfront now, there is still a lack of competition, in a genuine sense, between the stevedoring companies and the monopoly position of the union members themselves.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the House have been advocating that genuine enterprise agreements be instituted. That is what we advocated at the last election and we have not moved away from that position one bit. We believe that the real malaise on the Australian waterfront has been this lack of a genuine enterprise agreement between the management—in this case, Stevedores—and the waterfront workers. We have fundamentally agreed to this position. We have advocated it and the government has, after a lot of discussion, held a number of inquiries—I understand there have been 20 inquiries into the waterfront since the 1930s—trying to overcome this problem of permanency of tenure and, of course, the waterfront practices which are legend in the Australian work force.

I place on record my concern on behalf of the farmers, the exporters and the importers that a union of 55 personnel could hold up the whole Australian waterfront at a cost of millions of dollars per day, particularly in Sydney, by reneging on a contract that had been agreed to. I would hope there would be some sense of responsibility. I understand that today there is great bitterness at the waterfront, that pickets are being held strongly and that the men are concerned about the arguments. I place on record my concern on behalf of a number of my constituents and the exporters that such a small number of people would renege on a very important agreement after five to eight to years of discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Australian Stevedores who have done it.

—It is the union that has reneged on the agreement, not the employers. The employers have been negotiating for the last 12 months, as the honourable member for Gilmore would understand. They have been negotiating in good faith to establish terms and conditions that are acceptable. It has been achieved in the port of Geelong, as the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) would understand, where there is a good set of relationships between the employers and the personnel working on the waterfront. I leave my remarks with the House and hope that by tomorrow the matter might be resolved and, in the longer term, more harmonious industrial relations will return to the Australian waterfront.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Johns) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Johns) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) recently announced a $1 million boost to backpacker tourism. This is a welcome initiative to this industry, which is worth about $1.5 billion to the Australian economy. In November last year I raised the issue that backpackers to this country have a right to expect proper conditions and standards of fire safety in accommodation and that in a significant number of cases they are not getting it. I pointed out that state governments and local councils have allowed too many defective establishments to continue trading. Not only is this putting people's lives at risk; it is giving the industry a bad name and damaging Australia's tourist reputation.

PARA.TAB: Since that time I have received support from the New South Wales Backpacker Operators Association, individual operators and a number of individuals who have been subject to the appalling conditions in some of the hostels. There has been an angry response from a number of authorities who seem more interested in defending their pride than addressing the fire problems that exist.

I have also been subject to what I regard as a campaign of intimidation by the owners of at least two hostels with defective fire standards. That campaign has consisted so far of a major article in the Australian newspaper character assassinating me, a writ for defamation—but not to the media outlet on which the supposed defamatory remarks were broadcast—and a political campaign through North Sydney Council. The writ is designed to buy time.

The reason for this campaign is obviously to avoid spending some hundreds of thousands of dollars on fire protection. It now turns out that one of these hostels at 41 Cremorne Road in my electorate has been for sale for some time for $3.5 million. Every effort has obviously been made to sell before proper fire orders are issued. A tame North Sydney Council has aided and abetted this by delay and by largely ignoring the recommendations of the New South Wales Fire Brigade. The brigade specifically warned the council that deletion of any of its recommendations could prove detrimental to the overall fire safety of the buildings. Yet the council has watered this down on the pretext that the building is not a backpackers hostel but houses 90 low-income North Sydney residents, ignoring evidence to the contrary.

Frankly, the council should be severely censured for incompetence at best, and exposing its ratepayers to the risk of massive insurance claims, particularly with North Sydney's history of a death in the same area from fire some years ago as well as the tragic Luna Park fire. While social and economic factors must be considered in applying fire regulations to existing buildings, there is no case for compromising public safety in tourist facilities. Alternative accommodation is readily available.

The article in the Australian was a classic piece of intimidatory character assassination and a defence of backpacker accommodation at the Excelsior Hotel in Sydney. I thought it unusual at the time that a national newspaper would bother with such a subject, until it was revealed that the ownership of the hotel was the same as that of the hostel at Cremorne. While I do not believe the journalist P. P. McGuinness was acting on behalf of the owners' commercial interests, the effect was the same and I believe interests associated with the hotel approached him.

I have a 30-year history of very direct involvement in the problem of building fire safety. To be accused of cowardice, ratbaggery, hypocrisy, lack of integrity and irresponsibility by a national newspaper for raising the serious issue of inadequate fire standards in tourist accommodation is a misuse of the power of the press, especially when such intimidation happens to be of financial assistance to the owners trying to avoid fire regulations. These regulations may be unduly onerous in the newspaper's view, but they are the law and must be applied equally.

I believe I have a record of responsible use of parliamentary privilege over the last 12 years. I have not named any of the owners of backpacker hostels and I do not do so now. The issue is public safety and the slowness and lack of enforcement by the responsible authorities. State fire authorities must ensure that proper fire standards are implemented. In New South Wales there needs to be a revision of administrative procedures. The split responsibility between state and local authorities is not working. This issue will become even more important with the influx of tourists for the Olympic Games.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the honourable member for Fraser raised two issues of privilege concerning the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. The honourable member later made a further statement qualifying his earlier remarks. The first matter concerned articles in several newspapers this morning which referred to a draft report of the committee and which, the honourable member said, purported to reveal conclusions reached by the committee. The honourable member said that the committee had considered these matters at length at a meeting this morning and had concluded that the publication of the material had caused substantial interference with the work of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Photocopies of articles in the Canberra Times, the Australian, the Australian Financial Review and the Age of today's date were subsequently provided to me. The committee has followed the procedure established by my predecessor in these matters in that it has considered whether substantial interference had occurred. I certainly accept for present purposes the committee's conclusion on this.

The second requirement set out by my predecessor was, however, that in such circumstances the committees in question should take steps to ascertain the source of any apparent disclosure. I am willing to allow precedence to a motion on this matter, although before a motion is moved I believe the committee itself should take whatever steps it can to ascertain the sources.

The second complaint the honourable member mentioned concerned remarks reportedly made on the AM program by the honourable member for Pearce. The honourable member for Fraser said the committee was of the opinion that the views expressed by the honourable member for Pearce constituted a further substantial interference with the committee's work. A copy of a transcript of the relevant segment of AM was subsequently provided to me.

I have examined this transcript. It is clear that the honourable member for Pearce took part in an interview concerning matters currently before the committee and presumably to be dealt with in the report, and it is clear that she expressed views on the issues involved. Although it seems the person interviewing the honourable member had some knowledge of the contents of the draft report, having read a transcript of the remarks of the honourable member for Pearce it is not clear to me that she did in fact disclose either private deliberations of the committee or the contents of the draft report. On the information before me, I do not find that a prima facie case has been made out on that point, so I would not allow precedence to a motion.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to some comments made in this place yesterday by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) on both a speech I made in the House yesterday and a paper that I have circulated very recently regarding industry policy. I want to reassure the honourable member that I have not deviated from the true path as far as he thinks and also disagree with him on a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member suggested in his speech, which I read subsequently, that the Australian textile, clothing and footwear industry is as efficient as similar organisations in the rest of the OECD. Surprisingly enough, the honourable member quoted a study by John Matthews and Linda Weiss elsewhere in his speech which clearly indicates that that is not the case and gives fairly substantial evidence as to why the textile industry in Australia is struggling. So I disagree with him on that point. I suggest to the honourable member that there is little future in this country for certain types of manufacturing in that industry, particularly those focusing on long runs with low quality and competing on low costs, but there is considerable potential in many areas of the industry and that potential is starting to be realised.

Members of my family in the Brunswick area were involved in the clothing industry for almost 100 years up until about three years ago. The type of clothing that they were involved with was essentially low quality, high production run items. Effectively, the factory that they worked in ended up closing essentially because of the nature of the product that they were producing. There is very little future for Australia producing that type of product, irrespective of things like tariff walls, government assistance and the like, but there is a considerable future in other areas of clothing manufacture as an example.

Contrary to what the honourable member for Wills said, I do not agree with the notion that competitive advantage is effectively a fairly static concept. He criticised me in his speech for suggesting that I almost seem to be accepting the neo-classical position on this issue. I specifically criticised the neo-classical economists on that issue from precisely the same standpoint of the honourable member for Wills.

I refer him to my paper where I pointed out a fairly striking performance on the part of the World Bank, which has historically been dominated by people who take the neo-classical view. The World Bank in 1987 described the South Korean steel industry as arguably the most efficient steel producer in the world, yet in the early 1970s the same World Bank had refused loans to South Korea for steel production on the basis that South Korea had no competitive advantage in steel.

I should also say to the honourable member for Wills that I did not, in his terms, cast a shadow over interventionism. I want sophisticated intervention into economic activity. I was arguing against some of the more crude forms of interventionist proposals that historically have come from, amongst other sections of the political spectrum, the Left in this country. Therefore, I agree with him that sectoral policy is significant. I did not, as he suggests, support the notion of international competitiveness without sectoral policy. I support sectoral policy, but the question is: what sectoral policy? What is the policy going to be?

The honourable member seems to have some problems with my reference to the Left being instinctively interventionist. I was simply describing what I see to be fact: that the Left position has always been interventionist and that there is now something of a theoretical problem in the left because of internationalisation. Our interventionism has essentially been based on assumptions about Australia's ability to control economic activity within its borders that are no longer totally correct because of the internationalisation of economic activity across the globe.

The final point I make is that the references I have made to issues such as import replacement and government purchasing have perhaps been not fully understood by the honourable member for Wills, although I would accept that there is still disagreement between us on these issues. My basic position on these issues is that an indiscriminate approach in areas like that is of no great benefit to the Australian economy and may in fact be harmful whereas a discriminating and targeted approach can be of considerable value.

If we have a particular industry sector which either is internationally competitive or has reasonable prospects of being internationally competitive, then underpinning an industry strategy in that area with particular forms of import replacement or government purchasing mechanisms is of considerable value. The key questions are: what imports are we going to replace and what products is the government going to purchase? I therefore reject an indiscriminate strategy in those areas, not the use of those techniques. I am suggesting that they could be used in a much more sophisticated way as part of broader interventionist industry policy strategies. There have been examples such as the purchase of software by the Taxation Office, which occurred only as a result of industrial action being taken by the PSU. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time, this House honours certain people. Tonight we honour Ian Sinclair's 30 years in this place, which I think is a fitting tribute, but too often we forget other people within society who should be similarly honoured. Tonight I speak about George Thomas McLean, known by everybody as Captain Tom or Tom McLean, who is synonymous with the tourist industry right throughout Australia. Many honourable members here who have that genuine and deep interest in tourism would have known of him. Ninety-two years ago he came onto this earth and he departed just this time last week. I felt it was important that this House pay some tribute to him.

PARA.TAB: Tom McLean was born in the Rockhampton region at Mount Morgan in 1901. It is interesting to know that the area of Rockhampton, along with Mount Morgan, Yeppoon and Emu Park, has provided probably more of the real pioneering and building spirit, particularly in Queensland, than any other part of Australia. He was born at the mine site at Mount Morgan and his parents then went on to a farm near Yeppoon. The point I make is that he was `born' into Mount Morgan, and Mount Morgan is itself a centre of great history for BP. That was the company that took money away from Saudi Arabia and put it into the goldmine in Queensland. BP is known as the quiet achiever and that could also describe Tom McLean in certain ways.

Tom left the area of Rockhampton and came to the Mackay district. He knew what the difficulties of living were. He went through an economic depression and all of this, I believe, made him attuned to what people were really looking for and really wanted. He did not have the opportunity of an education, but I dare say that he had more commonsense, more nous, more business sense and more practicality built into his one body than the whole of this parliament with all of its academia. He was a simple person from a great generation of people who built this nation of ours.

It was said at his service that he was too young for the First World War and too old for the Second World War but that did not stop him participating. In fact, he joined the army. Only Tom would know the reasons he joined the army and later on he probably used those experiences to get money out of reluctant bankers and people like that.

It was during his service in New Guinea that he found his love for the sea and boats. In fact, at anchor in Port Moresby at the time he was working there was the Shangri La, a vessel used by Douglas MacArthur on his return to the Philippines. Tom was determined to own the vessel when he went back into civilian life. This he did. He bought the Shangri La and started a company by the name of Roylen—a name which became synonymous with tourism not only in the Mackay region and the Whitsundays but also elsewhere. He cobbled together the name from his son's and daughter's names—Fitzroy and Helen.

He was a very simple man, a man who did not have much of a brief for academics. He certainly had none for accountants or bankers. In fact, his belief was that the only reason accountants existed was that they received a percentage of a client's income tax for the year; he was absolutely certain of that. I could never prevail upon him, but he probably beat the system. Bankers, accountants and lawyers were the bane of his life because he was a practical person who did things. He did not do them with great flair. I suppose the highlight of Roylen Cruises was when he built on the fairmiles, which were the Second World War vessels.

Tom had about eight or nine vessels with which he opened up the Whitsundays. I am not saying that he was the person who created tourism in the Mackay district, but he did gain a respectability for those earlier pioneers like the Busuttins of Brampton and really built on an opportunity. I do not think he ever sought satisfaction in earning or owning money. His satisfaction was in seeing a thing to be done and doing it.

He had a brief political fling. He took the hardest of all seats, Bowen, which was held by a communist at one stage, but he did have that political interest. He had an interest in people. He was rewarded with the MBE and he was able to meet comfortably with royalty or anybody else. I pass on my condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent bushfires in New South Wales brought home to all Australians that certain summer reality that the threat of bushfire devastation is not far from us all as we enjoy what the summer has to offer. For Victorians like myself, it was a sharp reminder of that day roughly a decade ago when fire devastated our state on the now infamous Ash Wednesday. Watching graphic reports of the valiant efforts of professional and volunteer brigades to contain that recent disaster in New South Wales, one's admiration went out to those firefighters who risked their lives in defence of life and property. I felt a certain sense of pride in the fact that other states were prepared to commit human resources, capital equipment and expertise to fight the fires and limit the damage.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment briefly on the volunteer fire brigade force that formed the backbone of that effort. Volunteer firefighters are a rare breed. They spend considerable time in training for this important community task and they spend time, at considerable personal risk and emotional strain, fighting fires. However, time is not all these people give to their communities. The volunteer emergency work and training they perform may involve financial loss as well. There is always a cost involved in these commitments. For many volunteer firefighters, it might well be an opportunity forgone to work additional hours or to take on a part-time job to supplement the family income.

Clearly, communities benefit from their volunteer firefighters. Many communities would not be able to afford to maintain a professional firefighting presence in their areas to cope with complex emergency situations which occur in industrial and residential communities. But, given the risk and the time commitment involved for volunteers, it is becoming increasingly difficult for communities to retain and recruit new ones. It is time perhaps that we consider modes of compensation that say to experienced and dedicated volunteers that we really do appreciate their efforts on our behalf.

An interesting proposition has been put to me by one of my constituents, Mr Royce Collier of Portarlington, who has recently retired after years of dedicated service to the Victorian volunteer fire brigade and to his national administrative body. He has put the proposal not for himself but to strengthen and nurture the volunteer force that he has unselfishly committed himself to down through the years. He has proposed that the community consider a sliding scale, long-service awards program that would financially reward volunteers with over 10 years of committed service to the movement.

At present, the average length of service of volunteer firefighters in Australia is 7 1/2 years. If this could be extended to 10 years and beyond, the cost benefits to the community would be obvious. There would be obvious savings to the community in a reduced turnover of personnel and there would also be considerable savings in the use and maintenance of equipment by experienced personnel.

Such a scheme, which I understand operates in a similar mode in the USA, would retain valuable expertise in the volunteer force and be a powerful expression of the appreciation and gratitude of the community to these unsung heroes in our midst. It is a worthwhile proposition that I intend to take further and will explain further to the House at another time. I certainly thank Mr Collier for the time and the consideration he has put into this proposal on behalf of his fellow volunteers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to inform the House of a few details of the recreational and sporting facilities program in Victoria and how the discredited Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has deceived many people. I would like to give an example of the sort of letter that she arranged to be written to people in my state who, in good faith, put their applications in thinking that they would be treated fairly and that the program would be administered fairly, efficiently and equitably. The letter from her department states:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your letter enclosing an application for funding through the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. The registration number for your application is—
and a number is given—

This number should be quoted in all correspondence concerning the application. It is expected that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories will advise all successful applicants of grant offers to be made by the Commonwealth government towards the end of 1992. All applicants will be advised in writing of the outcome of their application. Thank you for your interest in this program. Any queries in relation to the application may be directed to . . .

and there is a Canberra phone number. Thousands of people receive those letters. At the time they receive them, they think: that is good, we have been invited to put our application in. We have put it in in good faith and it appears we are eligible; certainly we are going to be considered. We have not been told that there is anything wrong, we are going to be treated fairly and equitably, and the program will be allocated in accordance with proper ministerial principles and accountability. Those organisations then received a letter in December 1992—most of them were in December, at least in my state. It went along these lines:
Dear Mr or Mrs, I refer to your application of—
whatever date it was in 1992, registration number so-and-so—

for assistance through the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program in 1992-93. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the Hon. Ros Kelly, has now announced successful applications for Victoria. One hundred and thirty-nine grants totalling $7,962,352 were offered in 1992-93. Over 2,800 applications for assistance in 1992-93 were received Australia-wide. Due to the limited funding available many eligible projects could not be supported. Unfortunately your application was unsuccessful on this occasion. Thank you for your interest in the Commonwealth government program. Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this in your electorate?

—Yes, in Victoria. There was a lot of disappointment; nevertheless, even at that stage, most country people accepted that the program had been administered fairly, allocated equitably and that ministerial responsibility had been observed. That is what they thought. Now we find that the story has unfolded. The Auditor-General has revealed his concern at the department's maladministration and failure to perform. The minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other ministers are now involved in a conspiracy to conceal the truth of their maladministration. All members of the community in Australia—not only those people who applied in good faith—can now see through the illusion that was created; they can see through it. It was a deliberate illusion to let people think that this program was going to be dealt with fairly. Now it is exposed for all the world to see. I conclude by putting to the House that the only difference between Tonya Harding, Michael Jackson and the minister is that some people think Tonya Harding and Michael Jackson are innocent.

—Mr Speaker, I rise to pay homage to some communities in my electorate and bordering on my electorate, one of which, the city of Wollongong, is very close to your heart. An agreement between the municipalities of Wollongong, Shellharbour, Kiama, the Illawarra Area Health Service and the World Health Organisation Collaborating Centre on Community Safety Promotion has been established. It is a program run by the World Health Organisation to recognise safe communities. It has been promoted world wide by the World Health Organisation as a strategy for communities to reduce injuries at local level.

PARA.TAB: The World Health Organisation has established 12 standards which form the basis of the safe communities program. Within the program there is a strong focus on greater intersectoral cooperation and community participation in promoting safety at a local level. Currently 40 to 50 communities across 15 different countries are working to establish safe community programs. However, currently only eight communities have been officially recognised by the World Health Organisation for achievements in injury prevention. These include Lidkoping, Motala and Faulkoping in Sweden; Toulouse in France; Esbjerg in Denmark; Wang Khoi in Thailand; and Castlemilk and Corkerhill in Glasgow, Scotland. Illawarra—including the municipalities that I mentioned earlier—has been the first Australian community to be proclaimed by the World Health Organisation for the many achievements in injury prevention. Coming from that community and having been an alderman on one of those constituent councils, it is with great pride that I recognise the achievements that have been made under the Illawara healthy cities program.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent program, by the way.

—It is an excellent program, as the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has said. Under that program, in 1992 the Illawarra established a whole range of long- and short-term safety programs. The first, the child injury prevention program, started in 1987. I must pay my respects to the RTA which externally funded this project with the aim of reducing accident injuries amongst all age groups in the Illawarra and making it a safer community. It addressed issues such as childhood, age, sports, domestic, road and workplace safety. The Illawarra safe communities program is all about working with all sectors of the community, such as health, education, local government and industry and community groups, et cetera, to identify local safety issues and find solutions to these problems. It also involves pooling of resources and working together on innovative safety projects. So far this has resulted in support and involvement from all sectors of the local community.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, it is with great pride that I can stand up in this place—I acknowledge the fact that you come from one of those constituent cities; we are both very proud to represent those areas—and proclaim to this parliament and to Australia in general the achievements that have come from that program, the cooperation from our civic leaders in local government, state authorities and federal programs.We come from an area which has traditionally been given a hard time because of its heavy industrial base. You and I know that there is a resurgence of community spirit—as with our beloved Steelers—of wanting to do things cooperatively, the feeling of being Australian. Cooperation at this level and making our communities much safer for all those involved is an ideal that we all respect and are prepared to work for. I commend this House to foster this program in all the communities that honourable members come from because it is a program that has very real benefits for the people who live within our communities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd to move—
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)recognises that Cape York Peninsula is a vast, diverse and important region of tropical Australia that is—
(a)economically important as a resource base for the mining, fishing, tourism and pastoral industries;
(b)culturally important as the traditional homelands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; and
(c)ecologically important as one of the world's last monsoonal regions undamaged by industrialised society;

(2)notes that a unique Commonwealth-State agreement has set up the Cape York Peninsula Land Use Strategy (CYPLUS) as a framework for making decisions about how to use and manage the natural resources of Cape York Peninsula in ways that will be economically, culturally and ecologically sustainable;

(3)commends the outstanding work that has been done by the CYPLUS Task Force and representative community groups during the past two years on Stage I of CYPLUS gathering information about the environment, the community and the land use;
(4)calls on the Queensland and Commonwealth Governments to adequately fund Stage II of the study which is intended to develop the policy and framework for land use decision making on Cape York; and
(5)emphasises that a key component of funding for Stage II must be full support for both a Community Regional Advisory Committee and for the various community interest groups on Cape York.
