TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there an agreement between the federal and South Australian governments, in addition to the Better Cities Agreement, which governs the funding and organisation of the Multifunction Polis (MFP); if so, what are its terms.
(2) What is the total anticipated expenditure on the MFP by federal government.
(3) What is the total expenditure of State and federal funds on the MFP to the date of answering this question.

(4) Was $10.2 million allocated to the MFP project under the Better Cities Program in 1992-93; if so, (a) what portion of the sum remains unspent, (b) what arrangements have been made with respect to unspent funds, and (c) will unspent funds be rolled over to the next financial year.
(5) How were funds allocated under the Better Cities Program and spent in 1992-93 disbursed.
(6) Are funds allocated under the Better Cities Program available for development on the MFP at sites other than at Gillman.
(7) Was the MFP Project the only application from South Australia for funds under the Better Cities Programs; if not, (a) which councils applied for funding and (b) for which projects.
(8) When will investment from Japanese companies in the MFP commence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. There is an Agreement on the MFP between the Commonwealth and South Australia that applies to the period 1 July 1991 to 30 June 1994.

The Commonwealth and South Australian Governments agreed to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding concerning their respective responsibilities for the development of the project. A copy of that Memorandum was signed on 31 July 1991 by the Hon J C Bannon, then Premier of South Australia on behalf of the South Australian Government and by the Hon John N Button, then Minister for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia.
The main terms of the Agreement outline the responsibilities of the Commonwealth and South Australian Government as:
Consistent with its objectives and policies, the Commonwealth Government agreed to assist with the development of the MFP by:
(i) applying policies and programs to assist the development of the MFP;

(ii) encourage other State and Territory Governments, through mechanisms such as its management of the Commonwealth/State Standing Committee on the MFP, to cooperate with and participate in the development of the MFP and, with the agreement of the other parties, to enter into a Commonwealth/State/Territory agreement relating to MFP;
(iii) facilitating the development of national and international opportunities which could contribute to the MFP;

(iv) coordinating through DITAC (now the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development), the involvement of Commonwealth departments and agencies in the MFP activities through the Commonwealth Standing IDC on the MFP;

(v) managing its responsibility for the International Advisory Board (IAB) and utilising it to help establish and strengthen international linkages, as well as to provide advice on particular MFP development issues;

(vi) subject to budgetary consideration, the Commonwealth Government agreed to provide funds to the South Australian Government in the amount of $5.55 million over the three financial years commencing 1991-92 to help establish the Corporation and for promotion and marketing activities. An indicative annual distribution of this amount was $2.4 million in 1991-92, $2.0 million in 1992-93 and $1.15 million in 1993-94.
South Australia agreed to:
(i) undertake responsibility including provision of resources for the development of a site at Gillman suitable as a location for MFP activities;
(ii) establish a MFP Development Corporation with the following responsibilities:
(a) planning, coordination and direction of core site activities;
(b) marketing and promotion (national and international activities in cooperation with the Commonwealth);
(c) finance;
(d) urban development;
(e) site management;
(f) community relations and awareness.

(2) Anticipated expenditure by the Commonwealth on the MFP Project to 30 June 1994 is $18.8 million. (Building Better Cities Program funding for the MFP/Northwest Crescent Area Strategy is not included).
Of this figure, $12.275 million was allocated for the three-year period to 30 June 1994 under the Cabinet Decision.

(3) Expenditure on the MFP Project to end-September 1993 from South Australian and Commonwealth sources was $25.7 million. (Building Better Cities funding for the MFP/Northwest Area Crescent Strategy is not included).
(4) Yes.
(a) $9.9 million.
(b) & (c) Unspent funds have been phased into later years of the program to reflect the level of proposed/planned activity.
(5) Funds are untied and paid weekly as additions to General Purpose Capital Assistance Grants. Funding levels are contingent upon satisfactory progress towards achievement of agreed outcomes.
(6) No. Funds allocated under the Building Better Cities Program are not available for development of the MFP at sites other than at Gillman, South Australia.
(7) MFP Australia did not apply for funding under the Building Better Cities Program.
(a) Councils are not eligible to apply for funding.
(b)The State Government applied for, and was allocated, funding for the following four Area Strategies in South Australia:
1. Elizabeth/Munro Para Area
2. Inner West Area
3. Southern Area
4. MFP/Northwest Crescent Area.

Area Strategies incorporate a number of projects and programs assessed against agreed milestones and outcomes, not individual projects. Commonwealth funding is allocated on an indicative basis to Area Strategies, not individual projects.

(8) Japanese investment has already taken place with Chiyoda Corporation investing in the pre-feasibility stage of the MFP Services Consortium. I might also mention that investment has already been obtained from the Pohang Iron & Steel Corporation of Korea.

In Japan, the 73-member strong MFP Australia Co-operation Association of Japan (MACAJ) has as its main role the promotion of the MFP through the dissemination of information to members, to assist new members interested in the MFP and to facilitate contact between Australian and Japanese companies.

Recently Mr Yahiro, Chairman of MACAJ said that Japanese companies will look at investment opportunities on their merits and take their own decisions. Of course, Japanese companies no less than Australian companies will invest only when it is commercially prudent to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is his Department reviewing low volume compliance plate approval arrangements; if so, has it been found that the current arrangements for low volume production are not being followed.
(2) Has the option for low volume approvals of up to 100 vehicles per year been removed; if so, why.
(3) Did officers of his Department personally inspect a number of vehicles to determine that current arrangements were not being followed; if so, how many vehicles were inspected.
(4) Are further changes to procedures being considered.
(5) Will the Department make compliance more expensive.
(6) Will the Department curtail the importation and conversion of second hand Japanese vehicles; if so, are changed arrangements a means to this end.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department has been conducting a review of low volume compliance plate approval arrangements as part of the Department's own policy of continuous improvement of its operations. The review also addressed the issue of whether the intent of the scheme, to provide access to specialist or enthusiast vehicles not otherwise available in Australia, was being achieved. The review found that the arrangements under the low volume scheme are not always being followed. The main areas of concern relate to assurance that vehicles meet the standards, particularly in regard to emissions.

(2) The option for low volume approvals up to 100 vehicles per annum has been removed for imported used cars. It is still available for new vehicles. The decision was taken because of concerns that some operators were seeking to use the option to operate at 100 vehicles per annum in arrangements to avoid the full cost of certification and the $12,000 duty on used cars imported in large numbers. These activities were seen to be contrary to the intent of the low volume scheme as set out in (1) above.

(3) Yes. Departmental officers inspected twenty vehicles and concluded that an issue existed. Action has been taken to advise operators of acceptable procedures to ensure compliance of production vehicles.

(4) The Department has a policy of continuous improvement of its overview of the safety and emissions of vehicles supplied to the Australian market. This includes measures to ensure that requirements will be met by all vehicles.

(5) There have been no changes to the requirements under the low volume scheme for the past three years. Some manufacturers have not been following those requirements and avoiding costs. A manufacturer who has been meeting the requirements will incur no additional costs.

(6) No. The Department of Transport is concerned with the safety and emissions of all vehicles when first supplied to the market in Australia. The low volume scheme is intended to provide for specialist or enthusiast vehicles and treats vehicles, irrespective of source, equally. Separate industry policy measures have already been introduced by the Government through the $12,000 duty on used cars imported in large numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 22 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the reduction in the company tax rate affect the assistance provided under the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development; if so, how.
(2) Would the concession need to be increased to maintain its value in relative terms; if so, to what level.
(3) Has the Minister's Department expressed concern at the reduction in relative value of the concession; if not, why not; if so, what was the Government's response.

(4) Has the Minister's Department analysed the impact of the relative reduction in value of the concession on industry and research and development activity; if not, why not; if so, what were the findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The after-tax cost of R&D has increased from 41.5 cents in the dollar at a company tax rate of 39 per cent to 50.5 cents in the dollar following the recent decrease in the company tax rate to 33 per cent.

(2) The 150 per cent tax concession (in relation to the present 33 per cent company tax rate) would need to be raised to 177 per cent to reduce the after-tax cost of R&D to the level pertaining with a 39 per cent company tax rate.

(3) and (4) The Bureau of Industry Economics in its recently published major review of the R&D tax concession scheme concluded that the scheme is more likely to be welfare enhancing than not and consequently recommended its retention. The BIE concluded that the tax concession had played a role in increasing industrial R&D as a proportion of GDP, and it pointed to the significant benefits derived by other firms and by customers (the spillover effect of the concession).

In its analysis, the BIE examined the impact of a reduction in the company tax rate on R&D. It concluded that there was a basis for an increase in the tax deduction to 160 or 165 per cent to compensate for the reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. However, the Bureau stated that it would not argue strongly in favour of such a change.
The BIE's review is currently under consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: DITARD: Reports by McKinsey and Co.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minster for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 22 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many reports has McKinsey and Company prepared for, in conjunction with, or on behalf of, the Minister's Department, its predecessor or any statutory authority or council for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility.
(2) With respect to each of the reports referred to in part (1) what was its: (a) purpose and (b) cost.

(3) Was a tendering process conducted with respect to each contract entered into with McKinsey for the preparation of a report: if not, (a) why not and (b) on what basis was McKinsey awarded the contract; if so, (i) how many tenders were received, (ii) how was McKinsey selected and (iii) what was the duration of the contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: In respect to the Department, its predecessor or any statutory authority or council in the portfolio, only the Department, the Australian Manufacturing Council Secretariat and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation contracted McKinsey and Company in the period from 1991 to 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT

PARA.TAB: (1) In the period 1991 to 1993 the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development engaged McKinsey and Company to produce one report.
(2) With respect to each of the reports referred to in part (1):
(a) the purpose of the report was to develop of a strategy on business investment in regional Australia;
(b) the cost is $1,250,000.
(3) A tendering process was conducted in respect of this contract:
(a) not applicable;
(b) McKinsey and Company was awarded the contract on the following basis:
(i) twenty two proposals were received,
(ii) they were selected by an inter-departmental committee comprising representatives from the Department and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet,
(iii) the duration of the contract is six months.

(1) In the period 1991 to 1993 the Australian Manufacturing Council Secretariat (AMCS) received one report Emerging Exporters—Australia's High Value Added Manufacturing Exporters from McKinsey and Company. A report on a follow-up study to Emerging Exporters, is currently being conducted with a report, Growth Linkages available in March 1994.
(2) With respect to each of the reports referred to in part (1):

(a) the purpose of the Emerging Exporters report was to investigate the emergence of significant Australian exporters of elaborately transformed manufactured goods and associated high value services; the purpose of the Growth Linkages report is to identify and understand the critical linkages or structures which influence firms export growth, differentiated by a range of factors including firm size, export propensity and levels of foreign ownership;
(b) the cost of: Emerging Exporters was $605,000 and Growth Linkages is expected to be $600,000.
(3) In respect to Emerging Exporters a restricted tendering process was conducted in respect to this contract:
(a) not applicable;
(b) McKinsey and Company was awarded the contract on the following basis:
(i) three tenders were invited to submit proposals,
(ii) they were selected by a sub-committee of the Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC) who examined the proposals, interviewed the consultants and submitted a recommendation to the AMC Executive.
(iii) the duration of the contract was seventeen months.
In respect to Growth Linkages no tendering process was conducted in respect of this contract:

(a) the AMCS did not call for tenders on this project: because of the strict time constraints due to the Industry Statement; and the proposed study, being a direct follow on from the Emerging Exporters work previously undertaken by McKinsey and Company and utilising existing date, meant that McKinsey and Company was the only organisation with the relevant immediate expertise and capabilities.
(b) Not applicable.

ANSWER.PARA: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION (CSIRO)

PARA.TAB: (1) In the period 1991 to 1993 the CSIRO received two reports from McKinsey and Company. The reports are:
(A) Towards More Successful Interaction with Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises
(B) Report to assist the Institute of Minerals, Energy and Construction in an exercise designed to support an overall research program definition and assessment process.
(2) With respect to each of the reports referred to in part (1):

(a) the purpose of (A) was to examine the reasons why small to medium-sized, emerging, export-oriented firms make limited use of CSIRO and to propose and analyse possible models for increasing the level and effectiveness of interaction between such firms and CSIRO. The purpose of (B) was to design an overall research program definition and assessment process that would ensure that the Institute of Minerals, Energy and Construction was generating maximum value for Australia from its research.
(b) the cost was $262,000 for (A) and $146,914 for (B).
(3) No tendering process was conducted in respect to either contract:

(a) tenders were not called for (A) because the report was an extension of work done by McKinsey and Company for the Australian Manufacturing Council on the performance, key success factors and challenges faced by a large number of small-to-medium-sized Australian exporting companies; and for
(B) because of prior relevant experience;

(b) the basis on which McKinsey and Company was awarded the contract: in relation to (A) they were judged to provide the best value for money in this case because of their prior work on the same topic for the Australian Manufacturing Council. This work had generated significant data and information on which the Company could draw in addressing the issues posed by the CSIRO Board. No other company had similar information at its disposal. In relation to (B) they were judged to provide the best value for money in this case because in 1987, as part of the restructuring of CSIRO in which the Company played a guiding role, the Institute had participated as a model for CSIRO line management principles. This background was considered an important prerequisite to the work as both exercises had a common basis to encourage an outcome orientated approach from program managers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 18 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he identify the Renewable Energy Industry Development Strategy as having (a) substantial market opportunities and (b) the potential to assist Australia in meeting its obligations under the Framework Convention on Climate Change.
(2) What action (a) has been taken, (b) is being taken and (c) will be taken by (i) the Minister and (ii) the Minister's Department to implement the Renewable Energy Industry Development Strategy.
(3) What funds have been or will be allocated in the Minister's Department to the Strategy in (a) 1992-93, (b) 1993-94 and (c) 1994-95.
(4) Will the (a) funds and (b) staff allocated in the Minister's Department to the Strategy vary; if so, (i) how and (ii) by what quantity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) At present there is no Government program with this title.
However, the Department has been working with industry to identify appropriate industry and enterprise development activities for the renewable energy industry which might attract Government support.

The need for this arose from a recognition not only of the market opportunities for renewable energy products but also the potential that utilisation of these products has in assisting Australia to meet its obligations under the Framework Convention on Climate Change.

(2) In 1993 the Department was involved in the establishment of a renewable energy industry Working Group. This Group has consulted widely with the industry, principally by holding several discussion workshops to identify possible future directions for the industry and the industry and government actions needed to follow these. The Group has worked closely with the Department.
The Department is actively considering how this work can be further developed.

The Department has informed the Minister of the progress of this work, including consideration of possible future action to develop the Australian renewable energy industry as part of the Government's forthcoming Industry Statement and in the 1994-95 Budget context.
(3) There have been no program funds available for this work in 1992-93 and 1993-94.
Administration funds of some $8000 were provided to support 0.5 ASL in 1992-93.
Administration funds of $30,000 have been allocated to support 1.8 ASL in 1993-94.
Any funds available in 1994-95 will be determined in the Budget context.
(4) Funds and staff allocated in the Department beyond the end of 1993-94 will be determined in the Budget context.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister's Department employ proper accounting procedures to record departmental purchases; if so, (a) what system is used, (b) are all purchases recorded and (c) to what extent are records accessible by auditors, departmental officers and other officials; if not, (i) why not and (ii) what procedures are used for appropriate financial management and reconciliation of purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(a) Dun and Bradstreet Software (DBS), Millenium Software product.
(b) Yes, all purchases are recorded.
(c) All records are fully accessible as required by auditors, departmental officers and other officials.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister's Department employ proper accounting procedures to record departmental purchases; if so, (a) what system is used, (b) are all purchases recorded and (c) to what extent are records accessible by auditors, departmental officers and other officials; if not, (i) why not and (ii) what procedures are used for appropriate financial management and reconciliation of purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) Yes, the Department does employ proper accounting procedures to record departmental purchases. All Divisions of the Department, except the Australian Industrial Property Office (AIPO), use the Government Accounts Management and Estimating System (GAMES). AIPO uses the Financial Efficiency—Strategic Planning System (FINEST).
(b) Yes, all purchases are recorded.

(c) Financial records are made available to internal and external auditors, relevant departmental officers, and officials as appropriate. Annual audits of the Departmental accounts are undertaken by the Australian National Audit Office.

(ii) The Department has Secretary's Accounting Instructions which, inter alia, provide Departmental officers with procedures for the purchase of goods and services on behalf of the Commonwealth, and the procedures to be followed in relation to the custody and control of Departmental stores and assets. Stocktakes of all departmental assets are undertaken annually.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 1 February, 1994:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister's Department employ proper accounting procedures to record departmental purchases; if so, (a) what system is used, (b) are all purchases recorded and (c ) to what extent are records accessible by auditors, departmental officers and other officials; if not, (i) why not and (ii) what procedures are used for appropriate financial management and reconciliation of purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes.
(a) `SunSystems' accounting software.
(b) Yes.
(c) Both on-line access and paper reports. Access to officials other than departmental staff and auditors is not generally available and would need to be considered on an individual basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Has the Minister written to a wide range of industry associations, trade unions and businesses seeking input to the forthcoming industry statement; if so, to which industry associations, trade unions and businesses were letters sent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Since becoming the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development I have not written to any organisations seeking input to the industry statement. However, my predecessor as Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development had written to a large number of industry associations, trade unions and businesses seeking input to the forthcoming industry statement. Additionally, on 4 November 1993, a media release from the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development extended an invitation from the former Minister to all interested organisations or individuals to contribute ideas for the industry statement.

For my part, I have begun meeting personally with a wide range of industry associations, trade unions and businesses in the period leading up to the Industry Statement. I will be pursuing a very active program of further meetings and discussions over the coming weeks.
